name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the statements of the Council and the Commission on the presentation of the programme of activities of the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council (2017/2910 (RSP)). I would like to take this opportunity to welcome Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borissov to the European Parliament and to thank him. There will certainly be no shortage of cooperation with the Bulgarian Presidency by this Parliament. Of course we are all interested in listening to his words.

name: Бойко Борисов
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr Tajani, President of the European Parliament, Mr Juncker, President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen, chairs of parliamentary groups, honorable MEPs, it is a great honor for us to be here among you, the people who forge European rights. laws, in the highest body of the European Union, with which I hope to work as well as possible over the next six months. I am also convinced that this European Parliament has until the next elections and little but enough time to do a lot of work on the basic laws that need to be adopted. I am convinced and I want to assure you that when you need our expertise in the Western Balkans, in cohesion policy and in migration, we are at your disposal to share our experience, and of course to make a commitment, which you would impute to us. There are four priorities for our presidency: the future of Europe and young people as a key priority; the European perspective and connectivity of the Western Balkans; a secure and stable Europe; the digital economy and the skills needed for the future, which is also of direct and important importance for the whole internal market. I assume that after your speeches and later after the questions, there will be a lot to talk about, but I would still like to share with you why and in what areas I think it is important to make progress during our presidency, to have a debate and to look for the most serious and correct solutions. For 30 minutes now, we have been debating with President Tajani, and many times with the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, on the Dublin agreements, on tackling the flow of migration. I dare say that Bulgaria managed to make the migration pressure zero within a year. This was achieved with a lot of work, and I think that on the Bulgarian-Turkish border we showed how together with European solidarity and assistance - thanks to the Council of Bratislava, which allocated 160 million euro for technical means - with the efforts of the state and with the agreement we have with Turkey, we can work to minimize the flow of migration. And yet you know that we have a huge sea border on the Black Sea with Turkey and a large land border. Therefore, on the subject of Turkey, I believe that the agreement must be signed, must continue to work and that we must try - despite the firm position we have and which we must defend with regard to the rights of the media in Turkey, with regard to the rule of law. law - pragmatically try to resolve the issue of the migration agreement to continue to work, because there are millions of migrants who are currently cared for by the Turkish side. Of course, one of the main topics, one of the main disputes between the Member States, is how to relocate migrants entering Europe afterwards and how to take care of them. We will try to solve this issue with a lot of tact, with a lot of diplomacy, because on the one hand, in several countries of the European Union there is a huge concentration of migrants - they put a lot of effort, spend huge resources. Other countries do not want to take part in this process, and there is a third group of countries, such as Bulgaria, Greece and Italy, which are at the very entrance of the migrant wave and I think that we should find a solution to support the common protection of the European border. The solution, in my opinion - something I have always insisted on for years - is to guard our external borders so that entry into Europe takes place only through checkpoints and there is a proper check. And for those fleeing wars, fleeing bullets and missiles, for which Europe has always been the most humane, let us take care, but let it be known that this will be until the end of military conflicts. Or to make centers, safe centers, which we can support and provide financially close to military conflicts, so that people can then return and participate in the reconstruction of their countries, because perhaps you have all seen in the news, the degree of destruction where there is such a war. And those who are economic migrants should be allowed where they are needed. These are the suggestions I have for a solution, of course you will tell me how to do it. As far as the Western Balkans are concerned, there are several options, so we have proposed one that I do not think poses a risk to the European Union. We are sure, we know, and Jean-Claude Juncker was in Sofia only a few days ago - thanks to President Tajani, Jean-Claude Juncker and President Tusk for coming to Sofia to open the Bulgarian Presidency - that in the mandate of this Commission there will be no new Member States from the Balkans accepted into the European Union. At the same time, we must tell them very clearly and very honestly what hopes they can have, how our views on their integration into Europe would be set in time. I dare say, knowing the region, that this is the right time to do it. You see how a shot in Kosovo literally blew up the whole Balkans yesterday, the Kosovo-Serbia negotiation process and immediately the mood changed. At the moment, the peoples of the Balkans truly expect and believe that, being geographically and historically in Europe, they will finally have a plan to join the European Union. Some are ahead, some are further back. I think that Bulgaria and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have given an exceptional example that there are countries in the Balkans that can solve problems with tact and goodwill and not come to you with their problems. The good-neighborly agreement between Bulgaria and Macedonia, which has been dragging on or being worked on for decades, but was not accepted anyway, was signed only a few days ago. Yesterday, respectively, the Macedonian Parliament adopted it, ratified it, now, I hope, next week and the Bulgarian, but Prime Minister Zaev was, as he said, quite brave, as we are. We really hope that the name process between Skopje and Athens will also end now, because that will give Skopje a great perspective. I say this not by chance to irritate my Greek colleagues, but to give a perspective to NATO and the European Union, because this is a place in the Balkans that is like a cornerstone, the one that holds the construction sites - and if it moves, they start moving. the whole Balkans. What would happen if we did not make this decision, we did not work on building the infrastructure? I would just like to remind you that Corridor № 4, Corridor № 8 and Corridor № 10 are European corridors and we have the rare chance to prepare the Western Balkans for both investment and tourism without any risk. Let us not allow them to become depopulated, let us not allow young and skilled people to leave for America or Europe and leave there mostly elderly people, let there be no one to work for the payment of pensions that ensure a normal life. Bulgaria went through this path. And then completely different political parties appear and I don't know if the process will be able to continue. If we do not do it - the interest that Russia, Turkey, China and Saudi Arabia have in the Balkans is great - someone else will. That is why we are ready to work with everyone individually, I know the region, we have held multiple meetings with all leaders in Sofia and Belgrade, and now is the time to give them perspective. I really hope for the support of Mr Tajani, Mr Juncker and all of you, because the stability of the Balkans is directly responsible for the stability of Europe. Then we will wonder where Islamic fighters came from or where radical Islam came from, because there is a lot of fertile ground there, due to the large percentage of the Muslim population living in the Balkans. The way out is a European perspective. They expect it, they want it. In this way we will be able to have the necessary influence and security in this region. Of course, on the subject of Turkey I said. The topic of Russia, with all the remarks we have, there are Member States that they want the sanctions to fall, others are just the opposite - extremely harsh, they want to deepen even more. Ultimately, we will try to seek normalization of relations with our other big neighbor, such as Russia, but of course this far exceeds our threshold of opportunity. This will be a pan-European solution. In connection with all this, as we are already working with Commissioner Oettinger, with Jean-Claude Juncker, with President Tajani we have now talked for a long time, is the common European budget. I do not make it a follow-up priority. I trust and rely on the European Parliament very much, because the budget of a country or the budget of Europe actually makes the policy, gives the challenges and through the budget and the financing of the individual programs, we will be able to defend a given priority accordingly. Is the common agricultural policy important? It is important. Is cohesion policy important? It is extremely important. If we, the recently admitted countries of Central and Eastern Europe, the Balkans have prosperity - here I am making a bracket: Bulgaria has 4% economic growth, 6% unemployment, zero budget deficit, huge fiscal reserve, fixed because we have a currency board, the exchange rate of the lev to the euro, we are making efforts and I think we are ready for the 'waiting room' of the euro area - these policies have largely contributed to this. They contributed to what we managed to build in the field of infrastructure, competitiveness, educational infrastructure, ecology, transport, and here is the place to thank all donor countries that have helped so much for Bulgaria, but I think for the whole region. I have impressions of the former socialist countries before 1989, of what they looked like then. Now, when you go to Budapest, Prague, Bratislava or Warsaw, the difference is huge. And I think here we need to find the balance of mutual respect for the donor countries that have given billions of euros for our accession, in order to reach and be competitive with their economies and everything else, and what we have not only as a market but also as a culture, as a geostrategic location, so I think there is nothing better than walking all together and there is no better place to live . It is no coincidence that everyone wants to come to Europe, to the European Union. So cohesion policy must continue. In just a few words, I would go through the common European defense. Given the great geopolitical challenges we are facing at the moment, I think we are looking a little at the threats. We usually react a lot after they have already happened. We let whole processes develop and we be a kind of spectator. We leave the presidents of the big countries - Russia, the United States, China, Turkey, Iran - to make decisions on issues that we are actually facing with a terrible force in Europe. From these wars come migratory flows. When there were banking crises, then Europe paid the big price and we - around the clock - I remember there was advice until 5-6 o'clock in the morning - solved the financial crisis in Europe. It is an honor for all those who ruled the Council, the Commission and Parliament at the time - I apologize if I sometimes confuse the seats. This is not out of disrespect, just out of a desire to use my time and speak faster. But we have managed, albeit slowly, to deal with the financial crisis. Europe is already growing and I am convinced that there is no one better than us, that is for sure, than a united and strong Europe. The energy union, the social pillar, what Jean-Claude Juncker proposed yesterday ... I have three options to read, long and tidy, but on the one hand I want to save your time and at the same time really feel what is very important for us and what we consider a priority and to be able to clarify with the questions to us if there is something misunderstood. Not to miss Yuri and the Estonian presidency. I think Estonia did a great job, they put a lot of effort, they were very modern. It will be a joy for us if we can get closer to Estonia's good performance. And I dare say that with the Chancellor of Austria Sebastian Kurz, who is the next president in 2018, we already have maybe 4-5 phone calls. He will come to Sofia very soon and we want to work on the Bulgarian and Austrian presidencies so that in 2018 all the priorities we have, both we and they, are not interrupted, but to continue with your help in all portfolios for which I spoke. Finally, on the crucial role of the European Parliament. I know that there are many parliamentary groups, many different opinions. Our strength is in this diversity that we have in Europe. But in the end, the most important and most valuable thing that we in Bulgaria have written to our parliament is that "Unity makes strength" That is why we proposed and believe that this would be the most appropriate motto for Europe as well - "Unity makes strength".

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you above all for reiterating, during your speech, the centrality of the European Parliament in the action on behalf of the citizens, in favor of the improvement of our Union.This is an important step and an important recognition, which will allow us to work well together.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, let me start by saying that one of the most pleasing aspects of the Bulgarian Presidency is that I will get to see my good friend Boyko more often than usual. As I said to him when he hosted the Commission in Sofia last week, this is a special moment - for Bulgaria, of course, because it is the first Bulgarian Presidency of the Council - but also for me personally. It was under the Luxembourgish Presidency - with myself in the chair of the European Council - that the decisions necessary to launch the overall enlargement process was taken in Luxembourg in December 1997. As President of the European Council once again, I had the honor of signing Bulgaria's accession treaty to the European Union in Luxembourg in April 2005. I remember the year 2005 for so many reasons, in particular because we signed the accession treaty in April. I remember that day like it was yesterday. I remember the emotion that I felt at seeing Europe’s history and geography reconciled. I remember what it meant to a proud European nation to join its friends and allies in our Union. The clocks you had installed everywhere throughout Sofia counting down the days until Bulgaria’s EU accession is a picture I always have in my mind. I felt a kind of ‘Anticipation’, as the Germans say - ‘pre-happiness’, to some extent. The hope and joy we all felt on that day must never fade away. I even remember some of the words I used: that day I said (I sometimes say things like that) that 'history without truth is like a day without light', and the truth is that Bulgaria had to come a long way to join our Union. It had to make changes in a handful of years, that other countries made in decades. It had to be patient; it had to be determined; it had to be courageous, and it was. Today it is with great pride, but also with great expectation, that I look forward to the next six Bulgarian months. Monsieur le Président, Mesdames, Messieurs, je me félicite que la présidence bulgare se soit particulièrement bien prepared for ces six mois, car ces six mois bulgares seront cruciaux pour l’Union et pour son avenir. J’ai pu constater la bonne préparation de la présidence, la semaine passée, lorsque la Commission s’est rendue à Sofia. Pour les Bulgares, pour nous tous, il s’agirait d’abord de finaliser les travaux sur les grands enjeux pour lesquels une action européenne efficace peut véritablement faire la différence. Depending on the pense notamment à la migration, à l’économie numérique et à la sécurité. The Premier ministre a fait de la recherche du consensus l’une de ses grandes priorités. C’est toujours, en Europe, un choix judicieux, qui s’impose aujourd’hui plus que jamais. Depuis novembre 2014, depuis le début du mandat de la Commission, celle-ci a présenté 89 dossiers prioritaires aux colégislateurs, dont 29 ont été adoptés à ce jour. D’ici au mois de mai, toutes nos propositions auront été mises sur la table des colégislateurs afin de permettre au Parlement et au Conseil de terminer le travail législatif avant les prochaines élections européennes. La grande priorité, voire l'urgence des prochains mois, sera donc de traduire ces propositions en actes législatifs et de mettre cette législation en œuvre, car plus le Parlement et le Conseil parviendront à conclure rapidement le processus législatif, plus nos concitoyens rapid ressentirontens effets positifs de nos politiques dans leur vie quotidienne. Le temps presse et j’aimerais vraiment que ce travail aboutisse avant le prochain rendez-vous des Européens avec le suffrage universel. Et puisque le "B" de Bulgarie veut alsi dire "budechte", ce qui signifie le futur, il s'agira également de preper l'avenir en définissant nos ambitions européennes pour les prochaines années, ainsi que le budget qui sera nécessaire pour les réaliser. Il faudra évidemment faire des choix, décider quels sont les domaines où nous devons dépenser plus et ceux où nous pourrions dépenser moins ou différemment. C’est la raison pour laquelle je plaide pour un débat vertueux qui doit d’abord porter sur le fond des choses, sur les priorités, sur le contenu et puis sur les financements indispensables, et pas l’inverse. Ne commençons pas le débat budget en fixant des plafonds, commençons le débat budget en nous mettant d’accord sur les priorités et sur les contenus. (Applaudissements) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Bulgaria has repeatedly demonstrated that it can contribute to European compromises and build bridges - both among the current Member States and with our neighbors in the Western Balkans. Bulgaria is predestined for this, as it knows the region, the culture, the people, their characteristics, their languages ​​and has successfully gone through the difficult EU enlargement process itself. Whenever I am asked about EU enlargement, I therefore refer to Bulgaria, which has achieved great things, including in terms of economic development. The Bulgarian economy grew by 3.9% last year, employment is developing positively, Bulgaria has an excellent grip on its public debt and budget, better than many member states of the euro zone. These are the best conditions for Bulgaria to be able to join the European Exchange Rate Mechanism 2 - the so-called ERM II - and in a few years also the euro. Nominal convergence is important, but so is real convergence. There is still a lot to be done here, including the fight against corruption, and I know that the Bulgarian government is working very hard in this direction. Bulgaria is a real success story that can and will inspire our neighbors in the Western Balkans. It was therefore right that the Bulgarian Prime Minister made the Western Balkans and our relations with the Western Balkans a priority of his presidency. At the On May 17th a Western Balkans Summit will take place in Sofia. This is the right address to talk about the Western Balkans and our relations with the Western Balkans. In Sofia I will also end my trip through the Balkan countries, which I will undertake at the end of February / beginning of March, because I would like to find out on site what the expectations of the various countries are like. And I would also like to tell these Balkan countries what our expectations are of the Western Balkans. Accession doesn't just happen - it doesn't fall from the sky, it has to be worked for. And I would like to say here - in a friendly, as friendly way as possible - that all border conflicts that exist between the Western Balkans must be resolved before accession. Not that we are seeing, as we are now with Croatia / Slovenia, that the problems at hand are only discussed after accession - years after accession. The problems - the border problems - must be resolved before there will be further accessions. (Applause) The countries of the Western Balkans deserve to be given a real European perspective. These accessions will not take place during the term of office of this Parliament and this Commission because not all conditions will be met by then. But the goal must be clearly stated: the goal is the accession of the Western Balkan countries, and these accession can take place once the necessary reforms are made in these countries. Then accession will move closer bit by bit. We have joint projects with the states in this region - security issues, migration, transport, digital, energy and others. The rule of law is one of these projects because the rule of law is the foundation on which our Union, which is a community of law, rests. It is such a fundamental value that only states that adhere to it can join. If this applies before joining, it will of course apply if you have become a member, even after joining. (Applause) We are in - yes - constructive dialogue with the Polish government. I received the new Polish Prime Minister in Brussels and we both tried to bring our positions closer together. We are not at war with Poland, we have a dispute with the Polish government. Recourse to Article 7 (1) of the Treaty is not a sanction. It is a statement and warning article. That is why we should stop - and stop doing so in Poland too - pretending that we are determined to sanction Poland - whatever happens. That is not the content of Article 7 Paragraph 1. (Applause) I appeal to the Bulgarian Prime Minister, Boyko Borissov and his government to participate constructively and in a compromise way in this undertaking on the rule of law in Poland. One of the tasks of a presidency is to seek compromises. But it is also one of the tasks of the presidency to implement decisions taken by the Council of Ministers, at least to help so that they can be implemented. I do not want to abuse this speech in order to make another long digression about Brexit. But yesterday I was unable to answer all the questions that were asked, especially those that our colleague Henkel asked. I am of the opinion that there will be no winners when it comes to Brexit. This is a lose-lose situation, both for the British and for the members of the European Union and for the institutions. I still see Britain's exit as a catastrophe, even a defeat, that we must all tackle. But the reasons for the British decision are deeper. As Mrs May herself said, the British have never felt comfortable in the European Union and have not been given the opportunity for 40 years either given to be able to feel more comfortable. And that's why many are to blame. We - Mr Tusk and myself - held out our hands again yesterday and said to the British Government that if the British people, the British Parliament, the British Government wanted to go any other way than Brexit, then we are ready , to talk about it. We're not throwing the British out. We would like the British to stay. And if that's what you want, then that's what you should do. (Applause) But I noticed that people in London reacted almost piquely to this suggestion. So be it. But even if the British have resigned under Article 50, there is also an Article 49 that allows re-entry. I would like that and I would like us to treat each other sensibly now and not try to sideline each other. (Applause) Mr Henkel asked whether I really wanted to go down in history as the one responsible for Brexit. That calls for a double answer. First of all, I am glad that Mr. Henkel - and we have been with one another for many years - assumes that I will go down in history; I didn't know that before. And when it came to Brexit, I said what I had to say. I am confident that the Bulgarian Presidency will do well. Prime Minister Borissov is a proven European democrat with a strong will and conviction and persuasiveness. (Applause) We know from experience that what matters is not the size of the country, but the strength of will that inspires a government. In the matter of Borissov and in the matter of Bulgaria everything is right for this presidency to be a success. Blagodarya! For those who are less fluent in Bulgarian, that means "thank you". (Continued applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Now let's start the discussion.Normally I am flexible on the times, but please respect them today as the day is very busy.After this very important debate we will have another very important debate with the Irish Prime Minister, then there will be the votes, then there will be the working lunches, so we will not be able, neither I nor the Vice-Presidents who will replace me, be flexible regarding the times.I also ask the presidents of the groups, to whom I often and willingly allow a few more seconds, to be a little more rigorous today.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: im Namen der PPE-Fraktion. – Herr Präsident, Herr Kommissionspräsident, Herr Ratspräsident, Herr Premierminister! Willkommen im Europäischen Parlament und willkommen zu einer historischen Stunde: der Übernahme der Ratspräsidentschaft durch Bulgarien. Wenn man das in Bezug setzt mit den letzten 30 Jahren – der Kampf gegen den Kommunismus, der Kampf für die Freiheit und heute die Möglichkeit, dass Bulgarien Europa führt: eine wunderbare Entwicklung, die eingetreten ist.  Die bulgarischen Bürger können darauf stolz sein, weil sie immer proeuropäisch gehandelt haben. Bulgarien als Land kann stolz sein und, Herr Premierminister, ich glaube, Sie dürfen auch stolz sein, weil auch Sie bewiesen haben, dass Sie Bulgarien in diesen Jahren, Jahrzehnten hervorragend führen und viel Vertrauen von Ihren Bürgern bekommen haben.  The first question now we have the Bulgarian Presidency is what can we learn from Bulgaria? I think that is a good starting point, and one of the lessons we can learn is to look to the economy in Bulgaria. The growth rate is double that of neighbouring Serbia, and that shows that being part of Europe means strong economic success. When you look at Bulgaria, then you can learn that you can count on its values, it has a modernised state that is going forward with European values in the fight against corruption. That is what Bulgaria has been doing in recent years, very successfully. And, finally, we can learn that Bulgaria wants to be a full part of the European Union. It has a clear idea about the next steps ahead: to be part of Schengen and to be part of the euro area. The clear commitments from the Bulgarian Government gives us a clear indication that we should believe in our project. That is what we can learn from Bulgaria, and now let’s have a look at the tasks which are ahead of us. First, I want to underline what Jean-Claude Juncker also said, that the most important thing will certainly be the debate about finances in the European Union. The debate about the multiannual framework of our budget will start in the first half of 2018, and we as the EPP ask for an ambitious approach. We support Jean—Claude Juncker’s view that first of all we have to define what the priorities for Europe are, and then we have to talk about the necessary funding. The second task is migration. A kind of final debate in the European Council about the migration challenge for the European Union is planned in June. Prime Minister Borissov underlined his country’s success story in protecting the border. That is one big thing. The second big point in migration management is to practise solidarity inside the European Union. Hopefully we can manage in the next weeks and months to bring these two things together. On the management of the border, let me finally underline that we are asking for more European engagement, for there not only to be Bulgarian officials standing on the border, but that Frontex should also be more present in the border region. We ask for more Frontex staff. Finally, dear friends, the Western Balkans is the third task ahead; a really important task. The Western Balkans is part of Europe and has a chance to become a member of the European Union. When we and the Commission look at the Commission proposal on the enlargement process, we are in favour of this perspective for the Western Balkans and we as the EPP want to focus mainly on concrete projects. People must see that it is a benefit, a positive development to be part of the European Union. So let’s focus on infrastructure, on railways, on motorways. That is what people expect from us. There is a lot to do. We wish the Bulgarian Presidency all the best, and the EPP will support our friend Boyko Borissov.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, first of all, and on behalf of my group, I would like to express our deep respect for Bulgaria and for the Bulgarian citizens, who have demonstrated their commitment to European values ​​and to European integration. You arrive at a time of tough ideological battle. An ideological battle between open and supportive Europeanism and the worst ghosts of exclusive populist nationalism. You see, ladies and gentlemen, hearing today about the defense of the white race by a European leader produces real chills. So you have a lot of work ahead of you if you want to push the European Union exactly on the path of openness, solidarity and the future. You have presented a very well put together program, and I would like you to stand out, to leave your mark on some of those policies that you present. If we European socialists were to elect a mark of the Bulgarian presidency, we would like it to be justice. Social justice. The development of the social pillar that so many Europeans are waiting for. Social justice, which will not be possible without tax justice. We need, gentlemen of the Bulgarian Presidency, fiscal harmonization in Europe so that convergence is possible, so that development and the fight against inequality are possible. We share your intention to work hard to develop the Digital Single Market. And if we are serious about migration - we did so in this House yesterday, in the presence of the Council and the Commission - I will tell you that this Parliament has done its job. The Commission, too. We are awaiting the Council's decisions. It is the Council that now has to make the decisions and you know very well, Mr Borisov - because, furthermore, you are Bulgarian and understand this logic very well - that we need a common system of asylum and migration in Europe, and that we need reform the Dublin Regulation urgently. We count on you For that. But there is also the rule of law, democracy, the defense of democratic values ​​- Article 7 that the Commission has activated with respect to the Polish Government - freedom of expression, the fight against corruption. All of this is part of European values. His contribution in the Western Balkans is also highly anticipated. Europe is a community - this is not a cliché - that has to defend the same values ​​everywhere and the same values ​​for all citizens. My group will not accept any discrimination. Bulgaria and Romania must be part of Schengen. Nothing will be easy, but you can count on this group if you go down this road. And one last thing, Mr. President. I want to ask you, on behalf of the women of the European Union, but also of the friends of the women of the European Union, that the European Union ratify, once and for all, the Istanbul Convention, because integrity, freedom and the dignity of women deserves all the efforts of European democrats.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Prime Minister. Dobre doshli. Whilst the Bulgarian Presidency begins the last full year of this parliamentary term, it will be six months which could set the parameters for the future EU—UK relationship.  Mr Juncker, you should not take responsibility for the UK voting to leave. If responsibility lies anywhere, it is with the political class in Britain who, for the last 40 years, have not been honest about the political dimension of the EU, pretending that the EU was only about trade. Whilst Brexit has dominated the agenda of late, the ECR Group believes that the urgent must not crowd out what is important: the need for reform, fiscal responsibility and doing less, but doing it better. The ECR Group hopes that the Brexit negotiations will not just lead to a new EU-UK relationship, but act as a catalyst for a reformed EU. We hope the Bulgarian Presidency will be vocal and resolute in the face of continued Russian aggression in Ukraine. We hope that you will help Western Balkan countries on their journey of reform and, on the migration crisis, that you will ask EU countries what they can do to help – whether giving resources or taking people – rather than telling them what to do. I look forward to working with you and your team and we wish you every success in the six months ahead. Blagodarya.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr. president; Mr Prime Minister, we hope that you will successfully face the challenge of effectively implementing the reform - currently under negotiation - of the rules of the Common European Asylum System, so that the corresponding negotiations can begin as soon as possible. Also indicate that there is no immigration without integration, and there is no integration without immigration control. They are two essential parts. You have said it: Bulgaria is directly aware of the communal tension, the larval confrontation existing in the Western Balkans. This crisis has only one way: to deepen the European values ​​of respect for human rights, for the democratic freedoms that make up the European Union. The destination is Europe, and the solution is our common home. The European Union-Balkans summit next May is therefore crucial for peace and stability in the region. Prime Minister, populism, exclusive nationalism, corruption are the enemies of Europe. You must pay attention to those points. I also want to express the solidarity of the ALDE Group to you and to the Bulgarian people in the face of the unacceptable delays that prevent your country from joining the Schengen area. They have worked hard and well and the wait must end. The ALDE Group, this Parliament, all Europeans hope that your Presidency will be fruitful. In your endeavor, Prime Minister, you can count on us.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr Juncker, Mr Borissov, ten years after its accession, Bulgaria is taking over the Presidency of the European Union for the first time. This is an important moment and that is why I would like to personally welcome the Bulgarian Prime Minister to the European Parliament: "Dobre Dosal Minister-Presidential!" (Welcome Prime Minister!). Several of the priorities of the Bulgarian Presidency are also of particular importance to my political group on the European Left: youth unemployment, the brain drain we need to play, the social economy and the strengthening of the social pillar. education, immigration issues. However, I would like to place particular emphasis on the European perspective of the Western Balkans. I am glad that President Juncker has reiterated that the goal is the integration of the Western Balkans, but the Bulgarian Presidency is the ideal place to take steps on these issues. And in order to take steps, the countries of the Western Balkans and the European Union must also make progress through dialogue in respect for the rule of law, freedom of expression and information, the rights of national and social minorities, the fight against inequalities, unemployment, poverty. Recently, major co-operation initiatives have been taken in the Balkans. The Tsipras-Borissov agreement on joint infrastructure investments, the dialogue that begins today between the governments of Athens and Skopje on a solution to the long-standing name issue - which I believe will lead to a solution that will be good for both Greece and FYROM for both the Western Balkans and the European Union - is the road that can turn the Balkans from a European powder keg to a bridge of cooperation between the European Union, the Eastern Mediterranean, the Middle East. The Bulgarian Presidency for the next six months is an ideal opportunity to do positive things steps from which everyone will benefit.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Prime Minister to our plenary. A presidency is always, of course, a very good time for a country to shine in the European Union, but it is also always a great time to shine a light on the country specifically and to have a look at what is happening there. I think we can see a lot of things happening there right now: looking, for example, at the mobilisation of thousands of people on the streets, protesting for the preservation of a unique centuries—old forest – the Pirin National Park – which you are, of course, familiar with. They are protesting against corruption and a very dodgy decision to permit a skiing resort and also commercial logging in this precious natural heritage site, which is also protected by European Union law. Thereby, it is not just an environmental issue, which of course is important, but it is also an issue of how we respect European Union laws and rules. There, I think, as a presidency, you should really lead by good example, and that is one area where I think you can make a big difference. (Applause) Eleven years have passed since the accession, but we have also had 11 anti-corruption reports by the European Commission. Bulgaria is still listed as the country with the most corruption in the European Union. That is a great pity. Also, looking at the anti—corruption measures that have been taken in Bulgaria, many of them can be seen as ineffective and even counterproductive. For example, looking at the most recent anti—corruption law, which will say that whistle-blowers, i.e. people who from inside the administration highlight corruption cases, will face the danger of being persecuted. Citizens may still have to pay bribes for access to public services, and there is still a problem with high influence on public life and media from very obscure circles. The Commission cannot ignore all of those issues. I think the Presidency is a great chance for you to improve not only that image, but also the situation itself, to go deep and really take on the fight against corruption, which will also greatly benefit the citizens of Bulgaria. Let us know how we can also support you in this very important issue.  2018 is a very important year for the European Union, with the elections coming up. Many issues that have been highlighted – the eurozone, finally getting real on climate change, social issues, the rule of law – are very important issues. You have picked a very interesting motto: United we Stand Strong. I think this is very correct and true: we have to be united and we have to be strong in order to address those issues. We also have to be strong as a European Union of values which is fighting for democracy and against racism and xenophobia. I hope all of your ministers could sign that statement. If you are following through on this motto, then we are very much ready to support you all the way through.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I very much appreciated the choice of priorities of the Bulgarian Presidency. In recent years, Europe has been chronically ill with brain drain and youth unemployment. Despite the much-heralded recovery, the figures continue to be frightening: the average of the three rear-viewers - Greece, Spain and Italy - is around 36%. Young people, we young people, continue to feel the effects of the economic crisis and this undermines not only Europe's growth and ability to innovate and innovate, but the very foundations of our project. It is necessary to work together to find concrete and effective solutions and to implement an expansive, counter-cyclical and Keynesian policy that prioritizes work and innovation as soon as possible. Yesterday it was already late. The Bulgarian one was then also baptized as the "Balkan Presidency". I too am a firm supporter of the absolute need to relaunch the accession process of the Western Balkans, whose stability and prosperity are of fundamental importance to us all. Today, the lighthouse and example of the integration process is undoubtedly Montenegro, which is ever closer to reaching our large European family, and it will be our task to assist all the countries in the area, applying the principle of "more for more": reward those who are most committed to the process of necessary reforms without, however, abandoning others. Finally, I applaud the choice of continuity with the outgoing Estonian Presidency, centered on the digital revolution which, with lower costs and greater efficiency, is a pillar of the Europe we dream of, a less ancient and bureaucratic Europe, a digital, democratic Europe and cutting edge.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, during our discussions a few weeks ago in Sofia, within the framework of the Conference of Presidents, you indicated that the issue of external borders and their necessary control was undoubtedly the a great challenge for Europe today, and you reaffirmed this a few minutes ago. While many heads of state or government in Western Europe have shown appalling angelism and total laxity by literally organizing the migratory submersion of Europe, fortunately there are heads of government in Central and Europe. Eastern Europe who are determined to lead the fight for identity and security. This is the case with your Hungarian neighbors, Poland, the Czech Republic and now Austria. At the start of these six months of Bulgarian presidency, you therefore have an essential role and a responsibility. You can instigate a real political will, totally absent today from the European institutions, to deter immigration, destroy mafia networks and strengthen protections. Bulgaria has the most important land border with Turkey and at present your government, Mr Borissov, has shown a firmness which has paid off because you have obtained very good results, as you recalled. see you later. Bulgaria is one of the ancient nations of our continent, it has been a real country since 681, which has gone through history, hardships and wars; your people are strong, and Europe needs this strength and this steadfastness to fight against immigration, fundamentalism and preserve our values ​​of civilization. Finally, we have a big challenge to take up: that of economic competition. We must guard against unfair competition, whether it comes from outside the European Union or from within the European Union, and finally, Prime Minister, I welcome your desire, clearly expressed earlier, to normalize relations with Russia.It is indeed necessary - you are right - to put an end to the absurd aggressiveness of the European institutions towards this neighboring great power.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: - Thank you, Mr President. Dear Mr. Prime Minister, welcome! For the first time, the Prime Minister of Bulgaria is here in the House of European Democracy. Bulgaria is leading the Council at a difficult time for the European Union: migration crisis, Brexit, populism, uncertainty about our external borders. I am convinced that Bulgaria will be not only a good mediator, but also a good leader in finding solutions to current challenges. The accession of our country to the EU 11 years ago was the biggest event in the recent history of Bulgaria. We belong to European civilization, but the communist dictatorship had separated us for decades, both us and much of Eastern Europe from the European family. The path outlined by our national revivalists, who wanted Bulgaria to be equal to other European nations, has much in common with the vision of a united and free Europe. In the Balkans, history, especially in the 20th century, has opened deep ideological wounds among the peoples of our region. European integration is the best medicine to overcome these historical and ideological divisions and to heal open wounds. That is why I welcome your decision, Mr Prime Minister, that one of the main priorities of the Bulgarian Presidency should be the Western Balkans. We must close these wounds, and not compete over who is greater, but walk together in the common European home. History teaches us that Europe destabilizes very easily through the Balkans. Just one spark, as you said, just one murder, is possible to take things back decades. I wish success to the Bulgarian presidency and the Bulgarian administration. Thank you and you have our support.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - Dear Prime Minister, you have an exceptional understanding for the continuation of enlargement to the Western Balkans. We agree that this is a very fragile area. Yesterday's assassination of respected Serbian politician Oliver Ivanovic shook the region. I offer my condolences to his relatives and call on the authorities to shed light on the circumstances of the assassination as soon as possible. This brutal act confirmed how far we are actually from the rule of law in this region. Today, young people are leaving the Balkans en masse and the region needs an opportunity, but let us acknowledge that the rule of law is also on foot in the Union and it will be difficult to convince the Balkans to defend the rule of law if we fail to do so in the Union. If it is a matter of respecting the arbitration agreement between Slovenia and Croatia, which could seriously jeopardize further enlargements to the Balkans, or Hungary, Poland. In the case of Poland, I urge you to be resolute in applying Article 7 of the Treaty for violating the rule of law. Only in this way, by respecting fundamental values, as you said, will we stand together ourselves.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: - First of all, good luck to my homeland Bulgaria! Mr. Prime Minister, it is great that you are talking about the prospect, because the majority of Bulgarian citizens do not see it. They are losers from the European Union at the expense of a handful of people. We are talking about poverty, the dangerous symbiosis with corruption. In Bulgaria, this symbiosis is deadly to society. As Mr Juncker's European bureaucrats, let us not bury our heads in the sand like ostriches. Act with perspective, but we also expect retribution from you, Mr. Prime Minister. It is dangerous that a handful of oligarchs, notoriously known at home and abroad, enriched by European funds and privatization, have become moral mentors of our society on behalf of the European Union. They are done with freedom. Now or never, Mr. Borisov! I have always been honest with you. We still do not have a politician or an oligarch imprisoned for corruption. Bandits such as Ivo Prokopiev, Ognyan Donev, along with some of your former ministers, are awaiting sentencing from the court for hundreds of millions of public thefts. When will we see them in prison? Act because such individuals cannot be a symbol of European values. You also promised a perspective, I wish it to you! Don't just leave a beautiful tale.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: - Mr President, Mr Juncker, Commissioners, colleagues. Dear Mr. Borissov, I, in turn, join in the wishes for success. Undoubtedly, the Bulgarian presidency of the Council of the European Union comes at a time when Europe is at a crossroads. Important topics are on the Union's agenda. In addition, the priorities set by Bulgaria put on the table other important topics, such as the continuation of cohesion policy as a key tool against division and disintegration in the Union and the European perspective of the Western Balkans. I appreciate the fact that the topic of the Western Balkans has moved to a higher level on the European agenda, but that alone will not solve the region's problems. The six countries need systematic, political and financial support. To make real progress, they need a clear, clear roadmap. It can be prepared during the Bulgarian presidency, setting the deadline proposed by the European Commission until 2025. Europe should not worry about the Western Balkans, but should pursue a policy for the Western Balkans. Only with the integration of the region can we say that we have completed the project of Europe as a zone free of ethnonationalism. But let's not be fooled, Mr. Borissov. These causes can be doomed if you continue to rely on the extreme nationalists in Bulgaria and lead Europe with them. Fill in the credit of trust given to you by Mr. Juncker. Be a democrat, get rid of them, free yourself from the shackles of extreme nationalism! Do it for Bulgaria, but also for Europe! I count on you.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Mr Prime Minister, we note with disappointment that the program of the Bulgarian Presidency is a continuation of the dead-end neoliberal austerity policies of the Union, which have already led its people into impoverishment and young people into unemployment and immigration. In the policies of the digital agenda, it continues the philosophy of competition, with every social and labor cost, while in the issues of security and asylum, it faithfully follows the course of further militarization of the Union. Nevertheless, we welcome the Bulgarian Presidency's commitment to social cohesion and acknowledge the difficult work it has undertaken to negotiate the Multiannual Financial Framework. As a group of the United Left, we insist on our positions for long-term public investment in industrial sectors, which will create new secure and permanent jobs with full employment rights. We are against further militarization, we are in favor of humanitarian, solidarity-based, management of refugee and migration flows, by creating a fair and binding system of refugee redistribution.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: - Yes, there were good things in the Estonian Presidency, such as the directive on the energy performance of buildings, the rules on waste management.I believe it will be just as good during the Bulgarian Presidency.I like her chosen motto "Together we will become strong!".And striving to make the Union as open as possible to its citizens is a good thing.However, this is not the first time that rhetorical questions have to be asked.Why don’t those beautiful words usually turn into deeds?Why are the ambitious goals of one country's presidency quietly extinguished in the bureaucratic machine of the European Union?Why, when we talk as much as possible about the digital economy, are we less and less able to secure at least a minimum income for the most vulnerable social groups through the means of the conventional economy?The impression is that the priorities remain with the Presidencies and the real policy goes to others.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to take the opportunity to wish the Bulgarian people and state all the best in the New Year and good luck for the Presidency. We know that the European Union has been stuck in a reform process for over a year and that nothing is moving. It started with the referendum in Great Britain, where afterwards paralysis set in, and we have had five scenarios on the table for over a year, from less cooperation to complete centralization, when finally the states, the parliaments, the peoples, the institutions should talk about where we should go in the future. I miss that determination and I can only hope that what happened yesterday does not happen, namely that Great Britain has received an offer to stay here when it does not want to. That what happened again in Ireland with the vote on Lisbon, where a result did not go well and the result and the vote are repeated until it pleases - that is not the right way to go! I hope Bulgaria is a reform partner. I wish you all the best and thank you for your commitment.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: - Mister President! Dear Prime Minister, Your Council Presidency is a year before the European elections, and in these Bulgarian six months we can together prove that the EU is capable of acting, and together we can win people's trust. Firstly, if we manage to set the course so that medium-term financial planning - especially because of the Brexit - can be adopted by the European elections, if, secondly, we manage to promote stability and future prospects in the Western Balkans and to give a much more prominent presence as the European Union Thirdly, if we manage to solve the challenge of migration movements through even more reliable external border protection, through solidarity within Europe in burden sharing and effective help in combating the causes of displacement, if, fourthly, we manage to further stabilize the monetary union and increase our competitiveness and to create prospects for Europe's youth, then you and your country can be proud of a successful Council Presidency, and then we can look to Europe's future with more confidence. Good luck and good luck!

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: - For my generation, joining the European democratic family was a dream. The dream became a reality, but somehow we realized imperceptibly that neither democracy nor membership in the European Union is insurance against abuse of power, against corruption. In 2005, Bulgaria was ranked 30th in the Reporters Without Borders ranking for media freedom, and today it is ranked 109th. Bulgaria at the beginning of the transition was 9 million, and now it is 7 million. I hope that under the presidency of Bulgaria, we will have our contribution not to talk about depopulated areas, let alone depopulated countries. I hope that in six months my colleagues in the European Parliament will be able to say that Bulgaria was a worthy and working President of the European Union. Good luck!

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Distinguished Presidents, Commissioners, Colleagues, Distinguished Mr. Borissov, I congratulate you on the achievement of being the first Bulgarian Prime Minister in this Chamber! We have a lot of work to do in six months: changing the Dublin regulations and protecting our interest there; on the change in the protection of the external borders and Schengen - this affects not only us but also Romania and Croatia; on the accession of fraternal Macedonia and the Western Balkans; to reach a fair deal with our friends in the United Kingdom and our like-minded people in Poland, to fight double standards in food, in income, in the rights of carriers, and so on. This struggle, dear Prime Minister, must be waged smartly, consistently, persistently and with confidence. The self-confidence of people who built their country 1300 years ago in the Balkans and, as they guarded it in 717 from the invasion of Constantinople, still guard it today. I wish you success, I wish you hard work, which will make us in six months to be able to look each other in the eyes and brag about the successes achieved, because that is the will of the Bulgarian citizens. Congratulations and good luck!

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Mr President, Mr Prime Minister! There are three words above your Parliament: Unity makes you strong. I hope that you will send these three words to your 27 colleagues every morning by text message to greet the day. But I am particularly pleased that you were not only referring to the EU countries, but also to those in the Western Balkans. Here you will find many friends for it across party and parliamentary groups. Use our support, we are guaranteed to support you, here in Parliament and important for us all - also at home and on site. It is about concrete steps for Serbia and Montenegro, starting negotiations with Albania and also appreciating the good work done by your Macedonian neighbors. The path is not easy, so we have to tell people that we really want them. Roaming and other measures would be good contributors to this. Prime Minister, you told us that you would also like to normalize relations with Russia. You have my support for this, it is high time you did.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission.- Mister President!I am really almost overjoyed that I keep getting the floor, even though I don't really know what to add to what I said to you before the debate.I would therefore like to once again express my hope that the Bulgarian Presidency will be a complete success.It will be, and I would also like to thank all of my colleagues here in this House - who are a little more numerous this morning than yesterday - for having such an almost interactive debate.Good luck for!

name: Бойко Борисов
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Thank you, Mr President, thank you, Mr Juncker, for the good assessments and, of course, thank you to the heads of all the parliamentary groups and to the other Members who have spoken. I especially want to respond to the Greens, because I am a green person myself. The protection of Bulgarian nature is, I think, largely protected by our government. I have great respect for our environmental organizations and I met with them only ten days ago. I have stopped infrastructure projects for years so that the new storks can hatch because of a stork's nest. I have made the ministers personally carry marsh snowdrops so that not a single stalk is crushed by a roller. All our European infrastructure projects have tunnels for bears, wolves and turtles. We have changed the routes and I think they have no claims on me. What they have told you - I want to guarantee in front of you, and you will pass it on to them - is about a second lift, a single lift at the resort in the top ten in Europe - Bansko. Now there is only one lift and tourists wait in line for hours. I can sign you and guarantee you here that this is only a second lift. Why is it needed? Not just because of the tourists. Now these thousands of tourists board the road with their cars to the top of the mountain and descend from there. To keep the road running this time, we salt it all the time, as they do in Strasbourg, I guess. Dozens of trees around him are dying. I guarantee you that not only will illegal logging not be allowed, but - only here I am opening a bracket - in recent years Bulgaria is the first in Europe for new forests and the only one, perhaps, that has expanded its forests from all European countries. What kind of illegal logging are we talking about here? We are fighting such a battle with this, and what greater guarantee that when there is a second lift and this tourism, which investor will let the pines be cut down? So you have my guarantee that in addition to a second lift, a tile will not put there anymore. To answer those colleagues who raised the issue of corruption. Corruption is everywhere, we are fighting a huge battle. I will connect her with the Greens again. I have been elected 10 or 11 times, together with my party as winners in elections in Bulgaria. We started from the opposition, and we started from scratch. There was an unprecedented garbage crisis in Sofia when I became mayor. There was no factory, no processing, nothing. It was dumped in the ravines in Suhodol. We started and now Sofia is the best organized, I think that after Zurich, thanks to your European solidarity, with complete composting, processing, with a plant for household waste, with landfills - everything, as written in European books. At the same time, if there is such corruption as you say, will there be such economic growth, more investment and this growth? How will people always choose us in the first place? And as a policeman I was elected mayor of Sofia because of what I did in this area. And I guarantee you that, as we have done now, as with the garbage of Sofia, in 2-3 years we will cope. And we will do well. And with the new legislation, and with the will, and with your help and efforts. Please, these friends of ours who are protesting, they were also my coalition partners. They split the election into three parties, to have three leaders, and could not enter parliament just six months ago. They are our most natural partner. It is not my fault that they split into three parties to have three leaders. It is not my fault that I won the election under the government of the Socialist-elected president. They held the election and we won. Sorry, I'm not guilty. At the same time, I want to be responsible for the Istanbul Convention, which only last Wednesday the Bulgarian government adopted in my person. But it was the Bulgarian Socialists at a plenum on Sunday who decided not to support her in parliament. I will make every effort to pass in the parliament and support it, because there is violence against women and children monstrous not only in Bulgaria but in the whole of Europe. So you can count on it and I think the Greens would support me here too ... I hope. I would like to answer all of them. I deliberately wanted to concentrate on where the main criticism is. I want to tell my colleague from the MRF that we work with the United Patriots in this way, we have clearly understood that ethnic tolerance, the ethnic model and exactly what Bulgaria has achieved for decades, thanks to you, we will keep as the pupil of because Bulgaria is an example for the whole Balkans, with its ethnic tolerance. And with Michel Barnier on Brexit, I'm also committed to working. Thanks for everything. I am ready to sign for you that this is only a second lift, nothing else.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - The Bulgarian presidency comes at an important time for the European Union, when the need to deliver results on the three main concerns of citizens: immigration, security and job creation for young people is most urgent. In mid-December, the Sofia government presented its program for the Presidency of the Council of the European Union. Of the four priorities identified, none of them deal with human rights, nor are there any references to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. "Immigration management" is often mentioned, with the aim of increasing the effectiveness of "return policies" and "border control management", but no mention is made of the reform of the Dublin Regulation, nor of the redistribution of migrants. I am genuinely concerned that Parliament's work on this issue may come to a sudden halt. On security and employment, the intentions of the new Presidency seem convincing to me - economic growth and social cohesion must be at the center of the political agenda, as well as the fight against terrorism - but I think it is worth remembering, to all of us and to the new Presidency, that the stability of the European Union is at stake on the problem of immigration.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - I am pleased and pleased to note that one of the priorities of the Bulgarian Presidency's program is the European perspective of the Western Balkans region. 2018 could be a year of revival for a tired enlargement policy. Due to the geostrategic importance of the region, several global centers of power are seeking to gain influence in the Western Balkans. The EU must not allow this. Consistent policy messages and tangible results are needed. The existence of these is not only the responsibility of the candidate countries, but also of the European Union. Hungary is a committed supporter of EU enlargement in the Western Balkans. I am confident that the Bulgarian Presidency and Bulgaria, as one of the countries in the region, will bring new energy to enlargement policy. In this you can count on the support of the Hungarian and Hungarian People's Party delegations of the European Parliament. At the same time, I call on the Presidency to speed up the dynamics of the opening of chapters with regard to Serbia, as the current pace of accession, the 2025 accession deadline set by President Juncker, is difficult.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - The biggest challenge for the Bulgarian Presidency is to address the issue of migration. It must not lead to further divisions between Member States, and migrants must not be distributed in Europe under compulsory resettlement quotas. With regard to illegal migration, the will of more and more European citizens must finally be taken into account: we must be able to protect our external borders. This is our primary responsibility. The millions spent on external border protection on the part of Hungary must also be included in the concept of solidarity. Real refugees need to be separated from tens of thousands of migrants outside the Union and helped in a world where there is trouble, not brought into Europe. According to surveys published by Eurobarometer, 82% of those polled say the European Union needs to take stronger action against terrorism. The forthcoming European Passenger Information and Authorization System (ETIAS) will address these concerns and make a major contribution to the fight against terrorism and illegal migration, thus increasing the security of European citizens. I am pleased that an interim agreement was reached with the Estonian Presidency in December, and I hope that the dossier will be closed definitively during the Bulgarian Presidency.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - I am pleased to hear that the further development of energy infrastructure, including the construction of the necessary gas infrastructure, is a high priority in the program of the Bulgarian Presidency. Those who deal with this issue are well aware that energy security has been a topic for us for many years and also that not all the projects that could guarantee adequate security of gas supply have been completed. An example of this is Central and Eastern Europe, where dependence is still highest, but the construction of gas interconnectors and LNG terminals is still lacking. Unfortunately, a direction has recently emerged in my committee, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, which calls into question the need for fossil infrastructure projects on the list of projects of common interest (PCI list). It is not enough to emphasize that, although renewable energy may be the future, it is not the answer to today's and tomorrow's questions. Gas diversification is needed; a country cannot switch its heating mode overnight. In light of this, I welcome the emphasis on gas infrastructure development in the Presidency's program.

name: Kati PIRI
text: written.- Following the debate in the European Parliament with the Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov, the PvdA Eurodelegation calls on Bulgaria to push for a political agreement as EU president on the various migration files.In particular, on the proposal for the regulated resettlement of vulnerable refugees, for which Kati Piri is shadow rapporteur on behalf of the Social Democrats, an agreement is desperately needed so that the EU can finally provide safe and legal asylum to refugees who need it most.In addition, it is important that Bulgaria does more to tackle corruption in the country, as many other European citizens are also affected.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: written. - The motto of the Bulgarian Council Presidency “united we stand strong” is a nice way to tackle the important challenges of the coming months, because only united and together can we make Europe strong. It will also have to be a matter of defending the rule of law in Europe, which is increasingly threatened in individual Member States. Austria will next take over the presidency in six months. And there are big tasks ahead of us: From the conclusion of the Brexit negotiations, the EU-wide tax harmonization to the urgent forging of alliances for a social Europe. We will not get any further here with the idea of ​​a minimal Europe of black and blue in Austria. That is a slap in the faces of Europeans. If we do not reduce the growing gaps in prosperity, labor rights or advancement opportunities, Europe threatens to break apart. The “Austria First” club is the wrong approach to Austria’s important tasks in order to enable Europe to act.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – The first months of 2018 may crucially affect next year’s elections to the European Parliament. The tone could be set by the outcome of the Italian and Hungarian elections in coming weeks. Moreover, while entering the second year of negotiations, Brexit talks still remain a huge source of uncertainty. In this transitional context, which usually induces a legislative slowdown, the Bulgarian Presidency has presented a strong programme. By prioritising the deepening of regional relations, starting with the Balkans, this Presidency could further raise awareness of the state of peripheral countries, whose full inclusion in policymaking is key to ensuring economic and social cohesion in Europe. I also especially welcome the emphasis on the digital agenda. This issue is crucial, especially regarding SMEs. We should ensure that the development of the digital single market includes the needs of real users, who must adapt as they realise the possibilities afforded by technology. Lastly, tax—related concerns should remain important in this first half of 2018. Parliament has recently questioned the unanimity principle. Strong emphasis should remain on tax transparency and on the necessary tax flexibility for countries at the margin of Europe. Bulgaria is well placed to highlight this crucial issue.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. - EU President J. P. Junker said at the inauguration of the Bulgarian Presidency: "I remember that Bulgaria underwent relatively rapid and intense changes before joining the EU, but it has established itself successfully, so we still have high expectations of it." it is a historic premiere, but with enthusiasm it has set itself the main priority themes it seeks to address as part of the EU's leadership, namely: European security, young people, stability in the single EU, the perspective of the Western Balkans and the digital economy. The importance of these areas is also the common denominator of the statements of the Bulgarian, EU Council, Commission and Parliament, where reforms of the Middle East asylum system and security policy (which failed 4 previous presidencies), the successful functioning of the digital single market (along with the next 2 EU presidencies) or a deeper connection of the Balkans with the EU in the fields of energy, telecommunications and education will contribute to more intensive and effective multi-level cooperation. The Bulgarian Presidency will set in motion a number of important things and this will contribute to the better functioning of both the EU and the Member States themselves.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The Bulgarian Presidency will have important implications for the south-eastern region of Europe and will bring to the fore important issues, such as the future of cohesion and security policies. There are also expectations that the Bulgarian government will put pressure on the expansion of the Schengen area for Bulgaria and Romania, but also on the lifting of the Verification and Cooperation Mechanism on the two countries. However, the Bulgarian presidency also comes with a new lease of life in terms of European integration and rejects the possibility of a two-speed Europe. As countries on the border of the European Union, Bulgaria and Romania can bring a different perspective on the future of the European project, relying on the idea of ​​solidarity. My conviction is that we need more cooperation between Member States, but also a strengthening of relations with the Union's neighbors. As a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I will also monitor the position of the Bulgarian Presidency with regard to connectivity objectives. Having common interests in infrastructure development, I want Bulgaria and Romania to prioritize the implementation of a strategy dedicated to Southeast Europe, which identifies connectivity issues and correlates transport and tourism policies.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - The current year will be a year of great challenges for the European Union. The preparation of the post-2020 financial perspective and the completion of the economic and financial reforms that the European Union needs are the context under which the Bulgarian presidency is taking place. The defined priorities, namely the mobilization of young people, the stabilization of the Balkans, the commitment to digital skills and the promotion of the internal market, security and stability within a framework of cohesion and convergence, are adequate for the different European institutions and for Member States can continue the work they have to do to make the European Union more robust, more competitive and better able to respond to the global challenges it faces. The rotating presidencies of the Council of the European Union are a double opportunity. They allow the presidencies to apply a global vision on the future of the Union and at the same time contribute to the stabilization of the Union's relations with the territories and peoples closest to it. In relations with the Balkans, Russia and Turkey, among others, Bulgaria will be able to make a fundamental contribution, and it is important that this priority constitutes one of the pillars of its Presidency.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the discussion on the future of Europe with Leo Varadkar, Taoiseach (Prime Minister) of Ireland (2017/3023 (RSP)). As you know, this is the first discussion on the future of Europe that the European Parliament has decided to organize, inviting the Prime Ministers and the greatest protagonists of Europe for a concrete discussion, not with formal speeches but with the possibility of interacting to get to know the thoughts and proposals of European leaders. I want to thank the Taoiseach, the Prime Minister of Ireland, for having responded with great concern to our invitation. He will be the first to intervene with this new formula. It will be of great interest to us to hear it, also because Ireland is a leading country in the new phase we are facing, so its presence in the seat of the European Parliament and in the hemicycle is of great importance. I thank him for being the first to respond with great availability and concern to the possibility of confronting the European Parliament. So it is with great pleasure that I give him the floor so that he can address you and start this constructive discussion on the future of Europe.

name: Leo Varadkar
text: Taoiseach. – Mr President, Vice-Presidents, President Juncker, Commissioner Hogan, distinguished leaders of the political groups, Members of the European Parliament, dear friends, I want to say that it is a great privilege to be the first speaker in your series of debates with Heads of Government on the future of the European Union.  I believe that the European Union is at a decisive point now in our history. Despite all of the upheavals in recent years, the rise of populism and euroscepticism, nationalism and anti-democratic forces, we meet today in solidarity and with a renewed sense of purpose. The European ideal has always been inspired by a spirit of optimism and a belief in a better future. While that ideal has been tested, it has not been broken. Based on the achievements of the past, we have a renewed appetite to face the challenges of the future.  Back in 1947, representatives from 16 countries met in Paris to discuss how, in the words of Jean Monnet, they could resist economic decline and preserve political freedom.  En 1947, des représentants de seize pays se sont réunis à Paris pour discuter de la manière dont, selon les termes de Jean Monnet, ils pourraient résister au déclin économique et préserver la liberté politique. L’Irlande était l’un de ces seize pays. La sagesse de la prédiction de Monnet selon laquelle «il n’y a pas d’avenir pour les peuples d’Europe autre que dans l’union» s’est vite fait jour. Dès le début, les petits pays ont contribué de manière non négligeable au développement de l’Europe. Dans les années cinquante, Joseph Bech, luxembourgeois et grand architecte de l’intégration, a joué un rôle capital dans la création de la Communauté européenne du charbon et de l’acier, et dans la tenue de la conférence de Messine en Sicile. Interrogé sur la présence de politiciens européens réunis en Sicile en 1955, un haut dirigeant politique britannique rétorqua que ces derniers avaient pris part aux fouilles archéologiques! Des fouilles qui ont servi de base au traité de Rome. Wir sehen die Stärke der europäischen Wertvorstellungen im Erbe der Persönlichkeiten wie Konrad Adenauer und Hans Dietrich-Genscher, deren Vision für Versöhnung und Integration in ganz Europa so wichtig war. Wir sehen sie in der Arbeit Helmut Kohls und seinem Glauben, die Bedürfnisse und Gleichberechtigung kleinerer Nationen zu beachten. Und wir sehen sie in der Vision Jacques Delors' und seinem Glauben an einen tieferen Sinn Europas – eine Seele für Europa –, ohne den das ganze Projekt scheitern würde. Seine Arbeit bei der Schaffung einer gemeinsamen Währung, des Euro, ist ein bedeutsames Erbe. Seine Aufgabe an uns, einen größeren Sinn anzustreben, ist noch bedeutsamer. Mr President, the promise of a better future has motivated people to work for the European ideal since the very beginning. And speaking in this chamber today I am reminded of one of the greatest figures in Irish politics, and one of the greatest figures in politics from Northern Ireland, John Hume, whose birthday it is tomorrow and who served as a Member of this great Parliament for 25 years. John Hume spoke many times about the symbolism of the bridge not too far from here, connecting Strasbourg to Kehl just across the border in Germany. He spoke about how easy and ordinary it was to walk across that bridge, and given Europe’s dark history how remarkable and profound that ordinariness was. In the European Union John Hume saw a model and a vision for how a lasting peace, however improbable, could be fostered and built. and he saw how that model of people working together with a shared purpose and endeavour, spilling their sweat instead of their blood, as he put it, could provide an inspiration for my own country. Today there is a peace bridge crossing the river Foyle, bringing together the divided communities in John’s native city of Derry in Northern Ireland, a bridge that the European Union helped to build. Dear friends, it is hard to imagine the Good Friday Agreement being made without our shared membership of the European Union and its single market, and in Ireland we are now having to contemplate our future without that foundation which underpinned it and made it possible. That’s why the government which I lead has been so determined to protect the Good Friday Agreement in all its parts and all that flows from it. And it is why we have insisted that there cannot be a return to a hard border on our island, no new barriers to the movement of people or to trade. And it is why we are so deeply grateful for the remarkable solidarity and support from other Member States.
