It is a good start to our work here in January that we have the opportunity to have an open and frank debate with the leader of my country, An Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, and that that process will continue. So let’s make it beneficial.

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Mr President, Taoiseach, thank you for your speech. I too, like your nephew and niece, was born European, and you very kindly mention the one world city that will be leaving the European Union. Of course, there are people up and down the United Kingdom who are fighting Brexit, who are campaigning in towns and cities across the country, so don’t count us out yet. As Mr Farage has said, this issue is not settled, and how dare Mr Farage say that the European Union had nothing to do with the peace process. I worked in the Northern Ireland Office under the last government. I sat in the meetings with the victims and the families of the victims of the Omagh bombing, and what I witnessed was their incredible dignity. They did not have anger; they did not have hatred, just a sense that no one should ever go through this again.  It was not the common travel area that got rid of the checks on the border: it was the creation of the single market; it was the creation of free movement; it was the values espoused in this place and put into action that removed those barriers. We should never forget that. And a warning: there are people who just want Brexit at any cost. They will try to undo what was agreed in phase one. Let’s not let them do it.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Mr President, I would like to say the following to the Taoiseach. More than a thousand years ago, Irish monks reached Slovenians and other peoples in central Europe. Today you are the first prime minister to speak about the future of Europe in the European Parliament. My congratulations on your – and Ireland’s – strong European spirit. You used three key words: heart, soul and citizens. We can make progress only if the European project is supported by European citizens in all Member States. Prime Minister, we can agree on many concrete projects, but first of all we need a strong and uniting European narrative. What could, in your opinion, inspire and motivate European citizens for more Europe? On Brexit, I don’t believe in this expensive and hazardous exercise. British citizens decided in the first referendum without knowing the consequences. They have a right to know the consequences and to have the chance to decide in a second referendum when they are acquainted with the consequences.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, I say to Mr Varadkar: thank you for your enlightened words for Europe. As the child of a migrant, what would you tell citizens and European leaders about the rejuvenation, regeneration that migrants actually bring to Europe? How would you impress on the EU Council the importance of full social integration for migrants and for refugees and their children? On taxation, you said that you want a single market that serves citizens and not just corporations and you said that corporation should pay their fair share of taxes and that countries should not be played off against each other. So, are you in favour of a common cooperate consolidated tax base in the EU so that the race to the bottom does not continue? Will you also push in the Council for a financial transaction tax so that capital is not escaping taxes while citizens and SMEs are overburdened, and so that we will have a level playing field in the single market, and ensure that our own resources for the EU and for our Member States will increase?

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – Mr President, I apologise to the House for the state of my voice. Maybe a good Irish whiskey would help. At the end of this debate, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for honouring the past but looking towards the future. This is exactly what Europe needs right now. Sometimes the current situation in Europe reminds me of that famous poem ‘The Second Coming’ by the great Irish poet Yeats, in which he describes a falcon moving further and further away from the falconer until it can no longer hear him, and then comes the famous line ‘Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold’. These centrifugal forces are, of course, also at play in the EU, culminating in Brexit which will impact your country, Mr Varadkar. I’m aware of that. And it will impact my country, the Netherlands, and we should limit that impact as far as we can. But this – I am glad to say – was not a debate about Brexit: it was a debate about the future. It was a debate about making the centre hold on those issues where we stand no chance of defending our values and interests alone. By only acting alone and by only flying a national flag, as you said, we will in the end all be small Member States. Thank you for your outstretched hand. We in the European Parliament will gladly take it. (Applause)

name: Leo Varadkar
text: Taoiseach. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members again for their interesting questions and contributions. I was asked how we can avoid boom and bust again, and I think there are two things here. First of all, it is ensuring that we do not have credit bubbles again in Europe, and the European Central Bank is best placed to do that. And it is also around fiscal policy: balancing the books for the first year in 10 years, Ireland will not have a budget deficit this year. It is about reducing our debt so that we can ensure we have the capacity to borrow again in future if we need to, and it is also about setting up a rainy-day fund – which we have set up – to put some of our budget surplus into, to prepare for a future downturn, which inevitably happens at some point. Ms Childers asked about the social contract and social Europe. I think the best thing we can do to put fire back into the engine of social Europe is to build on what was agreed in Gothenburg. We actually agreed a really good political statement in Gothenburg and I would like to see us turn that into reality by using the proclamation made there to guide European legislation in those areas in the years to come. I am delighted to see we are joined by Commissioner Thyssen for this particular part of the discussion.  To Ms Harkin, I have to say that I like the idea of a citizens’ initiative. I think it is a good idea. It would be a good example of direct democracy though we would also have to have safeguards because, while one million people is a lot, in the European Union of 500 million it is also a small minority. So we would have to make sure that any citizens’ initiative was not a loud minority, but was actually reflective of a majority view, and that is what representatives do best. To be frank, it is our intention to increase defence spending. We are not going to increase defence spending to anything like the level that you see in other European countries, but we intend to do it for two reasons: first of all, because a lot of the members of our defence forces – our air corps, our soldiers, people in our navy – are quite poorly paid. We are now restoring and increasing their pay and, of course, that involves an increase in defence spending. We also need to replace a lot of out-of-date equipment – our fishery protection vessels, some of our helicopters – so, yes, there will be an increase in defence spending, but it something that we would have been doing anyway even if we were not involved in Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO). On Catalonia – one of my favourite parts of the world, and Barcelona is one of my favourite cities – I think the only solution is dialogue, and I hope that the central Government in Madrid will engage in dialogue with the new Government in Catalonia. Mr Rangel asked me to reflect on a few things in relation to a single European constituency. He makes some good points, notably that the United States, which is a federation, does not have a single constituency for anything. They elect their president, for example, through an electoral college. But perhaps they should have a single constituency because, on two occasions out of four now, the candidate who got the second highest amount of votes won the presidency. That, of course, is a matter for them. I am not entirely sure that transnational lists would necessarily benefit big countries because I see what is here in front of me – the heads of groups – and I see that a number of the people who are heads of their groups are actually from small and medium—sized countries. So why might that not also happen on a list? But I think we have an opportunity now. The UK is leaving, there are seats that are free, so it is possible to have a transnational constituency without any individual Member State losing any positions, and it gives people two votes: one vote for their MEP, who represents them in their region, and a second vote for a European party, challenging people to think about those ideas. It is a big challenge and I imagine a lot of people would cast a blank vote the first time round. In time, however, people would get used to the idea.  To Mr Nicholson, I just want to thank you very much for your constructive comments. I concur totally with what you said about the new relationship and also the need to get the executive and assembly up and running. The Tánaiste and the Secretary of State have already met on this, and I will be in touch with the Prime Minister on it as well. We really want to drive that forward. Finally, Mr Peterle asked about how we can inspire Europeans. Perhaps one of the ways we can do that is something I touched on in my speech, which is really to take action in relation to Africa, to make a part of Europe’s mission to improve Africa, to stabilise it, and to make it prosperous in the way that much of Asia has become prosperous. That is a way in which I think we can turn a thought into a feeling and really give people in Europe a positive feeling about what Europe can do.  Thank you very much again for your contributions. It has been a real pleasure and a real honour to have the opportunity here to speak to the Parliament and to answer some of your questions. Thank you again. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Taoiseach, thank you very much for your participation, thank you for your cooperation with the European Parliament. We will work together for a better Europe. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. - The EU is one of the most successful projects in the history of mankind: it has provided the longest period of peace in Europe, brought people together, promoted human rights and opened up to the world, prosperity and convergence, knowledge sharing and the circulation of ideas, abolished borders and divisions. The complexities of this extraordinary supranational construction, however, make any substantial change into a lengthy and sometimes tortuous process, peopled with deadlocks. This delay contrasts with the acceleration of time that characterizes today's world, faced with profound technological, energy, economic and labor changes, among others, which generate anguish and insecurity among Europeans. At the same time, internal fractures that have emerged or discovered in recent years persist, albeit mitigated, and sovereign rhetoric has returned in force to the media space. Despite all these difficulties, the balance of the historical trajectory of this political project cannot fail to be frankly positive. The EU's great challenge is to stand firm in asserting the superiority of the values ​​of freedom, openness, solidarity and moderation, refusing to compromise on closure, selfishness and extremism.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Parliament is organizing a series of debates on the future of Europe with leading figures. This initiative is welcome, but the institutions need to concentrate their efforts on swiftly making structural decisions for the coming years. I generally follow Leo Varadkar's vision of the main challenges for the future. With regard to Brexit, I fully subscribe to the need to safeguard the Good Friday Agreements, integrating this commitment into any exit agreement or future EU-UK relations. I agree with the proposal to move from Permanent Structured Cooperation, now launched, to deeper integration in defense, to tackle common challenges such as cybersecurity or drug and arms trafficking. I share the understanding of the need to deepen the internal market, building a Digital Single Market that understands the dimension of financial services. In this regard, I welcome the Taoiseach's commitment to the defense of greater integration in the fiscal plan, to combat fraud and evasion. Although I do not expect an enlargement in the near future, I follow the understanding of the need to deepen relations with the neighborhood, namely with Balkan countries. I subscribe to the alert for the need to speed up the construction of the new Common Asylum System.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I support the position expressed by Mr Vardakar on the need for a more democratic Europe, but in order to achieve this, we must be closer to our citizens. I believe that the path taken for a more centralized Europe, or in other words, the federal idea of ​​a European Union, is wrong. The many options for reform give us room for reflection. My position is that, within the EU, the double standard must be abolished and, above all, the competences of the Member States must be restored. We see that the mood of people who want the institutions to be closer to them is growing all over Europe. We see what is happening in Catalonia, but in the end it is normal. People want strong nation states. That is why the path to EU reform is no more, but less EU, stronger nation states. Less bureaucracy, more work on behalf of the people.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – As an MEP and President of the European Movement International, my take on the ‘future of Europe’ debate is that we don’t need to rebuild the whole house anew. The EU has a great body of achievements and we need to defend those that are valuable to EU citizens – such as freedom of movement, solidarity of cohesion policy or the EMU. But we also need a Europe that is able to change and adapt. We have a historic chance to establish a new relationship with citizens, and the wind is indeed in our sails. The levels of support for the EU have returned to those of before the crisis: 57% of Europeans today support their country’s membership in the EU, and 64% believe EU membership has benefited their country. In fact, many Europeans today are asking for a more engaged EU in spheres like migration management, security and defence and even social policy. The agenda that we set today is an indication of what kind of Europe we aspire to – a Europe that protects, a Europe that offers solutions to its citizens in disadvantaged regions, a Europe that has clear and uniform rules for citizens of third countries, an EU that creates stability for its immediate neighbours.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleagues, it is my pleasure to inform you that the Delegation to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean will meet today Mr Adel Al Asoomi, Vice-President of the Arab Parliament, and Mr Ahmed Mechergui, Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and National Security. I would like to extend a warm welcome to Mr Al Asoomi and Mr Mechergui and take the opportunity to stress the importance that we attach to cooperation between the European Parliament and the Arab Parliament, so a warm welcome to you, gentlemen. (Applause) I see requests for the floor for points of order, but I underline that I will accept only points of order with reference to the rule in the Rules of Procedure, otherwise I will not give the floor so that we can proceed with the vote.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – Mr President, I think you will realise that this is an important issue on which I would like to say a couple of words. One of the most respected and moderate political leaders of Kosovo... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Vajgl, I am sorry but this is not a point of order. You have not cited the rule under which you want to speak. As I have said, due to the length of the vote that we will have today on key items and key packages, I will only accept points of order. I do apologise, but hopefully we will have the time tomorrow.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – I would like to inform you that Professor Merera Gudina has been released in Ethiopia. We in this Parliament called for his release. That is very good.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Once again, note taken but we will now proceed with the vote. None of these were points of order.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I give the floor to Mr Tarand just to make his point.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Mr President, this is not a point of order, and I understand colleagues hate their rapporteurs grandstanding in the midst of votes, but it’s important. We have two very good candidates to be nominated to the Court of Auditors in Luxembourg, and they both deserve at least mentioning before a vote, and Ms Eva Linström from Sweden, among many other good qualities, also improves the gender balance in Luxembourg....  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr Tarand, we are not there yet. We are still on the report by Mr Buchner. After the vote:

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to request that we do not conclude the first reading but send a draft legislative act back to the Committee on International Trade in accordance with Rule 59(4) for interinstitutional negotiations based on the amendments adopted. Can we please vote on that?

name: Indrek TARAND
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I apologise for my first intervention. Statistically obviously I get two speeches in plenary now! The important thing is that we have two very good candidates, as I said, from Sweden and from Ireland, but in particular, I would like to draw your attention to the Irish method, which was an open public competition for the nomination. I would like to make an oral amendment to this report. I shall read it: ‘Calls on Member States to pay attention to, and if possible take inspiration from, the open competition model used by Ireland when selecting their nominees;’.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, unfortunately it was not at all clear when we proceeded to the voting on Amendment 240 CP and the article. On our list, for example, it was not clear at all.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Ms Kumpula-Natri, I made it clear on the first one, and on the second I specified the Article and the paragraph, so in my opinion that was absolutely clear. (So then the original text falls and we will now proceed with Amendment 317.) – After the vote:

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: speaker.- Mr President, after this clear and unequivocal mandate in favor of clean energy, I propose, in accordance with Article 59 of the Rules of Procedure, that the matter be returned to the committee in order to start negotiations with the rest of the institutions.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: - Mister President!With this in mind, we voted over 40%.And as I understand it, it has to fall because we agreed on a 35% target beforehand.So they don't go together.We should not have voted on this amendment, on this recital.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Pieper, the problem is that in consistency with the vote and according to the voting list, if the vote has taken place like that then it has been voted. I am afraid that is the case, so we will now proceed with the vote on Amendment 102. – After the vote:

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: rapporteur.- Like the other rapporteurs, I would like to ask for a referral back to the committee for the interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Claude TURMES
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, good day, sunshine. Good day, Paris Agreement. The people of this planet thank you for this vote. Dear President, dear Pavel, on behalf of the co-rapporteur, Michèle Rivasi, and myself, I would like to request a referral of the matter back to the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy for interinstitutional negotiations in accordance with Rule 59, paragraph 4, subparagraph 4 of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – That concludes the vote.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, cui bono. In whose benefit is this ban on biofuels? It is presented to us, as these things always are, as being in the interests of the planet and ecologically friendly and all the rest of it. But the reality is that this is a vote driven by the interests of rape seed producers here in Europe, specifically the biofuels industry at home. It is a much less efficient product. Producing rapeseed is in terms of the ratio of tonnage to energy about five times more costly than using palm oil, and yet it is being presented to us as being all about saving virgin forests and orangutans, and so on, to the extent that if there is any interest in Malaysia and the other producing countries in this kind of ban, it comes from the large producers who are trying to squeeze their smaller competitors out of business. The reality is that we should have a market based on choice; we should trust consumers to use their own ethics and their own judgment; and we should not have cartels dictating European policy yet again.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Thank you Mr President. I am proud to back increased binding targets for renewable energy and energy efficiency. We are getting greener. For the first time since the Industrial Revolution, last year the UK had a day without using any coal power to generate electricity. British wind farms, such as Ranson Moor in Fenland – which has a flat landscape, great for wind – and which I had the pleasure of visiting on Friday, generated more electricity than coal plants on more than 75% of days last year. Indeed, already this year, the compact Cambridgeshire site has powered over a hundred homes. But past success is no guarantee for the future. I believe that Britain needs to retain membership of the internal energy market, and our government needs to set a long-term consistent vision for energy, drop its opposition to onshore, and embrace these ambitious targets. We must not be blown off course. Rather, let us embrace the winds of change.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today the European Parliament adopted the revision of the Renewable Energies Directive. This vote is crucial for the environment and the health of Europeans, but also for European industries and farmers. On the important issue of first generation biofuels, I welcome the adoption of a clear, coherent and above all, realistic position. This directive will lead us towards a gradual reduction of first generation biofuels, which takes into account the concerns expressed by the 100,000 rapeseed farmers in France and the 20,000 employees of the French biodiesel sector. In addition, this directive tends and leads towards a total ban on biofuels produced from palm oil resulting from deforestation by 2021. The second largest importer of palm oil in the world, the European Union must be firm and legislate on imports of palm oil from deforestation. I sincerely hope that we will quickly reach agreement with the European Council on this major directive.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I would like to explain why I ultimately voted in favor of the proposal for a directive on the promotion of renewable energy sources.I agree with increasing the share of renewables to 35%, in a binding target for the whole of the EU, but with flexibility for nation states.Renewables are an appropriate way to combat climate change and air pollution.Of course, they are also an opportunity for economic development and innovation.But sufficient flexibility must be left to the Member States.I also voted in favor of extending the scope of the directive to aviation, because, as we know, aviation is one of the major polluters.On the contrary, I did not support a very strict approach to biofuels.I am in favor of capping the first generation of biofuels to the state of 2017, which will limit them in the future, but will not negatively jeopardize the investments already made.The EP has therefore adopted a proposal that is realistic and allows for good negotiating positions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Promoting the use of energy from renewable sources could help address the challenges posed by global warming. At the same time, however, the installation of RES units, especially wind farms, must be done with respect for the environment. This does not apply to the installation of wind farms in South Karystia, an area protected by the Natura network: it is planned to install 42 wind farms with a capacity of 700MW, a number higher than the allowable limit for any area of ​​Greece. The construction of new roads to transport wind turbines to the peaks of Ochi will upset the ecological balance. The electromagnetic radiation emitted by the pylons adjacent to residential areas poses a huge risk to the health of residents. With our interventions in the House and with a question, we denounced the violation of the legislation of the European Union for the protection of the health of the inhabitants and the environment. Given that the Commission has informed that the process of referring Greece to the Court on this issue has begun, we await the practical results of this action. Oopsometha!

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, many Members of this House seem to have forgotten the devastation caused by the Renewable Energy Directive in 2009, when binding targets for biofuels led to a sharp spike in land grabs and deforestation to grow crops for biofuels. As profits in the biofuels sector increase, so does their influence over policy-making, and their destructive impact was evident today. By increasing the cap on biofuels in the transport sector, Parliament is incentivising the land for fuel policy that has led to global food insecurity. Biofuel crops grown on peatland and deforested land contribute almost as much in carbon emissions as fossil fuels.  I welcome the ban on palm oil for fuel, but crops like soybean, rapeseed and sunflower have carbon footprints that are almost as high as oil from tar sands.  The 35% ceiling on biofuels by 2030 can be celebrated, but it is the fine detail in this directive that will have those in the biofuel lobby rubbing their hands in glee as they prepare to cash in on the land of the world’s most vulnerable people, land that should be managed for the good of the climate and for biodiversity.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: -President!I voted in favor of the report on renewable energy, which is an integral part of the Clean Energy package.In the sections on biofuels, unfortunately in several cases, palm oil and first-generation biofuels have been blended.At these points, I have consistently voted to eliminate misunderstandings.I consider it an important point that the proposal included a demand that we prohibit the taxation and punishment of energy self-sufficiency.In this way, we could reverse the senseless practice initiated by the Hungarian government, when renewable energy production is punished with extra taxes.I would cite the taxation of solar panels as a concrete example.It must be understood by all governments that renewable energy production, smart solutions and diversification must be encouraged and not hindered.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Let me therefore comment on the outcome of the vote on the proposal for a directive on energy efficiency.I voted in favor of the proposal because I consider energy savings to be a suitable tool for improving the environment.But the process must not be more rapid than research and innovation.I also strongly support the flexibility to set and assess compliance with national energy efficiency targets.I could not support the increase of the fixed binding target to 40%, which fortunately did not pass, and I also did not vote in favor of increasing the target and extending the obligation to renovate to all public buildings.I consider this to be too great an impact on state budgets.Given that a number of good amendments have been passed, I was able to vote in favor of the draft directive in the end.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, we are talking about energy efficiency at a time when the predominant problem across Europe is energy poverty. Energy poverty affecting millions of unemployed and poor. In Greece the problem has peaked. More than 100,000 households are unable to pay their electricity bills. Last year, there were 35,000 power outages in poor households which, due to their inability, owed debts to PPC. At the same time, we have increased value-added tax on electricity supply while it is a utility service. Heating oil has skyrocketed since the troika imposed an increase in excise duty. As a result, Greece is thawing and our fellow citizens are really burning what they find, resulting in an increase in smog. The current situation in Greece with energy poverty is now unacceptable.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President!I welcome the 'Clean Energy for All' package, which also takes into account, in part, important issues such as energy poverty and climate policy.In the case of energy efficiency, it is not a question of placing great emphasis on smart or smart technologies and procedures.I therefore welcome the amendments to this effect, as this is the only way in which the Commission's investment of more than EUR 100 billion can be spent.I would like to draw attention to one thing: in regions where livelihoods are a problem, it is not primary for people to be concerned about energy efficiency, because buying cheaper products comes to the fore for understandable reasons.Of course, I understand that innovation has to be paid for, but I also urge solutions in this area.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today when you evaluate the choices in the energy sector that are made by the European Union, you have an image in chiaroscuro that is anything but exciting, just think of what is happening in Italy, in my region , with the TAP and what is in the pipeline with the design of the Poseidon: that is, we continue to insist on new devastating achievements linked to the fossil rather than pushing for renewables. In this case, however, despite the outcry by the majority of those who sit here in Parliament with respect to the total elimination of fossil subsidies, which we have instead clamored for, the proposal on the governance of the Energy Union seems to make a step forward thanks to greater participation and transparency in the planning and updating of national climate and energy plans, exploiting the potential of cities, regions, citizens and businesses. Furthermore, the inclusion of energy efficiency objectives, the role of decarbonisation and the greater diffusion of renewables are certainly going in the right direction. It is for this reason that we voted positively.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I would like to comment on the proposal, which is the last of the three.It is a proposal for a regulation on the governance of the Energy Union, and we voted on it last, because it actually closed the vote on the three pieces of legislation that concern the energy package.Unfortunately, in the end, I could not support this proposal for a regulation.In general, of course, I support a flexible approach for individual countries, which is why I expected this to be taken into account more when voting on amendments, for example, I did not support strict deadlines for national energy and climate strategies.I voted against the binding nature of national energy efficiency targets.I simply think that more flexibility needs to be left here.Unfortunately, this third draft of legislation, ie the regulation, does not fully correspond to the two previous ones, which allowed for greater flexibility, greater rationality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the government of the European Union must respect the Treaty itself. This means that it must respect the responsibilities of the Member States and that the process of governing the Energy Union must also respect the principle of donors of power, which means that the institutions of the European Union have as much power as the Treaty confers on them. But what we are seeing is that attempts are being made to remove the power of the Member States in this area. This is done indirectly by the Commission, which wants to require the prior approval of any international treaties signed by the Member States. In essence, this is a usurpation of sovereign powers by the Member States. We now have a second case with the institutionalization of macro-regions where, and through this institution, attempts are also being made to reduce and remove sovereign responsibilities of the Member States in this field. I am strongly opposed to this process.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President! I welcome the 'Clean Energy for All' package, especially its report on the European Union. I support joint efforts, as this is also an issue that we can only successfully resolve together. Member States often forget that the development of a free energy mix in the Member States still has a common concept, so energy security, solidarity, energy efficiency, energy saving, interconnection and increasing the share of new and renewable energy sources must be kept in mind. This report also states that costly, highly polluting investments should be avoided, and that fossil energy-free investments should be safe and predictable. I think it is important that nuclear energy is not accounted for by the Member States as renewable energy, because nuclear energy is not clean and unsafe energy. In view of all this, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item on the agenda is the thematic debate on Russia - the influence of propaganda on EU states (2018/2507 (RSP)).I would like to inform you all that the 'catch the eye' procedure does not apply in this debate and blue cards are not accepted.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, I will not try to describe all the impacts of Russian propaganda on European countries and societies: instead I will focus on what should be our response. First we have to recognise, and then to raise awareness and share expertise within the Union. I commend the work of the European External Action Service (EEAS) East StratCom Task Force, the EU Hybrid Fusion Cell and the Centres of Excellence for Strategic Communication and for Countering Hybrid Threats, but I regret that the EU capacities are under-funded and under-staffed. The Commission and the EEAS have not heard the alarm bells that have been ringing in this House and in the European capitals since the war against Ukraine. I invite Commission Vice-President and High Representative Mogherini and other EU leaders to balance their meetings with Lavrov and Putin with due attention to the Kremlin’s attempts to weaken and undermine our democracies and alliances. Secondly, we have to make our societies more resilient. There are many aspects to this but some require swift legislative action by the House. Through the revised Audiovisual Services Directive we have to mandate national media regulators to adopt a zero tolerance policy against hate speech, irrespective of the media platform, and there is a need for significantly increased transparency of media ownership so that citizens know who’s who in the media they use. Freedom of speech should be defended against those who use it against our fundamental values. Transparency and stricter regulation are the key words for political-party and campaign funding in the Member States. The EPP Group has called for a major review looking into indirect Kremlin funding of European political protagonists, and particularly into shady support for anti-European and anti-democratic forces in our societies. This is closely linked to the need for enhanced investigation and prevention of money laundering by Kremlin-linked entities through European banks and companies. Thirdly, we have to consider how we credibly deter the Kremlin from cyber meddling and disinformation operations. When told in no uncertain terms that it will face unpleasant consequences and bear significant costs, the Kremlin tends to listen. But any deterrent is credible only if it is based on capacities and the political will to deploy the instruments available, and once again we need adequate resources at European level. The EU Cyber Security Agency is in its infancy and, if we want to be serious about it, its budget should be increased not twofold but tenfold. One key to our capacity building in the cyber domain is trans-Atlantic cooperation and NATO, and, given the political dynamics in Washington, European states have to take the lead in any collective action vis-à-vis the Kremlin, as well as in setting international rules for cyber space. Europe drives the global agreement on climate change and it should be among the rule makers for cyber space. Fourthly, there is no substitute for independent and fact-based journalism. The world’s richest and most powerful publisher, Facebook, has replaced editors with algorithms, shifting entire societies away from critical thinking while making billions from our clicks. I am convinced that quality journalism should be supported by governments, and by the EU, because otherwise it would disappear and leave us all at the mercy of Kremlin and other trolls who have learned how to play the social media game. (Applause)

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: Présidente en exercice du Conseil. – Monsieur le Président, honorables membres du Parlement européen, Monsieur le Commissaire, avant de présenter mon discours sur le sujet du débat, comme je prends la parole pour la première fois devant vous, au nom du Conseil, je voudrais tout d’abord vous dire que je suis ravie d’être à votre disposition au cours de la présidence bulgare. En tant qu’ancienne députée européenne, je sais très bien à quel point il est important de travailler ensemble, en étroite coopération, pour pouvoir répondre aux attentes de nos citoyens et garantir la légitimité démocratique de l’agenda européen et des politiques de l’Union européenne. Comme nous le rappelle la devise de notre présidence en bulgare, l’union fait la force. Now I will switch to the language of Shakespeare in order to thank you for inviting the Presidency to intervene on behalf of the Council in this topical debate and on this very topical issue. In this Chamber you have indeed discussed the issue of propaganda and fake news several times in recent months.  As regards Russia, in March 2015, the European Council stressed the need to challenge that country’s ongoing disinformation campaigns. It invited the High Representative, in cooperation with Member States and the European Union institutions, to prepare an action plan on strategic communication. It noted at the same time that the establishment of the communication team was the first step in this regard. As a result, the East StratCom Task Force was launched in September 2015. It has been engaged in developing communication products and campaigns, focused on explaining EU policies in the Eastern Partnership region. This includes proactive communication campaigns, as well as analysing disinformation trends, explaining disinformation narratives and myth—busting. In November last year, EU Foreign Ministers took stock of the current work on EU strategic communications, in particular as regards outreach to the Eastern Partnership region, the southern neighbourhood and the Western Balkans. They agreed to enhance work further and expressed their support for the development of all three task forces. In December 2017, they decided to reinforce cooperation with NATO partners on countering hybrid threats. Member States have also underlined the importance of expressing positive EU messages in the EU neighbourhood, as well as the need to counter disinformation where and when needed. I am sure that today you will discuss the work and the findings of the East StratCom Task Force, as well as the influence of the reported activities in EU countries. In their joint communication on resilience in the EU’s external action last June, the High Representative and the Commission noted that the European Union, as well as some of its partner countries, was targeted by external disinformation activities that discredit the political and social systems that are central to our identity, security and stability. They underlined the importance of further developing measures to increase citizens’ resilience to disinformation, notably by raising awareness and by supporting greater media plurality and professionalism. Indeed, the challenges posed by the proliferation – including online and on social media – of new sources of disinformation need to be addressed on many different levels. We must, for instance, not forget the important role of education and the need to develop democratic resilience, media literacy, tolerance and critical thinking. These efforts have become key to fighting off propaganda and manipulation through fake news, which threaten the very foundation of our societies as citizens elect their representatives on the basis of political views shaped by an open and fair debate. These issues were discussed notably during the third annual rule of law dialogue in the General Affairs Council in October last year, when Ministers discuss the topic of media pluralism and rule of law in the digital age.  Finally, I would also like to refer to the High—Level Expert Group on fake news launched by the Commission. Its first meeting was held at the beginning of this week. It will help define the roles and responsibilities of the different stakeholders and formulate recommendations. Its work will be of interest to all of us. I look forward to your debate which I will follow attentively.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for organising this topical debate on a subject which is, as we have already heard, of the highest importance, not only to the EU but also to all our citizens. On behalf of the Commission, I welcome the analysis set out in Parliament’s resolution on EU strategic communication to counteract propaganda against the Union by third parties. There seems, frankly, little doubt that the pro-Kremlin disinformation campaign is an orchestrated strategy, delivering the same disinformation stories in as many languages as possible, through as many channels as possible, as often as possible. This conclusion is based on two years’ work by the EU’s East StratCom Task Force, which has gathered more than 3 500 examples of pro-Kremlin disinformation, contradicting publicly available facts, repeated in many languages on many occasions. Russian authorities are not exactly shy about the goals of this disinformation campaign and disinformation activity. In Russia’s official military doctrine, as well as statements by top Russian generals, they describe the use of false data and destabilising propaganda as legitimate tools, and information as another type of armed force. While EU Member States are obviously in the front line for such Russian disinformation, the Commission’s main role is to try and head off any fragmentation that might arise from differing Member State responses to such activities. That is why we place great emphasis on the role of the East StratCom Task Force under High Representative / Vice-President Mogherini, responsible for countering disinformation in the EU’s eastern neighbourhood. Its objectives, as we have already heard, are to ensure more effective communication and promotion of EU policies towards these neighbourhoods and EU Member States, to contribute to a strengthened media environment in these neighbourhoods and Member States, and to improve EU capacity to forecast, address and respond to disinformation activities by external actors. In terms of positive communication, the Task Force supports and advises EU delegations in the Eastern Partnership, Russia and Central Asia on how to improve their communications. It provides media products to support that activity: for example, the team was responsible for the communications campaign in the run-up to, and during, last November’s Eastern Partnership Summit. The Task Force works closely with the Commission and EU delegations in the eastern neighbourhood in support of independent media. The Task Force is a permanent member of all the relevant donor committees supporting independent media. It has also launched a Russian-language service from Brussels, providing updates and fact-based background information about the Union for Russian-language journalists. The aim is to increase visibility and more accurate representation of EU policies in the Russian media.  Lastly, the Task Force produces a weekly disinformation review. Its Twitter account ensures that the Task Force’s products reach up to two million people per month, in addition, obviously, to regular background briefings, including to international media, think-tanks and academics. This work is very important. That is why I welcome the proposal that Parliament has advanced to strengthen both our East and South StratCom Task Forces. We have heard about the importance of cyber security. I have had the occasion to address this House on cyber security previously, and I am afraid time does not allow me today to go into details but, from the Commission side, as set out in the proposals last September, we strongly support measures to build our cyber resilience and our cyber deterrence. Rightly, there has been a focus on the wider phenomenon of fake news. It is one of the Commission’s priorities for the coming year. As we have heard, in November last year we established a high-level expert group, which has now started its work to advise the Commission on scoping the phenomenon, grasping its international dimension, defining the roles and responsibilities of relevant stakeholders and presenting recommendations. The group will contribute to the preparation of a strategy addressing the challenge of fake news, which we will issue in spring this year. The Commission has also launched a public consultation on fake news, which is open until 23 February. There are two questionnaires available – one for our citizens and one targeted at legal entities and journalists to draw on their professional experience. We will see what those consultations highlight, but we believe that strong media literacy and promoting quality media are important elements of meeting the challenge of fake news, because media freedom and pluralism are pillars of our of our democracy. They are fundamental rights and they are crucial guarantees for open and free democratic debate. It is primarily for Member States to guarantee media freedom and pluralism. That said, the Commission is aware of existing challenges and is taking a number of measures, within our competence, to strengthen media freedom and pluralism across the Union, including, further to an initiative of this Parliament, funding the European Centre for Press and Media Freedom in Leipzig to address violations of media freedom. We have to remain vigilant. The purpose of a disinformation campaign is to get people to believe that the disinformation is fact, is credible. If we look at opinion polls measuring how many people accept obvious disinformation planted in pro-Kremlin media, then unfortunately we have to conclude that Russian disinformation can be extremely successful. That is why we need to redouble our efforts to debunk this propaganda and why we welcome the debate today.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: You are right, because if we do not pay proper attention it means that fake news becomes truth and then truth becomes fake news. With your permission, I would draw your attention to an article which has been published in the latest issue of the Atlantic which deals with the subject.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. President, the national-populists of the world see our representative democracy and our European way of life as their worst ideological rival, and they think that disinformation is useful, that disinformation is their continuation of the war against us on the internet. That is why the enemies of Europe practice disinformation, to unbalance us and demolish those democratic principles that the European Union represents. If the European Union were not a beacon of democracy, the European Union would never be attacked with fake news. It is because we are democrats that they attack us, not because we are European. In the case of Russia, I must say that we are not talking about an enemy, although Russia sometimes treats us as if we were. The Kremlin has 1 billion euros a year in public media, a television network in one hundred countries and thirty-three languages ​​and an army of ghost accounts ready to spread fake news. And they use them in the field of the European Union. The European Union, to defend itself, has, however, only a million euros budget and the Task Force, which is seventeen people. Seventeen people compared to € 1 billion a year in public media. We are really quite helpless. Every time the European Union has a problem, fake news appears, cyber attacks appear, emails are stolen and the Russian media takes action. We must start to react more seriously. In recent events in Catalonia, for example, more than 4,800 robots have been detected acting in favor of the break-up of Spain, constantly spreading false or manipulated information on the internet. Some Russian televisions even opened their news in Spain with images of battle tanks, tanks heading to Barcelona, ​​which only existed in the editor's imagination. Therefore, I end up with two ideas. First, disinformation and propaganda campaigns are a threat to democracy, and as such we must treat them.And second, we Europeans do not want to impose our lifestyle on anyone, but we must know how to defend it, even on the internet.We are proud of our democracy, of the separation of powers, of freedom of expression, of the rule of law and of a free press, but that should be a strength, and never a weakness.Europe is an uncomfortable intelligence for the enemies of the truth, and post-truth is just another name for a lie.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. - (FI) Mr President, it is a fact that Russia's strategic communication in Europe is extensive and that aggressive behavior on the networks has increased. Let's talk about the information war. It is true, of course, that there has always been an information war during both peace and war. The relationship between the European Union and Russia is bad and inflamed. In this context, I would actually call on the honorable Presidents to do their utmost to have a dialogue between the Duma and the European Parliament. It does not currently exist. But for that matter. What can be done now to combat disinformation and false news? Just as it has been shown here, the European Union's strategic communication must, of course, be strengthened and given more resources. But also the media, social media, investigative journalism, incubators, and NGOs all have their own roles to help people distinguish between facts and lies. And as has been said here, media literacy is now very important. The European Union alone cannot, and the Member States must be involved. The great news was that the Swedish Prime Minister, Stefan Löfven, announced at the Sälen Security Conference last week that a psychological defense unit would be set up in Sweden. As the European Union now strengthens its own defense, we must also set up a psychological defense unit - let that be the key word.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President. I remember talking to my Western European colleague here in Parliament four years ago - even before the Russian occupation of Crimea - even in Parliament, that Sputnik is being registered in their country, that he is starting to broadcast in so many languages, and he replied: We are always in favor of freedom of expression, we are not worried about that. " I think this is an example of how many Western democracies underestimated what the Kremlin administration was doing when Putin came to power, in terms of technology and IT capabilities - from cyber-attacks to leaks to Western Democrats who then hid in Russia or in friendly countries, up to a well-developed level of propaganda. And for many Western countries, I think it was a problem for the Baltic States or the countries of the former Eastern bloc that Russia's concept of the world was starting to work as an element of propaganda. Unfortunately, we see that Russia is capable of interfering in propaganda and many other weapons in the information war, as has just been the case in the United States, not to mention a number of European Union countries in their political processes. Most importantly, it was not appreciated here that lies can be confused with truth in various proportions - up to one hundred percent lies and zero percent truth. And even the head of the Kremlin does it, who can safely say that our "funny bears" and others, say, hackers and those who work with information programs, do it as freelancers without being paid for it. And what has been said about robots or computers, which actually create this social information in the war of propaganda, then here we must remember that when it comes to freedom of expression, robots and computers do not have the right to freedom of expression. People have the right to freedom of expression. And that is an important thing that we need to take into account when understanding what kind of opponent we are currently facing. Therefore, I think it is extremely important to understand that our medicine against Russian propaganda must be very unconventional and fairly quick. Otherwise we will not win it.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, fake news is, of course, an issue affecting all ages. It has always been there. It comes from many states, as well as from private actors. But today in the internet age, people are very unclear as to where it comes from and who has sent this news. Indeed, as the Commissioner said, in order to have media literacy, it should be clear who has written these messages. What is interesting is that those who were at Maidan Square to support the democratic revolution against – let me say – the cronies of Mr Putin, find ourselves back on internet. I have seen myself at Maidan Square with big guns in my hands, but the guns were so big that they were bigger than my hands themselves. Normally, you would say that it’s nonsense, but people believe it. Why were you at Maidan Square with a gun? Well, again, I was not there. That is why I am sympathetic to the idea of President Macron of France that there must be transparency, on the platforms too, as to where the news comes from.  This is not intended to have a negative impact on news; there should be freedom of news, but there should be transparency as to where it comes from. You also have to see who sponsors it, because if you read something on the internet, you should know if it is supported by the state or by a private agency. Therefore, there must be transparency, and that is the most important thing concerning this. Once again, the best thing is that we provide not counter propaganda, but facts, facts and more facts, so that not only the Russians, but also the Chinese people and others, can have access to sources that they don’t normally have access to. Again, let us try to be active and not selective. It is not only Russia, but also China and others.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, expressions such as fake news must be handled with great caution, because they are ambiguous and risk being used for propaganda and censorship purposes.I do not mean by this to defend the Russian regime, but I am skeptical of the tendency to attribute interference to it in the elections in the US and Europe.There is no evidence of such interference but only denials from Winsconsin, California, the French Cybersecurity Agency and the Digital Society Institute in Berlin.Fake news is not only born on the Internet.In the Iraq war it was the mainstream press that spread devastating lies about weapons of mass destruction.We cannot hide the fact that those who most vehemently denounce fake news today and want to censor the Internet are in turn spreaders of fake news that restart a dangerous cold war with Russia.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! We have known for a long time that not only the propaganda media of Russia, but also parts of Russian politics are designed to promote divisions and polarization in the European Union, to undermine democratic debates and to strengthen Euro-skepticism. Fake news has become a particularly popular tool on social media. But it is also interesting that the Kremlin systematically supports anti-European parties, right-wing extremist populists such as Five Star, but also left-wing nationalist parties and incorporates activities against the European Union into this propaganda. We noticed that in the Brexit dispute, we have evidence of it, Ms. Spinelli, from France. And in the German elections there was an extremely interesting collaboration between bots from Nizhny Novgorod and the American alt-right movement to strengthen the alternative for Germany. How do we deal with this? The argument that we are waging about it does not serve to somehow defeat the Kremlin, rather the argument that we are waging serves to strengthen our societies in their democratic constitution. That is why I believe that it is right that we have DG StratCom. But it is too small and the networking with the national level is not good enough. In addition to tracking down the propaganda and the lies in the propaganda, I believe that the European Union urgently needs to strengthen journalism. We have to debate this because journalism has weakened in recent years. We watched. And I would like to say one last thing to strengthen the Commissioner: when social media start doing news like Facebook or Twitter or Google do, then they have to obey similar rules as media companies and the media Press.That is a task that we have to face.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Mister President! Today we are firstly talking about fake news, the battle term with which the established try to discredit all undesirable facts and opinions. Second, about Russia, which the same established people have made the scapegoat for everything bad in the world. Today's debate about the alleged influence of Russian fake news on the election is for the established people like Easter and Christmas on one day. I won't be able to prevent you from indulging in tirades about right-wing populists, Russians and the supposedly necessary regulation of opinions - we have just heard it from Ms. Harms. This is pure hypocrisy, because this Parliament will campaign in its own interest in the 2019 European elections. Own slogans with EU officials as election campaigners, who then produce their own truths, according to the motto: "Quality news should be supported by the government". This is propaganda at its best! Anyone who does something like this has no right to complain about the alleged influence of Russia on the election. If Ms. Kalniete rightly insists on freedom of expression, then take a look at the Network Enforcement Act in Germany as an example - why wander far away when evil is so close. You are sitting here in a glass house, so it is better not to throw stones.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the natural interlocutor in this discussion of ours, to whom we could address the doubts, all the doubts that have been expressed, is the Duma and it is truly disconcerting that this Parliament does not dialogue with what is the natural interlocutor of the largest country which, among other things, is part of Europe, not of the European Union but clearly of Europe, much more than Turkey. Fake news: keep talking to us about this problem which, in itself, would be serious. Very recently it has been said that there would be very strong Russian influences on the Italian electorate. The Italian security services denied it immediately, there is none of this, so we must be very careful. It is said that there was an influence on the Brexit vote, on the democratic explosion of the will of the Catalan people. But then you have to explain to me: are you so far from hearing people that you think that when they vote, they vote because there is an influence from Moscow? No, there is the voice of the peoples expressed by a vote, until proven otherwise.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - I listen to all this, especially the first speeches, and I feel as if I were at the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union: exactly the same phraseology that we need to strengthen our journalists, it is true that everyone should not be allowed to say what they want, only we here must be in charge of all that the enemy is threatening our socialist democracy. The same was said in the Soviet Union, I remember it, I am 75 years old, I remember it as it was. You speak exactly the same as they do. Russian propaganda is partly based on Soviet patterns, and therefore fortunately still a bit clunky, but European propaganda is based on Dr Goebbels' patterns: you lie and lie constantly. All newspapers say the same thing all over Europe. Here, Mr. van Baalen spoke about the shots in the Maidan. Who, sorry, said it was our people shooting it? Mr. Paet, your friend (Mr. Paet is sitting there), said on the phone to Baroness Ashton that we were the people who fired in the Maidan. Here are the basic lies and let's get over the lies. This is the first thing.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, as previous speakers have already pointed out, Russian disinformation campaigns are intended to undermine objective or ethical journalism while casting all information as biased or as an instrument of political power. I agree we have to tackle these challenges; it is high time to build up the resilience of our Union. In my opinion this should include four points. Firstly, to thoroughly investigate Russian interferences in election campaigns. Secondly, to impose targeted sanctions against hacking and falsified publication of sensitive data. Thirdly to turn the East StratCom task force into a permanent EU structure with adequate funding and increased personnel. And, fourthly, to develop an effective, well-targeted and tailor-made strategy on how to communicate and promote our European policies and values. In all our actions we ought to keep in mind that the European Union’s main strength when facing hostile influence from Russia is information rather than criminalisation. And, Mr President, a final remark. As a European Parliament we could perhaps improve things in our own House too. I observed in 2017 a few of our Members using the technical infrastructure of this Parliament to broadcast discussions and interviews on Kremlin-backed news channels such as Russia Today. I’m not quite sure if you can really, on the one hand, criticise disinformation campaigns backed and facilitated by Russian media outlets and, on the other hand, allow active support to them with our very own parliamentary infrastructure. This is inconsistent, this should stop. (Applause)

name: Eugen FREUND
text: - Mister President! We have known for some time - almost a year to be precise - that the spread of lies and fake news is also possible from the White House. Nevertheless, it makes a difference whether a self-centered politician believes that this will improve his own standing, or whether foreign media companies purposely spread false information in order to destabilize countries. As the shadow rapporteur for my group on the European Parliament's report on anti-EU propaganda, I have dealt intensively with this propaganda and the targeted misinformation. It was clear that some companies like Sputnik or Russia Today contribute significantly to the spread of false information. The fact that the Kremlin is not averse to this dissemination of propaganda, especially when it finances channels like Russia Today, remains undisputed. Europe therefore needs a powerful strategy. This is particularly important in order to protect yourself against outside influence and to counteract the uncertainty and radicalization of European citizens.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, the best way to deter Russian propaganda is to remain consistent. Every time we feel the temptation for a rapprochement with Russia, we have to know that there are necessary prices to be paid, usually by the weakest among us. Eight years ago, the Smolensk catastrophe happened. The Russian propaganda in the first quarter of an hour afterwards was extremely successful all over the world, including in our countries. Listen to the sound of silence whenever I even mention this thing nowadays. We have to know that next time we wish to go into deeper dialogue over the heads of others, there will be victims. This time, they will probably be among Ukrainian children.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: - Sir. Chairman! Colleges! After all, fake news was not invented in Russia, and the debate about fake news is much broader than Russia. There is no doubt that Russia has helped launch the latest and most important round of the debate, and that Russia will also be the place where this debate ends somewhere. But in the Liberal Group, we have made some effort to come up with a broad-spectrum plan with a lot of suggestions on how to actually do something about it. A multi-stranded plan. We must take action against data protection and transparency, including limiting the misuse of personal data - an incredibly important area! We need to focus on a much better education of the young people so that they will be able to move around the web in a proper way. We must have introduced an online media responsibility. We must ensure that the players in the market introduce some form of self-regulation. We must ensure that there are support mechanisms for proper journalism, for cross-border journalism. Finally, of course, we must make sure to take action - as several colleagues have mentioned - against decidedly fake news from, among others, Russia. We can do this by also supporting - as several colleagues point out - this East Stratcom task force, which we have already set up in the Union. We are also supporters of strengthening it. With these points, we should be able to address this issue in a sensible way.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: - Mr. President, Einstein used to say: «Two things are infinite: human stupidity and the universe; and I'm not sure about the latter. ' The pathetic obsession of the European right-wing media against alleged Russian interference is reaching degrees of stupidity that would make the scientist himself blush. Last November, the Spanish Foreign Minister denounced the Russian and Venezuelan interference in the debate on Catalonia to the European Union, and claimed to have data. We are still waiting for that data. Because there aren't. The media interested in repeating this mantra have embarrassing examples: Twitter accounts based in St. Petersburg, fake news. But, if we go to the facts, let's see, if you have an interest. Last November, the National Intelligence Center, through its head of cybersecurity, affirmed that the CNI had not detected any cyber attack by the Russian Government. Neither did the German agencies find significant Russian activity, nor did the French cyber authority. In other words, behind this pathetic paranoia lies a clear political strategy, that is, to prevent good neighborliness with Russia. Stop paranoia, gentlemen!

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - Even those who have not heard the famous Nazi propaganda minister Gebels say that a lie repeated a million times becomes true can be seen by watching television controlled by the current Kremlin regime. The situation is worrying. Even suffering from falling oil prices and far less from European Union sanctions, Russia sends out thousands of false and hateful messages every year for tens of millions of euros. By the way, Russia, which has become a hostage of the Putin regime, is not the only source of such a threat. The information threat posed by radical religious movements has diminished in recent times, but that does not mean it has disappeared. It is only so gratifying that the dangers of hostile propaganda are already recognized here in the institutions of the European Union. Until a couple of years ago, only individual Member States spoke about such information threats. I am convinced that we are on the right track in strengthening strategic communication. At the same time, I would like to point out that we need to start strengthening Europe's resilience to propaganda from the very beginning, from raising citizens' awareness.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, thank you very much. Now just so there’s no misunderstanding about my position on Russia, I’ll repeat what I’ve said many times before. Mr Putin is a gangster that runs a gangster state. The old Soviet Union used to spend millions on infiltrating and undermining Western governments and societies, and it has to be said they were very successful at it. So there’s nothing new going on, but you are seeking to create a scapegoat for your own unpopularity with the peoples of Europe. Now, don’t blame the Russians for your own mistakes. To give you two examples, you’re unpopular because of economic stagnation on austerity due to the eurozone and mass uncontrolled immigration and the Islamisation of our societies due to that immigration. Now you seek a distraction and you found it in Russian propaganda. You give Mr Putin too much credit. He is not the author of your unpopularity, you are the authors of your own unpopularity.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: - Thank you, Chairman.This debate is based on false assumptions, fake news.The responsible Dutch minister, Ms Ollongren, could not cite any serious example in the Lower House of Russian influence on the opinion of Dutch citizens.Influencing is done by the European Commission.This is not allowed, but is done systematically: in elections in Italy and Spain and in the Brexit referendum.Because as Mr Juncker stated, a democratic vote against the Union is not possible.Brussels has alarmingly little faith in the voter and therefore does not see much in democracy.Only difficult, those changing preferences.That is why we are moving towards European censorship laws.Scary.This is not going to end well.Not for the media, not for the citizen and not for the freedom of expression.Mr President, we have to choose: this European Union or our freedom.I've already chosen.Thank you.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I feel as though I have been transported back to the 1980s: the cold warriors have woken up, the transatlantic people are back. Mr King, when you are talking about the Russian media supplying wrong numbers and facts, why not tell us when the Russians have supplied wrong numbers. When did they provide false facts? I have followed the events and the wars in Libya, Afghanistan, Serbia, Iraq and Syria, and so in all these things I have seen that our transatlantic lying media report incorrectly, but not the Russian news like Sputnik or RT. On two visits to Syria I was able to see for myself who is telling the truth. Why are you not brave enough to approach Russia and seek dialogue instead of starting a propaganda war? The future of Europe - a Europe of fatherlands - lies in communion with Russia and not with the alien power of the USA.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr President, Putin's propaganda contains anti-Western discourse, seeks to influence elections and cultivates a positive image of Russia's autocracy. Before the new year, a new headquarters for Putin's trolls on the Internet was inaugurated, an environment conducive to propaganda. In Romania, the work of these trolls is facilitated by numerous public figures, politicians or alleged journalists. Former MEP Adrian Severin, for example, publishes texts on the websites of the Russian propaganda Sputnik and Russia Today, which also take in extenso the positions of Sorin Roșca Stănescu, former PNL senator, and Adrian Năstase, former socialist prime minister. Their common point: challenging convictions for corruption. In the Romanian context, pro-Russian propaganda has become a tool in the fight against the institutions of justice, anti-corruption legislation, the influence of the European Union and the United States. The special relationship between socialists and Russian propaganda is also confirmed by incumbent politicians, such as the PSD deputy from Bucharest Liviu Pleșoianu, who also fights with the Romanian justice and broadcasts ultranationalist speeches. The world of journalism is not forgiven by the sin of flirting with misinformation of Russian origin. The information from the Kremlin is sometimes presented as truthful, without any critical spirit. There are also colleagues in the European Parliament here in the S&D group who support exactly the same views as Russian propaganda. I see, for example, Mrs. Grapini, right here with us.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: You cannot combat fake news with other fake news.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, next year the citizens of Europe will elect a new European Parliament. This raises an uncomfortable question: how many seats will Russia get? Let us not kid ourselves; Russian meddling in democratic elections is no longer the exception – it is becoming the norm. From the US Presidential election to Brexit, the hands of Kremlin have been busily dancing along keyboards, churning out disinformation – the real fake news and propaganda – the full extent of which is yet to be uncovered and the consequences yet to be fully understood. In the EU alone, we know for a fact that Russia has conducted propaganda and misinformation campaigns in several countries: Latvia, Estonia, Lithuania, Denmark, Sweden, Finland, the UK, France, Netherlands, Spain, Germany, Hungary, Bulgaria, Italy and so on. All of these EU member states have been – and continue to be – the target of Russian misinformation and propaganda campaigns. Our best defence is to stand firm on European values, principles and ideals: Democracy, freedom of the press, speaking the truth to power. The EEAS and this East StratCom team is doing a tremendous job, as several have noted. They are the front line, defending democracy and the free press, but they are caught in an uneven fight and that is why I am calling for a marked strengthening of East StratCom and an EU action plan for countering Russian meddling in the 2019 European election. And so I return to my original question: “How many seats will Russia win in the European Parliament?” Let’s make sure they win no seats.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, Minister, honorable colleagues, social media is the new media and that is the reality, whether we like it or not. We live in a time when any publication can reach anywhere in the world, up to hundreds of thousands, millions of users in a matter of seconds. The more scandalous, unbelievable and fabricated a fake news is, the faster it spreads. Both enemy propaganda and aggressive small communities, which are considered to be the ultimate truth bearers, take advantage of this. And in this legislature there are followers of modern cultural Marxism who are trying to impose censorship and stigmatize holders of different opinions. Yes, there is fake news, but the answer is not to impose censorship or write norms about what can be written or not written on social networks and why this is impossible. Nor is it in the forcible change of cultural patterns and traditions. The answer to fake news is to tell the truth as quickly as possible, more organized, calmer and supported by facts. This is what each of us must do.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, Mr Commissioner, colleagues, a massive wave of Kremlin-produced propaganda flooded the continent, from Vladivostok to Lisbon. It finally ended up across the Atlantic, just to find Washington DC equally unprepared. This was also the case with the political waters in London, Paris, Madrid and Barcelona. I particularly appreciate the title of today’s debate on Russia. It is precise concerning the Russian propaganda which aims to influence EU countries, meaning us! The EU’s response to this hybrid warfare will not be policing the media. Our response must be an effective EU media policy set up to defend our liberal European democracy, basic values and way of life.  Lastly, in shaping the EU’s media policy, we must certainly not be limited only to election periods as Putin’s foreign services, troll factories and bots are on duty 24/7.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: - President! The influence of Russian propaganda is taking on increasingly worrying proportions. Strengthening the EU's anti-propaganda campaigns is extremely important and a good direction, but it is worthless in countries where governments themselves are the main consumers and disseminators of Russian propaganda. In recent years, the Hungarian government has consistently sided with Russia, not only in economic and political alliances with Vladimir Putin's Russia, but also played a significant role in disseminating Russian false news and propaganda in Hungary and beyond. Russian channels that spread fake news - Sputnik, Russia Today - operate not only on official channels, but also, of course, on online platforms. Thousands of trolls help spread false news, propaganda. In Hungary and some other Member States, they receive significant support from the state and public service media, which should be a forum for politically independent, impartial, real news. Therefore, the European Union can no longer go without a word in favor of the countries where the public service media themselves and the government itself are the main consumers and disseminators of this false news. This requires the EU to recognize the need to support independent, free and impartial media, both legally and financially.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, we are again discussing the influence of so-called Russian propaganda in EU countries. What about the millions, the millions in EU propaganda to pervert the democratic decisions of the Irish, the Dutch and the French on the Lisbon Treaty? And you spent millions on EU propaganda to prevent Brexit, aided and abetted of course by the BBC, the Brussels Broadcasting Corporation, which also receives largesse I believe from the EU. This destroys any impartiality or credibility that they might have had. Fortunately the British public saw through that one.
