But the EU is still trying to do this by setting up the Orwellian propaganda machine to push the EU project and subvert national democracies, in your own words: “challenging Euroscepticism”. Well, it is pure Pravda as the old Soviet Union called it, pure Pravda.  I am more concerned with EU propaganda than the clunky Russian version, and I assure you so are most other people. Mr McAllister talked about Russia Today, well Russia Today gave UKIP a voice in the days when we could not get it on the BBC. So perhaps they are defending freedom and a freedom you lot want to close down. So thank God for them.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Mr Coburn, you practically managed to transform a blue card into a speech at the end of your intervention. That is not allowed. We have to respect the time limit because otherwise other colleagues would not be able to exercise their democratic right to speak.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The fact that governments are spreading propaganda - pretty much all over the world - is nothing particularly new, and that Russia is also participating is not particularly surprising. However, it must be stated that probably over 90% of the European population has never come into contact with this propaganda. Because this form of propaganda that exists is more of a marginal phenomenon - especially when we refer to Sputnik or Russia Today. It was already heard today that it was Russian military doctrine to spread false information, and I would like to remind you of the Iraq war, in which, by the way, Spain and Italy and a few other countries took part alongside the USA and Great Britain. You may remember the fake news that started this war. If you want to decide politically about truth or lies and it is no longer part of the political struggle to decide what is truth or lie, then you leave the democratic consensus. That is not how it usually works in democratic societies.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, colleagues! Russia is an authoritarian regime in which genuinely free elections under the opportunities of equal rights do not take place. I see that colleagues like Meuthen and Pretzell and Coburn and Couso Permuy and all these people are defending this Russia in this system, because it also corresponds to their own ideology, which does not correspond to free, liberal democracy. And that decouples them as real opponents of freedom. Second, we have to make it clear that we cannot strike back with the same method that Russia and its friends in Europe do, but that we are a free society with free media and cannot respond to it with state instruments. For this reason it is the best way to give the western free media, but also the opportunities that may still exist there, opportunities in such countries, including the new media. We ourselves must make it clear to our own people how lies are made. And it has to be clear that we have to find ways to explain when lies are lies. That is the bottom line. It cannot be that truth and lies stand side by side and that this is presented by Mr. Pretzell as a democratic discourse. It's the opposite of that.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, in the autumn of 2016, we voted in the European Parliament for a resolution to combat Russian propaganda. I was restrained myself then and still think the same today. I agree that monitoring the media influence of countries on politics and society is necessary, and the intertwining of the media with political parties and companies must also be recognized, so I have some critical caveats. First, why are we only dealing with Russian propaganda? What is our attitude to the news of American FOX News? Are we bothered by the capital investments of American media corporations in European media stations? Whose views do Al Jazeera channels tell us? And if we stay in Europe, what do we think about the national media owned by a party, its officials and their associates? We have such a medium in Slovenia. Are their political messages propaganda? And another remark, perhaps in the message of Sputnik and RT, which we call Russian propaganda, we should recognize Russia's successful attempt to find its position in the media world by imitating existing patterns after many years of Western media domination. I hope that the establishment of an expensive anti-Russian propaganda department will bring results, but if our plenum is to remain credible, we must treat all media propaganda, especially false propaganda, equally.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Mr Chairman!In taking the floor in this debate, I would like to highlight three points.Firstly, the importance of the report adopted by Parliament in November 2016, prepared by the Polish MEP Anna Fotyga, which was just largely devoted to Russian propaganda, and its conclusions, which are being implemented with some resistance, but are nevertheless implemented.Secondly, the establishment of the StratCom institution dealing with the study of sabotage techniques, counteracting disinformation, and conducting educational campaigns, and it seems that this institution should rather be excluded from the EU foreign service.It should simply be an independent institution, an independent EU agency.And finally, thirdly, I would like to commend the one million euro increase in funding for the fight against Russian propaganda, but at the same time recall that Russia allocates a thousand times more per year to one of its television stations, Russia Today.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Mr President, I’m listening to this debate with a strong feeling of déjà vu. I was born in the Soviet Union and when I was a child I heard about anti-Soviet propaganda each and every day. If there were no meat or coffee, books or cars, we always knew who was guilty: Western capitalism and, personally, Ronald Reagan. Today when the European Union is facing challenges, crisis in Catalonia, problems with democratic institutions in a Member State or a low level of trust in Europe as such, some of my colleagues know exactly who is guilty: anti-European propaganda and, personally, Vladimir Putin. As a former journalist, I cannot agree with such a black and white approach. And the main solution I see in terms of counter-propaganda is an honest, open and professional media. A media which is free from censorship and which is not regulated or directed by politicians. We should not make the mistakes of Soviet leaders but today, sorry, I have a strong feeling that we’re dangerously close to that. And of course I fully agree with Mr van Baalen, the media have to be transparent. But it also concerns Statcom, where you will find not a single name of these guys who are writing this information review.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: - Mr President, combating disinformation through disinformation, this is a beautiful subject of philosophy which somewhat sums up the state of the European Union. I am particularly amazed by what I have heard from the Commission. I find it scandalous that you can stigmatize Russia in this way. Fake news has always existed, including with us. If the European Union wants to hunt fake news, well, let it start by doing it at home, sweep in front of its door, do it with certain media which, for their part, are force-fed. public money and which very often disseminate false information by which, of course, they influence the elections in the Member States. The European Union accuses the Kremlin of funding a campaign of disinformation against Europe. Tackling Russia is good, it's fashionable. You won't have many enemies, at least, with this. Russia is really the right scapegoat for you because the reality is that what you cannot stand is that someone can speak in dissent from what you are saying. Rather than hunting down Russia, start doing it with Islamist propaganda.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: - This debate is not at all about Russia alone. It goes much deeper than that. In public space, we find it normal to know who we are dealing with. On the internet and social media, on the other hand, you can anonymously declare all kinds of untruths, or as the exposed Dutch troll who was active during the Ukraine referendum said: "Of course I lie about the Ukraine". Employers, companies and educators will need to join forces to give people the tools to tell opinions from fact and real from fake. I would like to ask the Commission how we can tackle anonymity on the internet and what the right balance is between privacy and transparency. If Twitter can indicate with a blue tick who the real Beyoncé is among all the fake accounts, why can't we indicate who's identities are known, who are not, and who are clearly just a computer? I believe this challenge is at the heart of our democracy. Let me underline this, especially for our colleagues in the ENF Group, with a short quote from Hannah Arendt: 'The ideal subject of totalitarian rule is not a convinced nazi or a dedicated communist, but people for whom the distinction between fact and fiction, true or false, no longer exists'.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I am afraid that technology today has eliminated our privacy, that is my belief.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the work done in recent months by the Union to combat the phenomena of external interference is intensifying. The creation of the fake news task forces by Commissioner Mariya Gabriel is certainly a positive fact, alongside the work already started by High Representative Federica Mogherini within the External Action Service with East StratCom to improve European communication in the countries of Eastern neighborhood and spot disinformation operations. At the same time, however, we must be careful not to focus on Russia alone, with which a political dialogue must be maintained precisely in order not to unwittingly help Putin's authoritarian grasp and his nationalist narrative. The phenomenon of counter-information to destabilize Europe, in fact, is certainly a serious and tried issue, but of global scope, not attributable to a single country, and which questions us on the need to ensure that the European Union takes a leap forward. institutional quality towards a true federation, which knows how to counter these phenomena more effectively.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, we have been talking for a long time about fake Russian propaganda and we are doing this because yes, it is real, it is true, and it is a threat. Just a week ago, US senators detailed in a more than 200-page report the Kremlin's practices of influencing elections in states on several continents. Once again, it is reconfirmed that Moscow has no hesitation in controlling the elections and intervening even in consolidated democracies. In the Kremlin, manipulation, misinformation and lies are state policy to control domestic and foreign policy decisions in as many states of the world as possible, if at all. And in our country, the Foreign Action Service has only 14 employees in East StratCom, which should fight thousands and thousands of trolls of false Russian propaganda. Obviously, it's a joke and it's totally insufficient. And, in order to answer an earlier colleague who said that he hopes that in the elections there will be no agents of the Russian Federation in the European Parliament, I want to tell you that we still have agents of the Russian Federation in the European Parliament. last term. Finally, people died for democracy and free elections. So we have to respect this desire, we want to live in democracy and the politicians who work with Russia for various interests betray us.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, propaganda is nothing new, but with the Kremlin, and certainly other governments and non-state actors also actively seeking to influence European audiences and undermine democratic values, we should not be naive. What is new is the exponential spread through social media, the lack of transparency of political advertisements online, and the selection of the order in which information is presented by unaccountable companies’ algorithms. This impacts people’s access to information and thus democratic resilience. But in the quest for solutions, the worst thing we can do is to erode the very freedoms we need to defend.  A few action points: we need transparency rules for political advertisements online. We need algorithmic accountability and the tackling of botnets and trolls. We should actively try to reach Russian-speaking minorities in Europe and populations in the countries around Europe directly in Russian language with pluralist sources and opinions. We should defend and promote democratic values in Europe and abroad and not compromise them.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: - Fake news, especially in recent years, is becoming global. With the advancement of digital technology and increasing connectivity, information reaches every corner of the planet in seconds. It is a powerful weapon that can easily and much cheaper win the minds and hearts of millions of people. In the geopolitical race, these weapons are increasingly used to achieve political goals. The aims of this propaganda pressure are to distort the truth, to provoke fear, doubt and division in the European Union. The big question is what is our democratic response to such practices. There can be only one answer - the truth. Any false information must be answered immediately with the truth. I therefore call on both the European institutions and the Member States to invest much more money, resources and people in this response to propaganda and false news. My examples are directed against the European Union, NATO and its geopolitical choices. The Western Balkans are particularly threatened by propaganda aimed at changing public attitudes.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Thank you, Chairman. Russian President Putin has a new weapon in his arsenal against the democratic West: the deliberate dissemination of disinformation. This is done through social media, among other things, but also - as we noticed during the debate today - by financing political parties in Europe in order to disrupt democratic processes. The greatest threat is to Russia's neighbors, mostly young democracies. But we have also seen how Russian propaganda was effective in Brexit and in the US elections. First of all, we must recognize that Russian propaganda is a serious threat to our open democratic societies. That is the case. We must therefore do more to protect our citizens against this. The European Commission will issue recommendations in the spring. Technology companies like Facebook will have to provide more transparency about advertisers and about algorithms that determine what we get to see at all. To underline the seriousness of the matter and to create more awareness, we should organize an annual debate in the European Parliament to enter into a debate with each other on the basis of information (including from StratCom). Thank you

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!The foundation of our security in the East, as well as the foundation of the security and independence of the countries that neighbor us there, is our real, not virtual, solidarity, above all solidarity in security policy.Today, in this Chamber, we heard a representative of the German Social Democracy, and thus one of the largest political parties in Europe, say and convince the European Council that it is time to normalize relations with Russia.Crimea is occupied, Russia does not want to return the plane in which the Polish president died and which is the main evidence in the ongoing investigation, and we are talking about normalization?What is this standard supposed to be about today by our colleague sitting in the very center of this parliament?This is the career of Chancellor Schröder, his outstanding expert role, which he continues to do with President Putin?

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I am not convinced that it is necessary for us to return to this subject so many times in Parliament.I think we have a lot of more important things to talk about.The creation of false stories, tendentious news, including stories and actions that constitute an attempt to influence democratic elections and processes in other countries, all lead to aggravated international conditions.However, I believe that propaganda from abroad, from Russia or from anywhere else, cannot undermine the confidence of the citizens of the European Union in the Union alone and its values.These are Cold War instruments and the Cold War is a foreplay of real fighting usually.Therefore, two equally active and motivated parties are needed.When we point out the unacceptable actions of others, we must not ourselves become participants in this dangerous game, which is becoming more and more biting and, unfortunately, more and more effective in the face of the new and pervasive means at our disposal.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, it is quite interesting that the communists and the extremist nationalists in this Chamber can’t see Russian disinformation. Of course you can’t, but we can see you. We see that you are giving the same message of extremism, conflicts and dislike for democracy as Russian disinformation tries to impose on our societies. The difference between Russian disinformation and a lot of the other disinformation we see is that Russian disinformation is part of a broader warfare against Europe and European democracies. It cannot be seen as isolated from all the other things that Russia does. It must be defeated and disclosed, and we must tell them that we will win and they will lose.  (Applause)

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Thank you for acting in my interest. It is no wonder: propaganda and propaganda activities against strangers have always been present and present. Are you surprised that Russia is not satisfied if the European Union grows stronger? And how is she to be satisfied, since she has lost Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary, and so on? It is known that it will act in this direction to weaken the European Union within. I have the impression that if we show that we can be proud of the European Union as a beautiful project, it will increase our resilience. We have a new instrument, i.e. social media, which is actually uncontrolled, because we want it ourselves, which are generally available, but if there are records, for example from our today's discussion, that Russia Today or Sputnik informed better than the BBC, Agence France or the Polish Press Agency, and if we pass this on to the public, it will be an incentive - watch Russia Today. So this is not what we should be doing. If there are records - here we heard our colleagues: "Before you talk about Russia, put your affairs in order, because it is not good in the EU itself" - we are giving fuel ourselves. It is important that our debate does not contain the premise of helplessness - they talked, but they cannot do anything. Here we should support the efforts of the Commission. In the European Parliament too, we are taking steps to avoid being the ones who cannot.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! I believe that the issue that appears most often here, i.e. fake news, is only one of the examples of Russian propaganda and Russian propaganda channels, not the most important one. We should reflect more deeply on the problem that colleagues raised on the margins: the influence of Russia and Russian propaganda on European politics and politicians, and the role of some European politicians or in European countries in spreading Russian propaganda. It is not just about populists, nationalists and the like. Let us take the example mentioned by MP Jurek: former German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder. Is he a nationalist, a populist? No - he is a man who, like his party, always speaks very positively about the European Union. What about its activities? Well, I think it is much more dangerous than all this fake news. Likewise, all those politicians who claim that Nord Stream is just an economic project are spreading Russian propaganda.

name: Javier NART
text: - Mr President, there are some facts that are decisive. One, there are computer servers based in the Russian Federation that generate, spread and multiply false messages, poisoning the networks. Two, these messages are aimed at fracturing Western societies. Three, servers require high investments in facilities and personnel. Four, the required funding is not known or justified, as it has no advertising. Five, the police and intelligence services of the Russian Federation are extraordinarily effective. Six, certainly this situation does not benefit the relations between the European Union and the Russian Federation, which I understand cannot remain frozen. Seven, why do the Russian authorities allow this activity? And, in conclusion: if President Macron has had the common sense to establish legislation that blocks this fictitious information, this intoxicating information, what is the European Union going to do to carry out such an activity?

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - I will allow myself one such historical parallel.Before World War II, many nations and Jews lived together.What happened?What else did the Jews do that many people completely changed their minds about the Jews during the rise of the Nazis and then cooperated, beat them, betrayed them to the Nazis?They just believed in propaganda, and that is why we need to open this topic here today.Ladies and gentlemen, the hundred-fold lie about the EU is becoming true, and if we do not realize this, the EU has no place here at all in the future.And I personally don't want that.That is why I am happy for this debate, that is why I am happy to be able to comment on this, and that is why I am happy to be able to appeal to the Commissioner and the Commissioner to increase money for organizations and ways of combating any propaganda..

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr. President, Commissioner King, Henry Kissinger once said to Robert McNamara: 'Do you know, Bob? The fact that I am a paranoid doesn’t mean that I don’t have real enemies. " We can argue if the strategy is erratic, but not that the threat is real. Because propaganda as a way of doing politics did not end with the totalitarianisms that faced in World War II, but continues to threaten the founding values ​​of the European Union, in a hybrid of cyberterrorism, fake news, intoxication and blackmail. And it is true that the threat does not come only from Russia nor does it affect only the countries in its direct vicinity, but also that the studies and reports of the United States Congress and the commission of inquiry launched in the United Kingdom and of European intelligence agencies point to thousands of automated accounts, based in Russia, that attack the founding values ​​of democratic societies, as recently demonstrated in Catalonia, to sow chaos and confusion, furthering the cause of secession. It is imperative that the European Union lives up to the Prague declaration by Police Station Mogherini and invests and equips itself to deal with this absolutely real threat.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!I am glad that today most of us here in the European Parliament see something like Russian propaganda and its harmfulness for the European Union, for democracy in general, but it would be really hard to leave this room and say: "Well, we said and we can do nothing.”As Mr Liberadzki pointed out to us here.Well, we have to do something.Russian propaganda, of course, there are many, many pianos, but we have all pointed to one of them here, namely Russia Today.Yes, they want to influence public opinion in the European Union, or in general in the world, but we also have to influence their public opinion.Europe Today - this should be our answer.We have experience, we have Radio Free Europe.There are such initiatives and the European Union, the European Commission should support them.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, tensions between Western societies and Russia have given rise to the flow of fake news that aims to weaken the European Union. Europe must become less naive to be able to defend itself given this surge of false news and propaganda. A few examples. Most European hotels show the TV Russia Today alongside ordinary channels. Some months ago, in this very same European Parliament building an exhibition was opened showcasing Russian views on the events in Syria. Would anyone imagine having the same kind of EU exhibition in the Russian State Duma right now? Also, European journalists have to be very professional. There is a need to go back to classical journalism rules. All facts must be checked. You must be critical of your sources and no Russian media channel should be considered a trustworthy source. One must be able to distinguish between propaganda channels and real journalists, and it is not that difficult actually. So Europe itself can do a lot to protect its societies from propaganda attacks by using common sense and being less naive.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank first of all our StratCom team for their excellent efforts which should be taken extremely seriously by our governments and foreign policy leaders. Still, they are too small and need much more funding. But one field where Russian propaganda has had a lasting effect: it has succeeded to make us believe that the Russian Duma is freely elected, not a Putin selected body and that by fostering personal contacts with Duma members we can exercise some influence on the conduct of Russian rulers.  I think the opposite is true: Duma members are instruments of Putin par excellence. They have a very clear programme and they are ten times better prepared for spreading disinformation among European parliamentarians than we are. We should keep this in mind.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the impact of Russian propaganda on the citizens of the member states of the Union is certainly not negligible, but the big question is how crucial it is in their decision-making in elections and referendums.I'm sure it's not that much.It seems to me that the European political mainstream, which is rapidly losing the trust of its citizens, and thus its political power, wants to find its Pedro in Moscow, someone he can blame for everything.Yes, Moscow certainly wants to make some impact in Europe, but no - it is not primarily responsible for disappointing our citizens.Nothing is happening today that has not happened before.The great powers have always used various methods to destabilize each other.Today, only other means are used for the same purposes.Of course, we should not silently observe this and allow ourselves to be destabilized, but I do not think it is advisable to attribute superhuman traits to Putin in order to cover up or mitigate his own inaction, incompetence and obvious mistakes.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, the famous Collins Dictionary declared 2017 the word of the year fake news. Compared to 2016, this term was used 360% more. So that also tells us something about what it is about. Ms. Caliente, thank you very much for being able to raise this topic on today's agenda and I agree with you that we want zero tolerance when it comes to hate speech. Likewise, we can in no way allow the democratic European values ​​we have achieved to be undermined, even through Russian propaganda. We want to fight myths, manipulations, hybrid wars. It follows from all this that the aim is to destabilize the European Union. Mr. Gonzales, I agree with you. We will not impose our way of life on anyone, but we want to preserve our way of life and we want to fight propaganda. It is true that great powers, not great but undemocratic powers, have always used propaganda for their influence. We must preserve ours and I am glad that the European Union is taking all possible action to prevent fake news and hybrid wars.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: - The European Union's response to the threat of Russian aggression has so far been weak, as a large part of our political elite, especially in western Europe, still does not recognize this threat. The Kremlin’s aggressive actions are unprecedented after the Cold War. These include the occupation and annexation of foreign territories by force, the constant violations of other countries' borders and airspace, the unprecedented use of disinformation, hostile interference in democratic elections and constant cyber attacks. The fact that when the United States investigates a clearly hostile intrusion into its democratic fortress, the electoral process, such investigations have not been launched anywhere in Europe, although cases of Russian intervention in the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, France, Germany are obvious. We must therefore identify Russia as a major source of hostile disinformation and take immediate practical action: 1) to acknowledge the threat, 2) to investigate and publicly unmask hostile Russian activities, 3) to increase STRATCOMM capacity to the required level, and 4) to spread awareness outside the professional community.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: - Madam President! In recent months, we have witnessed attempts to manipulate public opinion and influence the results of democratic elections in the European Union and beyond. Many of these attempts were made by the Russian Federation. Russia has developed a strategy of deceitful propaganda, the main aim of which is to weaken and dismantle the European Union, inter alia by fostering anti-European tendencies and strengthening nationalist and populist parties in individual Member States and in neighboring countries. I am sorry to say, but there are also party representatives in this room who defend this conduct by the Russian Federation. The example of Ukraine is particularly telling. Influenced by the lies spread by the Kremlin-controlled media, foundations, internet bots and the troll army, many EU citizens believed that Ukraine was responsible for the bloody war waged on its territory by Russia. Madam President! In the face of this information war, we must act immediately and decisively. I appeal to the European Commission and the representatives of the Member States to take steps to develop an effective strategy to combat this phenomenon.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!I think an important point is that, in the context of this debate, we should make our public aware that something is happening in this area - that Russia is actually on this path.If we let Mr Putin succeed in the form of pushing the line between truth and lies, or if we accept that everyone has their truth, then he would have won.I am confident that through the power of our democracy we have the strength to make it clear: We are not doing anything against Russian politics, we are not doing any counter-propaganda, but from my point of view the most effective means against such fake news is simply the plain truth.If we get that across, then those who want to falsify the truth have no chance.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - I watch with regret and bitterness how much damage the Kremlin trolling has done to our country, to the EU Member States.The team, which has been fighting disinformation on the EU side, has been active since 2015 and has just over 10 members.Yes, the East StratCom team has been expanded by 2 members following countless calls from this Parliament.The High Representative here - euphemistically speaking - underestimated the situation and is not in an irresponsible way to remedy it.My country, the Czech Republic, is inundated with meaningless false information about the EU.Before the second round of the presidential election, a whirlwind of prefabricated lies from the workshop of AC 24, Aeronet, Sputnik and many others is pouring into the decent opponent of the current president Zeman.Please consider our tactics against the Kremlin.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Madam President, a number of EU Member States have been subjected to severe disinformation attacks from Russia. Russian deception is aimed at weakening, destabilising and dividing the European Union. In essence, we are talking about an attack on democracy.  When it comes to confronting this, the High Representative has stated that the External Action Service has taken proper action. However, many experts beg to disagree. The EU instantly needs to raise public awareness, to streamline the exchange of intelligence and to allocate necessary resources to institutions like Europol and StratCom. In order to protect and preserve fundamental values we need an effective strategy. We need political courage to counter the forces for whom misrepresentations and lies are the principal political instrument.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: – Madam President, the chief editor of Russia Today said that Russia Today is capable of conducting an information war against the whole western world: to conquer and to grow an audience in order to make use of this audience at critical moments. It seems that the Kremlin decided a long time ago that the EU is an enemy of Russian interests and should be treated accordingly, by any means. But our lack of action shows that the EU does not perceive Russia as a real threat and we are not doing enough. We must end this dolce farniente and decide more quickly about our position on strategic communication and counter propaganda; such a decision must be followed by actions with an appropriate budget. Either we respond on the same scale or we start an open dialogue with Russia based on our interests and priorities. We must understand that this is not about an ideological conflict. The Kremlin’s propaganda is targeting very concrete files, such as the energy file and, using the old, but effective, strategy of divide et impera. It will clearly win this game if we do not take firm action today. (Applause)

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of the Commission, can I just express our appreciation for the work that this Parliament does to address the issues around this phenomenon, this challenge of disinformation. Today’s debate obviously, but not just starting today, going back some time, a number of you have mentioned the resolution that Ms Fotyga was rapporteur for in 2016.  Deliberate disinformation raises the stakes. It raises the stakes both for freedom of expression and for our properly functioning democracies. The challenge for public authorities at all levels is to find ways of tackling disinformation without having an adverse effect on freedom of expression, as a number of you have underlined. It is no good our seeking to counter disinformation or fake news by setting up some kind of 1984-style Ministry of Truth; and we are not going to do that.  As I said earlier, the Commission is looking at what more might be done to address the challenge of hostile propaganda, fake news and online disinformation, always bearing in mind that balance between countering disinformation and respecting our democratic rights including crucially freedom of expression.  So we are reinforcing our StratCom’s efforts. We will continue our support to media freedom of expression. We will come forward with proposals focusing on this challenge of fake news later this spring. We are looking at what more we can do with the big Internet platforms to address these issues and we are pursuing, with you, the measures that need to be taken to reinforce our cybersecurity, our cyber resilience and deterrence. Those are concrete steps that we are taking on these issues.  Honourable Members, this has been a most timely debate.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: Présidente en exercice du Conseil. – Madame la Présidente, je vous remercie. Madam President, thank you again for inviting me to this debate. I have followed it closely, and it has again illustrated the topical character and the scale of the challenge posed by disinformation and propaganda. As some Members have mentioned, the tools we already have, such as East StratCom, are proving to be valuable in raising awareness of disinformation, but it is clear that they are only a part of the response to such challenges. Today’s debate also further highlighted the need for EU institutions and Member States to further cooperate. Supporting greater media literacy and media plurality is also essential, and here all Member States have a role to play too. The European Union should further communicate positive narratives and fact-based messages and develop resilience among its citizens towards propaganda and disinformation. In this way people will not feel confused or insecure and will be able to engage in critical thinking, distinguishing facts from propaganda.  (Applause)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.I come back to you, Mrs Grapini.I have already been warned twice that you asked to speak for "a personal matter".There is no problem, I will give it to you.I just remind you that under Article 164, you cannot express yourself on the substance of the debate, but simply, which is not bad enough, I believe, to refute either comments made during the debate.concerning you personally, or opinions that are lent to you, or you can correct your own statements.You have a maximum of three minutes to do this.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, I will not refer to the merits, I just wanted, based on this article that you said, to refer to false things said. My name was pronounced. Colleague Cristian Preda, who, by the way, left the hall, used his speaking time in this extremely important debate on a very important topic, accusing me of being pro-Russian. I am a pro-European demonstrated in the country and here, through my activity. We have demonstrated this both in the country and here, and I believe that we cannot debate false news by feeding colleagues in Parliament, the Commission, the Council with false information. And I think he is unethical, he is a man who does not enjoy any popularity, he is no longer part of a political party, he is totally discredited and I do not think it is normal to accuse without arguments. And I think it would be good to try to find a solution by which those who come here with accusations - we should also benefit from the presumption of innocence - also come with evidence. I believe that this would be the ethical path in a forum, as is the European Parliament, and this is not the first time that Mr Cristian Preda has done so. However, we should summarize and tell those who take the floor to refer to the subject under debate. It is an important subject and I believe very much in everything that the Commissioner and the Council and many colleagues here have said in the debates that we, the European Union, the European Commission, the Parliament can do more to avoid false news. By the way, I am a member of the LIBE committee and you know - and you are a member - that I am involved and I appreciated Tanja Fajon's own-initiative report, which wants us to find a solution together to combat false news. Thank you - my intervention was only related to an absolutely shameful attack.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: You have had the opportunity to speak, Madam, indeed, on this subject.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - This debate without resolution deals with the impact of Russian propaganda on the security of the Member States and the interference in their political and electoral processes. Russia is taking and encouraging actions to destabilize both European governments and societies as well as the EU and NATO. Several Member States have expressed concern about the effects of this propaganda and its potential dramatic political effects, especially considering that Hungary and Italy will hold elections this year, or the geographical and historical links existing in the Eastern countries. This issue is highly relevant from the defense perspective, since the relationship with Russia is one of the crucial points in the creation of the European Defense Union. The EU has considered this issue as key and a specialized unit has been established to address it. In addition, a Declaration was signed in Prague urging the High Representative to adopt measures in this regard and the budget has been increased to fight against external interference and false news.

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: in writing. - The information space has become a modern battlefield, including in Europe and Latvia. We were the first to notice it in the Baltic States, so in 2015 StratCom was made in Riga. Today, thanks in large part to the Baltic Members, this issue is on Parliament's agenda. Russia is one of the countries that uses this information space actively and efficiently. As long as the Russian authorities do not hide the fact that false news and false information are military tools, there are growing concerns that Russia has been involved in both the US and Brexit referendums. Social networks have become a breeding ground for this information battlefield and the spread of false news. Astronomical funds have been invested in the Russian propaganda machine. The EU has created the EU's Eastern StratCom, which actively and successfully disseminates information about open Russian disinformation campaigns and false news in an attempt to refute Kremlin propaganda. It is therefore necessary to increase the resources and capacity of this center. We also need to think about how to reduce the spread of such information on social networks, what limits to privacy and freedom of expression are allowed here, or whether comments on the internet can be anonymous. We must be prepared to try to influence not only the results of the national elections but also the results of the European elections. I would like to add that the impact of Russian propaganda is also being felt in the European Parliament, as there have been repeated attempts to put issues of interest to Russia on Parliament's agenda.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I consider this debate important because, following our resolution of November 2016, it reflects the recognition that the situation has only worsened since then, disrupting the EU's internal cohesion and Atlantic federal system with a wide range of open provocations, covert threats, false news and sharing attempts. Putin's expansionist policy has now become one of the most dangerous external challenges to the security of the European Union. I welcome the Commission's intention for the Union to help the Member States counterbalance Russian propaganda with significantly more Community resources than before, with modern, concrete action plans. Moscow, with its targeted pseudonyms and many other means of the dirty "hybrid war", attacks the security, values ​​and democratic rule of law of the whole of Europe: it occupies a sovereign country, fights at its borders, provokes EU member states elsewhere, tries to manipulate our internal relations and press. We have found that Putin does not understand the language of common sense and diplomacy, only his strength. Therefore, joint EU action is needed, demonstrating the strength of the democratic community, with differentiated instruments for each Member State, but according to the gravity of the situation. At the same time, as a Hungarian politician, I regret that the weakest link in EU unity is the policy of Hungary, or more precisely the Orbán government: Hungary cannot become Moscow's bridgehead within the EU!

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – As we all know, fighting the influences of Russian propaganda, or any disinformation campaign for that matter, is not exactly straightforward. Since we do not want a ministry of truth, we need a more sophisticated approach. I myself am not susceptible to Russian propaganda, having lived half of my life in the Soviet Union I have no trouble discerning facts from fiction, but there are plenty of impressionable people out there, especially on the internet. Some studies indicate that six out of ten people do not even read the articles that they share and repost on social media. The Geier / Tarand report on the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 decided to create ‘a Strategic Communication Capacity budget item in line with the European Council conclusions of March 2015 and equip the EEAS with adequate staff and tools to face the challenge of disinformation from third states and non-state actors.’ We might indeed need to provide the EEAS East StratCom Task Force with more financial and human resources, but before we do that I would like to see a thorough impact assessment of their work so far, especially considering the complex nature of combating this problem.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Romana Tomc, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative in the Member States (2017/ 2039 (INI)) (A8-0406 / 2017).

name: Romana TOMC
text: Rapporteur. - Of course, I would like to begin by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs and all the colleagues who have contributed to the final version of the report that we have before us today, which we will be voting on tomorrow. I would also like to thank, of course, all the experts who really contributed to making the report good. We had our first meetings a year ago, and in order to see what the experience is also in the field, we also carried out an inquiry mission to Slovenia and Croatia. 224 amendments have been tabled to the report, and I think we have covered all the main findings in them and in the report itself, and highlighted the challenges we will have to face in the future as we continue the Youth Employment Initiative. What is a youth employment initiative anyway? It is a financial program that supports a project launched by the European Commission in 2012. At that time, a commitment was made to provide young Europeans with a quality job offer, further education, within four months of losing their job or completing their education. apprenticeship or traineeship. With the Youth Employment Initiative, with this program, which has € 7.6 billion at its disposal, we will be able to achieve this goal more easily. But the important thing, of course, is that the money is spent effectively and that it covers the most vulnerable groups of young people. However, the available data unfortunately show that only a small proportion of those inactive were covered. Despite some shortcomings, mainly related to the target groups and the measurement and monitoring of results, the final results of the implementation of the initiative proved to be very positive. The most important issue that remains a challenge for the future of this program, however, is the issue of cost-effectiveness. So how money is spent, efficiently or not, and the Court of Auditors has also pointed this out. One of the findings is that Member States use the funds from the initiative as a primary source instead of an additional source, and in fact replace them with those national resources that they would otherwise have to contribute themselves. The monitoring and evaluation process is also very demanding and unfortunately non-uniform, so today we do not have very exact evidence of whether it is good or a little less good efficiency, and of course I also pointed this out in the report. One of the key issues in this report, and also in our debate, was the issue of the quality of job offers. These offers are usually or often very questionable, especially today, when atypical forms of employment predominate, this is a problem. That is why I am glad that we have reached an appropriate compromise on what a quality offer means. Finally, I must add that the measures taken by the initiative have supported more than 1.6 million young people in the European Union. Therefore, we need a secure strategy to transform the initiative into a more stable and sustainable funding instrument beyond 2020. At that time, we will probably face different challenges in the labor market, but it will always, indeed always, be necessary to take care of those in the labor market. , which are our future, that is, for our young people.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms Tomc for her report, which stresses that youth employment is, and remains, a top priority at Union level. Your report, Ms Tomc, comes at the right moment to take stock, four years into the launch of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative. As you know, there are two sides of the coin: the policy and the financial support dedicated to young people not in employment, education or training, the so-called NEETs. Setting up the Youth Guarantee required commitment and political support from Member States, building new partnerships, as well as significant reforms of the labour market, education and training policies. Back in 2014, only a few Member States had fully set up their implementation structures and launched measures to benefit from this dedicated funding. Given their budgetary constraints, many Member States were struggling to ensure sufficient financial liquidity so that measures could take off. Therefore, my first action as a Commissioner was to address this shortage by proposing to release 30% of the Youth Employment Initiative resources directly as advance payments to the Member States.  These efforts are now bearing fruit. Since the launch of the Youth Guarantee, around 11 million young people have received an offer. The Youth Employment Initiative has directly helped at least 1.7 million young people to receive job training or a further education opportunity.  In parallel, we observe a strong decrease in the youth employment rate, from a peak of 24% in January 2013 to 16.2% last November. There are now two million fewer young unemployed in the Union and one million fewer young people who are not in employment, education or training. I believe that the combination of the Youth Guarantee, the Youth Employment Initiative and the European Social Fund (ESF) has contributed to this remarkable improvement. Together, they have created new opportunities for young people and acted as a powerful driver for structural reforms in all Member States. However, I agree with you that our work should not stop here. Youth unemployment is still far too high in many Member States, and the figures diverge, from 5% in the Czech Republic or 6.6% in Germany to around, yes, 39% in Greece, and also, still, more than 30% in Italy and Spain. Inactivity among young people, as well as untapped potential, remains a reality across the Union and, as your report and also the report of the Court of Auditors highlight, not all young people have benefited equally from these initiatives. Let me stress a few aspects that we will further concentrate on. We need to step up efforts to reach out and to support the low-skilled and those with fewer opportunities. We know that young people with disabilities, those with a migration background and young parents with caring responsibilities remain much more at risk of becoming NEETs.  I agree with you that we have to expand the pool of good-quality offers. We need to ensure that they really help young people to get a solid foothold in the labour market. For the second phase of the Youth Employment Initiative’s implementation, until of the end of the current financial framework, we will pay close attention to this quality aspect.  The Commission is already helping Member States to improve the quality of their job and training offers and to design outreach measures. This is the case for the ‘find-bind-mind’ outreach method that certain Member States already use successfully to ensure that the most disadvantaged and vulnerable young people are given special attention and receive the personalised assistance they need. And let us not forget that the ESF can also be used. It can be used as an additional support for an integrated approach to these young people. It can also invest in the reform of services and the setting up of the so-called one-stop-shop approach, offering young people a single contact point for all formalities and assistance provided by several services – social, employment or education. In order to offer policy guidance to Member States and stakeholders, we adopted a proposal for a European framework for quality and effective apprenticeships. We are also working to increase the supply, quality and image of apprenticeships through the European Alliance for Apprenticeships, and we will continue our efforts with the social partners on promoting the implementation of the quality framework for traineeships.  As regards monitoring the Youth Employment Initiative progress, we continue providing guidance on a regular basis and requesting Member States’ feedback on data collection and monitoring. In 2019, we will report to you and to the Council on the main findings of the Member States’ evaluations of the Youth Employment Initiative, which they are currently carrying out. The Commission will also continue to support mutual learning and dissemination of good practices among Member States. Last October, for instance, we organised a Youth Guarantee learning forum that brought together Youth Guarantee policy coordinators from Member States and Youth Employment Initiative managing authorities. The aim was to disseminate good practices, take stock of the lessons learned so far and come up with proposals for the future.  Your draft report confirms that the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative are, and will remain, important instruments for fighting youth unemployment in Europe. As the Court of Auditors pointed out, we need to reach out further to the NEETs far away from the education and labour market, and ensure the quality of the offers provided. The Commission and the Member States are committed to improve further the outcome of these schemes. Finally, let me thank Parliament once again for supporting the increase in the Youth Employment Initiative resources until 2020. This additional EUR 1.2 billion will allow Member States to support around one million more young people until 2020, in the Member States and regions most affected by youth unemployment.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Madam President, I am happy that this debate is coming just a few hours after the presentation of the Bulgarian Presidency and its priorities. One of those priorities is youngsters, and it is good to have youngsters as a priority because we have to fight for each and every one of them. They deserve it. No matter what crisis is going to hit us post-2020, no matter how hard it will be, no matter how impossible it looks, we have to find enough resources to provide ourselves with the tools to fight youth unemployment. And it is not just empty talk. It is obvious that our Youth Employment Initiative is working well and delivering results. For example, in my own country, the country I know best, the youth unemployment rate dropped almost 5% in just few years, and this is how we are going to proceed. So we are obliged! Youngsters deserve our support and the next Multiannual Financial Framework should find enough resources, no matter which country decides to leave this Union, to provide those resources.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Madam President, despite the initial delays in implementing the initiative the youth employment scheme, we believe, has been a huge success. However the Budgetary Control Committee would like to make a few suggestions for the future. We believe that labour market demands and skills training should be better linked together. We also believe there should be a quality offer made to all young people and that there should be a definition of quality; we believe the definition so far is good but it could be improved upon. We also believe there should be more of a focus on the results of the programme. So far example, better indicators and monitoring of permanent contracts given to all young people who are on the programme. In other words we need to make sure that although we are spending this money and we are spending it on good things, we need to make sure this programme in particular is seen as effective. So in short President, we would say the programme has been a huge success but of course there is room for improvement.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Madam President, Mrs Theissen, access to the Youth Guarantee scheme is selective. This shows the evaluation of the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative by the Member States. The data show that the program benefits mainly educated and highly qualified young people. People with disabilities, the less educated and the long-term unemployed remain outside these statistics. In my country, Bulgaria, the situation is similar. The scheme benefits almost entirely young people with secondary and higher education at the expense of the low-skilled. Young people registered with employment offices are rather rare. That is why we need to think about alternative solutions. One of my proposals as a rapporteur for the Committee on Education and Culture is the creation of single information desks. There, young people will be able to receive information about various opportunities for training, internship or work in one place. Every young person, regardless of the economic and social situation in which they find themselves, should have information and access to such programs. Ensuring equal access will be the cornerstone of the success of the initiative.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - The FEMM Committee acknowledges the contribution of the Youth Initiative to reducing youth unemployment and ensuring gender equality, as approximately 48% have taken advantage of the opportunities offered by this initiative. men and 52 percent. women. But at the same time, we still see a lack of gender-disaggregated statistics, so it is important for Member States to collect more accurate data in order to have a more accurate picture of how this initiative contributes to tackling unemployment among young women and men and what could and should be done. The Commission would carry out an appropriate impact assessment. I also call on the Member States to develop new, innovative and more personalized approaches that are both high-quality and sustainable, and that improve young people's chances of returning to the labor market or learning, for example through childcare and adult care. Equally, of course, it is important to support the inclusion of girls and women in all sectors of the economy, and yet, despite the current progress in the Youth Employment Initiative, it is necessary to continue this initiative with additional funding.

name: David CASA
text: the PPE group. - It is intended to provide information and statistics on the quality of natural products, including natural products, natural or other constituents. It is considered important that the present case should be taken as soon as possible and the President of the Republic of Bulgaria should be registered in the same way. The report is intended to address the implications of the Youth Unemployment Initiative, and to implement it in a more comprehensive way. name: Brando BENIFEI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, my sincere thanks to rapporteur Tomc for her work on this dossier. I believe that also thanks to the contribution of the colleagues rapporteurs of the groups we are facing, in the end, an ambitious text, which presents a precise picture of the implementation of this fundamental European program to combat unemployment and youth inactivity, not only because it is analyzed in detail the available data and the impact of the resources deployed to achieve the Youth Guarantee objectives, but also because the elements that require more critical consideration are carefully evaluated, proposing specific recommendations on how to deal with them. I am strongly convinced, in fact, that today a reform of the Youth Guarantee and its financial instrument, the Youth Employment Initiative, is necessary, which knows how to build on the experience accumulated in recent years. The objective of this reform must focus above all on three fronts: firstly, to enhance its range of action, demonstrating to better involve those who need it most, namely the "NEETs", those inactive young people who do not study and do not work, which are on the fringes of the labor market. Secondly, bureaucratic mechanisms must be simplified, allowing greater involvement of businesses and youth and trade union organizations, and enhancing the efficiency of public employment services. Finally, it is necessary to work on the quality of the offers, starting from the elaboration of a definition at European level of quality offer. I have fought, even in dissent from some colleagues, that the definition contains clear and very clear principles, including the mandatory remuneration of traineeships, full access to social services for trainees and respect for rights and rules on I work in complete manner. The ultimate goal of the measures funded by the Youth Employment Initiative must be long-term integration into the labor market and cannot be limited to financing short-term internships which, for example, have been predominant in my country in some regions. It is therefore necessary today to equip oneself with tools to prevent any possible abuse, such as late payments or the violation of contractual conditions and the rights of participants, which damages not only the educational and professional process of the many young beneficiaries but also the reputation of the Union. European Union in its action to combat youth unemployment. For this reason, I have proposed that a European Union hotline against the violation of the rights of young people be set up, allowing them to communicate directly to the Commission any negative experience during their participation in the program, allowing the investigation of possible abusive practices in the use of EU-funded policies. A key element in the discussion concerns the funds to be allocated after 2020. I strongly believe that the Youth Employment Initiative must change from an extraordinary anti-crisis instrument to a permanent mechanism, which finances the Youth Guarantee in the years to come. Discussions on the new multiannual financial framework will start shortly: the European Parliament will have to fight to ensure that this program remains an absolute priority for Union action. The future of young people is the future of Europe, we must not forget that.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group. - Madam President, let me briefly explain my position on today's report. First of all, I would like to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Mrs Tomc. From the beginning, our cooperation included thorough consultations and an open approach. I also thank all the other colleagues who have worked on this topic. I agree with many of the suggestions in the text of the report. I agree that we need a better exchange of comparable data and a more active approach to more vulnerable young people or young people outside larger cities. It is important to me that the report warns against the risk that European Union funds may - and sometimes tend to - replace national funds. However, the initiative should be the engine of reforms. It must not replace the Member States' own policies and ideas. That is why I am very careful to agree on a future commitment in the form of a proposal for an initiative as a long-term instrument of the European Union before clearly clearing out all the shortcomings that the Court of Auditors has pointed out, for example.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: for the ALDE Group. - Thank you, in particular, to the rapporteur, Mrs Tomcová, for her efforts and time in this report. I really appreciate her efforts. We can talk about the Youth Employment Initiative in many beautiful words and argue with numbers and statistics. But for me, the main goal is quite simple, we have to teach young people to work. Work is normal. This is my message to the school leavers to whom the initiative is addressed. Although the programs funded by this initiative do not replace working hours, they make a lot of sense. I welcome the efforts to transform the initiative into a more permanent financial instrument to tackle unemployment beyond 2020. Negotiations within the multiannual financial framework will ensure the necessary continuity with the program. Member States should make full use not only of the opportunities of the initiative, but also invest themselves in promoting job mobility, the potential of which remains untapped. The EU's workforce is around 243 million people, but only 8.5 million of them work abroad in Europe. At the same time, young people are the ones who are most willing to move for work. Let's support them! After all, we already know well from fairy tales that success and happiness were only waiting for Honza, who went out into the world to experience it. I also see a problem in the fact that our companies cannot rely on a functioning education system that would equip young graduates with skills that meet the needs of the labor market. So let's connect successful companies and educational institutions with young people who are actively looking after their future. Only in this way can we help to address the skills gap, which is one of the main causes of high youth unemployment rates. Let us join forces in our own countries, let us communicate with the national authorities, which can do the most to make better use of the initiative. We should not ignore the given hand, but press it firmly. So let's teach young people that going to work, gaining experience and learning new things is great. The reward may not be a princess and a half-kingdom, but a functioning economy is also not to be thrown away.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the figures that this report reveals on the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative are a slap on the wrist for the European Commission, because what at first seemed like a good idea to combat youth unemployment, has ended up highlighting serious problems in its design, financing and implementation. Such as the problems when mobilizing funds, because they did not reach the countries that most needed them, the problems in the design of the programs themselves and, as a culmination, the fact that the little data we have tells us that this policy is not being effective. And it must be said that it is a shame that Spain, having received 1 billion euros, hardly provides data on where it has applied the funds. The Youth Employment Initiative should serve so that young people could make a correct transition to the labor market and, however, we have seen how under this Initiative there are cases of exploitation, replacement of permanent workers, contingency and precariousness. Ladies and gentlemen, the problem of young people is not the lack of employability, and those who speak of NEETs in this House today I believe that they have not understood this and that, in fact, they do not understand what the solutions are for the future of our society. We believe that if this report is approved, it will force the Commission and the Member States to react to meet the social objectives for 2020, because, for the moment, the Youth Guarantee in countries like mine has a resounding suspense.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, young people in Europe count on us, and it is true what some of the colleagues have mentioned: that the numbers have slightly decreased. But we cannot deny that youth unemployment is still a massive problem within the European Union, and we cannot let one more day pass in which we do not put all our efforts into fighting against this, because it is one of the crucial questions about whether we have a future in a united Europe or not. Yes, the Youth Employment Initiative has been presented as the answer, or at least partly the solution to this big problem of youth unemployment, and young people all over Europe have put their hopes into this initiative. It is true that some of them have been satisfied; their expectations have been met. But we must also say that many young people have been disappointed, and that there is a big gap in implementation and the success of implementation in different Member States. We have Member States where the numbers have gone down and we have Member States where the numbers have not gone down, and where I believe the wrong proposals have been made in order to fight against youth unemployment. One of the crucial questions is whether Member States have actually provided high-quality sustainable offers to young people, because the Youth Employment Initiative is not about giving something to do to young people who don’t know what to do with their time. It is about giving perspectives to young people; quality and sustainable offers so that they can enter the labour market. I believe that if we want these quality offers to be meaningful, they should, for example, also be remunerated. That is why it is important for the report to very clearly state that we need quality offers and why we should have a definition at European level as to what these quality offers mean. Lastly, I think as the European Parliament we can take a very concrete measure in order to show how sincere and how clear we are in our demands to fight youth unemployment, and that is to finally implement fair internships and to treat the interns here in this House fairly and to remunerate the internships that are being done in this House.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, deciding what to do with the Youth Employment Initiative means choosing whether to be a country up to the problems it has or to continue living at the mercy of a national and local politics that is a victim of itself , victim of bad management imprisoned by clientelist logic, small interests to defend and nourish as possible. Youth Guarantee is not the solution to youth unemployment, it is not the panacea to stem the brain drain from our country to places that recognize and appreciate its potential, but it can be a support for a new policy to enhance our wealth, because the young people are the wealth of our country. Our work on this document was proactive, because we need an assiduous and constant monitoring of the use of resources, we need a capillary work in the territories to understand the needs of the productive fabric, becoming able to give concrete and effective solutions. Training must be specific for professional figures, respect for working conditions cannot fail and the abuse of this tool must be countered by any means for the benefit of undeclared employment. You need vision, transparency and consistency, you need strategy and you need to live up to the needs of citizens to make the most of every minimum resource. Every single euro wasted running after patronage will show that we are not up to the role we, as co-legislators, have.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, any device intended to come to the aid of employment, except in very specific cases, is proof of the failure of national and, in this case, European policies in this area. This is all the more true since the last economic crisis took place more than ten years ago. It is therefore an assistantship from public funds intended also to alleviate the difficulties of private entrepreneurs in their search for qualified employees. In this specific case, however, the mechanism of the Youth Employment Initiative deserves a closer look. Indeed, if on the financial and budgetary level, one must be very circumspect, as recommended by the report of the Court of Auditors, and if its approach from doctrinal angles such as equality between men and women may seem excessive, its implementation allows us to conclude that there is a need to continue further. Our group and I were able to verify this on the ground, both in France and abroad, thanks to the rapporteur, Ms. Tomc. The conditions necessary for its implementation are better controlled and better managed financing which does not replace national funds and which benefits from regular quality evaluation. This device must especially not become definitive. On the positive side, it must make useful use of European funds to support our most precarious young people in their learning and employment, and it can prevent the drain of talent from their country. Very attentive and positively critical, we will support this implementation report.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - How many more times do we have to discuss youth unemployment in this Chamber without having managed to improve the situation even in the slightest? The report itself acknowledges that the austerity measures imposed by the European Union in the various Member States have had the direct effect of dramatically increasing youth unemployment. What the report does not acknowledge is that the action taken by the Union to reduce unemployment had zero effect. The relative decline in unemployment observed in recent years is nothing more than flexible forms of employment and shift work, which have become the norm in most Member States with all that entails, ie temporary jobs paid by starvation wages and minimal rights for employees. Let us not forget that the Commission, through the troika, has forced Greece to introduce, as a fiscal reform, a separate lower basic salary for young workers. And then we talk about protecting young people, while most leave the country in search of work abroad. Our requirement: stable jobs with a decent salary, full insurance coverage and protection of workers' rights.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: - (NL) Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, we all know. It is the youth, my generation, who have paid the highest price for the crisis. She was and rightly is a top priority of this legislature. Europe has really tried to make a success of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative and it paid off. Also in my country. Youth unemployment in Brussels, for example, fell for the 55th time in a row. Yet youth unemployment remains far too high at 24%. How did that happen? The economy is heading towards cruising speed. Employers are looking for the right talents and my government is also juggling with figures about great job creation. However, the problem lies with the mismatch. However good our intentions are, the real target group - the unemployed young people who are not in training - is still not being reached enough. That is why I support the call to Member States for more data and more results-oriented work. Show us where the money is going and deliver quality too. Every -24-year-old deserves the chance to get a real, decent job and I am glad that the Commission will soon be able to monitor this too. Colleagues, the debate about the multi-year budget for the period after 2020 is already about savings. Well, I am telling you clearly: do not let young people be a savings item. On the contrary, more resources will be needed, for example for youth employment, Erasmus + and other programs. We have a compass in our hands with the European social pillar. Let's put that compass to good use towards the future, towards the youth. Thank you.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – Madam President, some years ago a number of adults – or should I say people pretending to be adults – created a global financial crisis because of their greed and immaturity. The crisis turned into an economic crisis which affected millions of young people. They had no part in causing it, yet the effects will affect their lives profoundly. This is why I think it is no more than normal that the EU Member States have together committed themselves to protecting young people through the Youth Guarantee. It is not an issue of charity, but one of decency. Luckily unemployment is decreasing now – and I am very glad that it is – but youth unemployment in Member States, such as Greece, Spain and Italy, which have already been mentioned by the Commissioner, are still shocking, so we are not there yet. We owe it to young people to keep assisting them. Firstly, we have to insist that jobs and traineeships made possible throughout our initiative hit the spot. This initiative should not only guarantee the development of skills among young people and ensure their integration on the labour market, because it is not only for jobs – the initiative is for life. I want to remind Member States that it is not about lip service, but the future of their young people.  Secondly, I think the Youth Employment Initiative needs to be transformed from an anti—crisis instrument into a more stable financing instrument for tackling youth unemployment. We need not only to maintain the initiative after 2020, but we need to increase the funding. May I remind you that the ILO fund, which guarantees young people a job or training, costs EUR 45 million, whereas the current initiative has only EUR 9 million to spend.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Of course, it is important to get young people in particular into work. But is the employment initiative the way to go? I'm afraid not. The program has not turned the trend, particularly in southern Europe. Take Spain, for example: this is where most of the money, namely 943 million, went to this initiative. Spain still has a youth unemployment rate of 40%. Overall, however, the labor market in Spain is more of a positive example. Spain’s total unemployment has decreased significantly. In summary: Although Spain is very successful overall and gets most of the money for the youth initiative, the decline in unemployment among young people is particularly low. This very poor result for Spain is also confirmed by the Commission's own analysis. Conclusion: the program doesn't work. The European Court of Auditors also confirms that the efficiency of the funds used is highly questionable. Therefore it should not be increased any further here.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, youth unemployment in Europe is a scandal and it is in an attempt to respond to this evil, to this scourge, that our Heads of State or Government in 2013 devised the Youth Employment Initiative, leaving it to Member States to implement the appropriate arrangements. If real progress has been observed, let us agree that the evaluation is proving delicate. In many cases, it is a matter of being in a hurry, depending on the urgency of local situations. Commissioner, we need structural measures and I take the liberty of emphasizing vocational training, which is a real investment in the future. Take the example of countries with a tradition of apprenticeship: Germany, the Netherlands, Austria, or Denmark. These countries have virtually no youth unemployment, and therefore I hope that, on the basis of these good practices, we can develop, Commissioner, a specific program for vocational training and apprenticeship.
