I pay tribute to your initiative, since at the beginning of October you put on the table, for the attention of governments and the Council, a unique framework of what could be, in Europe, an effective learning and quality. I therefore hope that there will be a vocational training and apprenticeship program, with a view to the next multiannual financial framework. I also hope that, for more efficiency, there is a real mission of professional training and learning within the services of the Commission so as to better coordinate the interventions of your Directorate-General, but also of the Culture and Education Directorate, for Erasmus grants, and also of the REGIO Directorate General, since it is a question of mobilizing regional development funds and the European Social Fund. I think that, taking this path, the European Union will speak to Europeans;this is obviously a way of the future.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Let me first congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on their work on this report. It contains, in our view, positive elements such as, firstly, the recognition that austerity measures promoted by Union policies are dramatically increasing youth unemployment, criticism of Member States that have not promoted youth employment, and , of course, it is important, the introduction of the definition of decent employment of the ILO. As a group of the United Left, we have serious reservations about the youth employment initiative, as there are no concrete steps to solve the structural problems of unemployment. The promotion of youth migration needs to be stopped immediately, as well as internships as a means of getting young people into work. Instead, what the Union needs is public investment that will create decent jobs, with all employment rights guaranteed for young people and those entering the labor market for the first time. They just need public investment in the real economy.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the European Youth Employment Initiative is a very important instrument, but we have a problem of implementation in many Member States. Particularly bloody, for example, is the Spanish case, as Spain is at the moment the second country with the most youth unemployment in the European Union, 37%, which is more than double the youth unemployment rate of the Union average. In this case, for example, it is not acceptable for most of the resources of the youth guarantee to be allocated to a bonus system that only means lightening the social security contributions for employers. There are no programs to create jobs or to reduce precariousness in the labor market, the most important needs that young people have when they want to work. The results are working worse than in the rest of the European Union, since the youth employment rate grows much less in Spain. In practice, the Youth Guarantee is being used, in this case, for programs that pay less wages or do not recognize the employment relationship as such. Only 30% of the program offers are for employment, compared to 70% in the EU-28, so, far from being a program that helps to have quality work, in this case it becomes a mere subsidy to the businessmen, who are precarious. For this reason, we also ask that the rest of the House support the amendment presented by our group and the S & amp; D, which asks to improve the definition of what is quality offer, so that it responds to the needs of young people who are in this program. Therefore, Commissioner, it is very important to go ahead with the program, but above all it is very important that you ensure that your application is done correctly.

name: Nathan GILL
text: – Madam President, we have heard in this debate that youth unemployment in the EU ranges from 5% in the north to almost 40% in Greece. I also heard claims that this initiative has been – and I am going to quote – ‘hugely successful’. If using billions of taxpayers’ euros to train youth was hugely successful, why do we still see youth unemployment rates of 40% in Greece? If this scheme is so great, use it to eradicate unemployment in southern Europe. Funding training is admirable, but it does not help skilled youth find worthy employment when there are no jobs. High taxation, red tape and restrictive employment laws are a barrier to small and medium—sized businesses taking on more staff. If you want to help our youth, promote freedom for our SMEs to run their businesses the way that they see fit with access to funds for investment and growth. Surely the goal must be job creation.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: - Madam President, the facts are known: the unemployment rate is high in many countries in Europe and young people are seriously affected. The causes are also known: the 2008 crisis, to which are added the austerity policies and the scarcity of jobs requiring few qualifications, which make the phenomenon sustainable. In 2013, the European Union finally realized the need for action. The youth employment initiative having been ineffective so far, it is therefore necessary to extend it until 2020, as well as to extend it to 25-30 year-olds since those who have entered the labor market without finding a permanent job in 2008 are now in this age group. Rightly so, the report is particularly concerned with young people who are neither in work nor in education. It is necessary to promote their integration through apprenticeship, work-study or training. It is now urgent, since we risk mortgaging the future of those whom sociologists already call "sacrificed generations".

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - The surge in youth unemployment, the exacerbation of its general increase, worries you. Not to solve the problem: neither you want, nor you can, but to curb the indignation of millions of young people, their rejection in your system, but also blackmailed by unemployment to hand them over as slaves to capital, in any job, industry, or country they need them. You call it labor mobility, while it is migration and uprooting that eats Greece as well. Temporary, flexible, low-paid employment subsidized by European programs only benefits businesses. It turns young people into lifelong trainees, underpaid apprentices below the basic salary, more or less unemployed. Even the training you rely on it. The investments you cite as a solution require this. Cheap staff, blackmailed by unemployment and insecurity. This is your vision for the future of work, the European social pillar! It is a nightmare and barbarism. That is all that capitalism has to offer. Young people must fight for its overthrow, for perspective and future.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, first I would like to remind you that the Youth Employment Initiative was born as an emergency instrument in the face of a critical situation that affected millions of young people throughout the European Union and thanks to which 1.6 million of the most affected regions. Specifically in my country, in Spain, youth unemployment has dropped by more than 20% in the last four years. The employability rate — also in my country — of young people enrolled in the Youth Guarantee system is 41%. I think these data are positive and we are moving in the right direction. Undoubtedly, there is a long way to go and, above all, to incorporate young people with the most difficulties in the labor market, such as NEETs, long-term unemployed young people, young people with disabilities and those belonging to ethnic minorities. For this reason, and in order to decisively support youth employment, we must turn this Initiative into a stable instrument. And with regard to its application and to assess its effectiveness, we have to take into account several issues. First, that NEETs are a very diverse group, with different needs and levels of training and that they need a personalized approach, and then, also, that the Youth Guarantee has served to tackle profound structural reforms in the Member States, reforms carried out in a adverse economic context, especially in the beneficiary countries, since they started from a higher youth unemployment.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! The aim of this initiative is to reach the young people who are furthest from the labor market: young people who have neither jobs nor education. We are now beginning to see that this initiative has had positive results. That is also the reason why there was a budget increase last year. But that increase only applies until 2020, and that is also the reason why we are having this debate today. We must therefore make decisions about choices. My firm view is that we must first and foremost ensure that the Member States invest more than they do today in getting young people into work. They have to make the priorities. According to both the ILO and Eurofound, it takes between 45 billion and 50 billion euros per year to achieve the goal of the program. It can be compared with the fact that there is only 8.8 billion in the EU budget, if I remember correctly, for the program between 2014 and 2020. The Member States must therefore also put the money on the table. There are big differences between the Member States, we know that very well. We know that the support from the employment initiative has been absolutely necessary for them to be able to develop their own youth guarantees. We must, of course, continue to be there, but it must be the case that the Member States also make the priorities necessary for them to keep some young people in their Member States and for them to have young people who can handle difficult tasks and who are willing to give get into it. The economic crisis has also meant a waste of time for many young people, so it is important that the youth guarantees are qualitative, that they do not mean another loss of time. To achieve this, the young people themselves must be involved in the design and evaluation of the youth guarantee. It is no longer possible to dodge, because that is actually what some Member States do, so everyone on board! That is what is required.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Madam President! Youth unemployment is a very serious, multi-dimensional problem. On the one hand - the threat of isolation, social alienation, and even pathologization of these young people, and on the other hand - the unused potential of young human capital. Importantly, the current generation must realize that today's potential young workers will face a double burden resulting from demographic change and the need to ensure the sustainability of pension systems. Therefore, working for young people is a condition for a better future for a generation. However, we have many comments on the report. First, there is a need to leave more flexibility for Member States in managing the allocation. It is necessary to simplify and reduce bureaucratic burdens and standardize monitoring rules, introduce the obligation to report actual indicators of results - such as starting a job, learning or obtaining qualifications, and not only receiving a job or training offer - provide genuine support for NEET youth, it is necessary to reward the participation of young people with disabilities and counteract their discrimination, conduct concrete cooperation with youth organizations.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, according to Eurobarometer, half of young Europeans feel excluded and marginalized from any meaningful participation in social and economic life. And this is not corrected only with economic contributions from the European Union through the Youth Employment Initiative or the Youth Guarantee, and more so when the Member States have misused these funds, as the Court of Auditors itself has denounced. Paying the social security contributions of companies, as in Spain, has only served to increase precariousness in the scarce employment generated. Or we take advantage of these economic resources to make structural changes that truly generate quality jobs, that bet on another productive model, that guarantee active employment policies with training itineraries; or we end once and for all with those scholarships that only serve to generate greater precariousness; In short, we guarantee that stable employment and public employment services or, if not, next year we will be here again with large numbers and headlines and with a greater disaffection of our young people.

name: André ELISSEN
text: - Today we discuss the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative. The European Union has imposed an obligation on Member States to offer a job, continuing education, apprenticeship or traineeship within a period of four months. An unrealistic ambition, where everyone knows in advance that such a thing is not feasible. The interference and waste of money from the EU once again knows no boundaries. Once again, the effects of the multi-billion investment cannot be measured. The objectives are not achieved and they cover themselves in advance. And what is the solution of the unworldly European elite? Even more money, of course. The taxpayer is paying for these absurd, unworkable plans. The report goes no further than kicking open doors and enumerating vague generalities. The only way to really tackle youth unemployment is customization at the national level. In short, sovereignty and power back to the member states.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Madam President, the Youth Employment Initiative is based on a tripod consisting of job offers, training and internships. And in my region, as in many Member States, this tripod is unbalanced, because we are investing much more in training and internships than we are investing in job offers. And therefore, we are not contributing to the fight against precariousness. We have a second problem with one of the legs of the tripod, which is precisely that of the formation. Our young people are being thrown into continuous training cycles, completely inadequate training, training that is completely inconsequential, when we have to guarantee the opposite. We have to ensure that our young people have individualized support, in multidisciplinary teams, made up of technicians, psychologists, and specialized sociologists, to ensure that the training offer is appropriate both to the trainee's characteristics and to the needs of the companies. Finally, internships cannot mask employment contracts or replace job contracts. And, therefore, it is necessary to ensure an adequate definition of the functional content and the responsibility of the trainee, who must be accompanied by a monitor who supports him and gives him training. More inspection is needed, with adequate inspection means. More transparency and a qualitative assessment of the program in terms of results are needed. Finally, the Youth Employment Initiative must be consistent. This implies greater social mobility and that we reduce social inequalities in the European Union.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, the crisis ended up robbing the expectations and hopes of an entire generation in Europe and also ended up breaking one of those invisible pacts on which our society is sustained and structured: the pact between generations. For all these reasons, it has been four years since we started our work from the European level with the Youth Employment Initiative. Four years that also give us to be able to value and claim what we have done during all this time. Claim that it is necessary for the European Union to continue working, to make this program a permanent program, that we look at the 2020 horizon and our financial perspectives with a clear vocation to continue working in this regard. But at the same time with the will to reform, because it is necessary that this money go to structural changes in our active employment policies, to comprehensive labor integration programs, with quality jobs and quality training, and that we do not hide our labor problems under the carpet of precariousness or temporality.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: - I would like to thank the rapporteur for this balanced report. However, it is not a good idea to make the Youth Employment Initiative a permanent EU funding instrument. After all, the causes of youth unemployment vary widely in the different Member States. A uniform approach is therefore impossible. It is more sensible to motivate the member states and regions to adopt structural policies tailored to their own labor market. But this initiative achieves just the opposite. It removes the incentives for the regions concerned to change course. After all, large-scale EU funding hides the structural problems that underlie youth unemployment. By the way, I see a clear example of this in Belgium. Wallonia and the Brussels Region receive funding from the Youth Employment Initiative. Subsequently, these young people disappear into training programs and unemployment statistics and these regions can present a good news show. I regret that, in this way, these regions are not obliged to implement much-needed structural reforms. For example, the youth initiative is only an expensive cloth for bleeding. Waste of money!

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, given the disproportionate impact of austerity and recession on youth, it is essential that this Youth Employment Initiative is properly implemented. I welcome that this report highlights both the positive and the negative aspects of the implementation of the scheme so far. While much is to be said for the positive impact of the initiative – helping to fight against social exclusion, poverty and emigration among the youngest sectors of society – there are significant concerns that the full potential of the scheme is not being realised. Inappropriate usage of funds and Member States using it to replace funding from national governments has resulted in the waste of possibly life-changing funds for young men and women throughout the EU. Some Member States including my own, Ireland, excluded single parents and young people with disabilities from the initiative. We must also ensure that there is proper engagement with trade unions to ensure that young people are not being exploited in the jobs and the training that they are being offered and that those internships are not just displacing real jobs.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: - Madam President, the world has moved from the industrial age to the post-industrial age. Increasingly, the supply of jobs is growing in the service sphere, while in the classical spheres of industry or agriculture, the supply of jobs is declining dramatically. I appreciate this report which discusses the initiative on youth employment in the European Union. We need a strong and dynamic segment that means, in fact, our future, the future of the European Union. I strongly believe that the Union as a whole will not be able to compete with the United States or China if it is not able to provide young people with the conditions to be able to fulfill their energy and creativity. Europe's youth is surrounded by elements of a multimillennial culture. These elements are a cultural background, but also an urge to develop specific patterns. In this context, I would like the youth employment initiatives to be as closely linked to the elements of culture and tradition as possible. This is all the more possible as we enter an era of the creative industries. Europe is unity, but it is also diversity. This idea must be carried forward by our young people.

name: Thomas MANN
text: - Madam President! Five years ago, the council - largely influenced by Angela Merkel - agreed on the youth employment initiative. We have campaigned in the European Parliament for sufficient funding for the Youth Guarantee, for jobs, further training, training and internships. The program works! Youth unemployment in the EU-28 has fallen sharply to an average of 16.2% instead of 24% - Marianne Thyssen pointed this out. It is finally declining even in Greece, Spain and Italy - albeit still too low, we all know that. We have increased the funds by 2.4 billion euros to 8.8 billion euros by 2020 - concrete words, yes, but above all concrete actions. However, there are concerns in some parts of the report. Employers should be obliged to offer high-quality internships. I am in favor of demand, but not for coercion, this is not an instrument of the social market economy. Or round tables with all stakeholders to assess the implementation of the strategies on site - that is difficult to realize. A hotline for violating young people's rights is very populist, so we have to go even further. I am counting on the effectiveness of measures and have recommended that my EPP Group approve the overall very good report by Romana Tomc. We must do everything we can to ensure that young people who are of good will are not left to work alone.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Madam President, paragraphs 34 and 43 of this report rightly treat the need to support apprenticeships in tackling youth unemployment. Yet this week in the UK we see 1 400 apprentices thrown into absolute turmoil by the collapse under the Tory government of the Carillion construction firm. Nobody is telling them anything or giving them any support whatsoever about whether they will have apprenticeships next week or the week after or will be joining the back of the queue, despite their best efforts to get on. One bricklaying apprentice in Birmingham said: ‘yesterday we saw people leaving, the man in charge of stock just left, he was the first to go. Then, we saw people high up in the office with their bags packed leaving. I saw another man going, and more people just with their bags packed going’. That is not support for apprenticeships, that is a disgrace and this Tory government needs to look to itself and start looking after people.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: - Madam President, the Youth Employment Initiative reaffirms that nothing is more lasting than a temporary government measure. Just like the temporary euro or the temporary redemption of bonds, this initiative was to be only temporary. But as you can see, it is a complete illusion to think that European bureaucrats will give up the redistribution of money. Youth unemployment is undoubtedly a major problem in several Member States, but it must be tackled by the Member States. It is a classic agenda falling within their competencies. We do not need European coordination here, quite the contrary. We need a competition for the best concepts. In addition, we will not solve the problem of youth unemployment with subsidies. The real and honest solution is to remove barriers to business, reduce the workload and reduce red tape. With another billion in subsidies, we are only reducing the pressure on Member States to embark on bold reforms, and we are ultimately preserving the status quo.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President! First of all, I congratulate Roman Tomc on this very good, important report. We speak of the Youth Initiative, the EU's financial instrument aimed at those countries and regions where youth unemployment exceeds 25%. In particular, we talk about targeting NEETs: young people who do not work, study, train or participate in any internships. We have 7.5 million of them in Europe. Some of them have the status of unemployed (looking for a job), but about 40% are economically inactive. They do not undertake any activity to change their status, so we can expect that their situation will be similar tomorrow, the day after tomorrow or next year. How destructive such an experience is for the individual person and for society as a whole does not need to be explained in this House. Therefore, we should focus on solutions and recognize that the majority of NEETs are women. The risk of women ending up in the NEET group increases with age. The greatest predominance of women is in the 30-34 age group, i.e. when the EU programs aimed at young people can no longer help them. Commissioner! EU programs need to be better targeted as women are among the most vulnerable young people. Specific projects in the Member States should be programmed and assessed by gender. This requires not only the collection and analysis of statistics broken down by gender, but a clear change in the goals and content of the Youth Initiative funded programs.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I have been working in the field of youth policies for as long as I know myself, and I am therefore a strong supporter of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative. Following a mission to Slovenia and Croatia, but also to many other examples of good practice in the European Union, I would like to encourage all Member States, the European Commission and colleagues in Parliament to fight for the following: First, the definition of clear on what a quality offer means for these young people, including: customized learning programs, working conditions, social protection and quality remuneration. Secondly, the initiative is intended to complement other measures taken at Member State level, so I encourage Member States to make a more ambitious commitment, both financially and in terms of developing quality programs. and, above all, sustainable. I also hope that this initiative will receive appropriate funding in the post-2020 multiannual financial framework. Europe cannot afford to lose this young generation with so much potential.

name: Anne SANDER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, after three years of activity, it is time to give the Youth Employment Initiative a health check. It is clear that this fund is doing well and has come a long way since the boost offered by our assembly by releasing an additional billion euros to help young people in the most disadvantaged regions. Of European funds, he is the best student today. However, this is not the time for bliss. Yes, the youth unemployment rate has fallen, but it is still too high and a number of states are lagging behind in the use of funds. Now is the time for good New Year's resolutions, I would like to formulate three here. They are essential to boost the strike force of the Youth Employment Initiative. This help must first go to those who need it most, to these young people isolated because they are not registered with the employment services, because they have little or no skills or because they are far from major urban centers. This aid must then attract quality offers. They must be an added value on a CV and a passport to get a job immediately. In this sense, more emphasis should be placed on learning experiences that directly train for a trade and on experiences abroad. Finally, this European aid must be made safe; it must at all costs be one of the priorities of the next budgetary programming.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Europe can and must afford more active labor market policies. The employment initiative was a good start and the Youth Guarantee needs to be expanded. The labor market figures point in the right direction: Unemployment is falling. But the numbers don't tell the whole truth. Core problems are hidden that have not been resolved: the continued poor wage development and almost exploding employment in the atypical sector. It is therefore important that the Youth Guarantee focuses on quality, quality training and work. We want to achieve this in three steps. Firstly, programs funded by the EU, such as the Youth Guarantee, must meet quality standards - including fair working conditions, social security and fair wages. These points need to be defined more clearly. We see that where social partners are involved, the quality is mostly right. Second, we call for the social partners to be more closely involved in regional projects. Too often young people are exploited and abused as cheap labor. Thirdly, we need a Europe-wide ban on unpaid internships. We want young people to have fond memories of Europe when they think about starting their careers.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: - The first debate that I was allowed to have as a Member of Parliament in July 2014 was on the same subject. At the start of this parliamentary term, we then called for youth unemployment to be an absolute priority. Looking back over the past three and a half years, I think we have succeeded, in particular thanks to the strong cooperation between Parliament and Commissioner Thyssen. 132 measures have been adopted in the Member States, 1.6 million young people have taken advantage of them and youth unemployment in the EU has fallen sharply. And yet I have a bit of an ambiguous feeling about it. Because it is nice that we have been able to help so many young people. But at the same time it remains sad that this was necessary and still is. Because we still see alarmingly high youth unemployment in many European countries. So more needs to be done, in the first place in the Member States themselves. Structural reforms, better use of available funds and a better match between supply and demand in the labor market are absolutely necessary and can also be encouraged from Europe. Many issues have already been mentioned, but let me mention one more specific theme: if we want to give youth a future in Europe, we must not only want to look beyond borders, but also be able to look. I think one of the important things is: attention to neighborhood language education. Member States must insist from a very early age that students learn the language of their neighboring countries. We are going to pay attention to that in the resolution tomorrow and I ask the Commission to follow suit. In a beautiful border province like my own Limburg, enclosed between Germany and Belgium, that is absolutely crucial.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the Youth Guarantee has offered an opportunity for integration to thousands of young people across Europe who were expelled or excluded from the labor market by the economic crisis. And, in this sense, we must insist that we have to decisively continue with this program and, above all, provide it with greater budgetary resources to be able to serve all young people. But we cannot be complacent, and my country certainly has no reason to do so. And we have to try to improve the program. In this report we point out many problems with the Youth Employment Initiative, and I would like to highlight two fundamentally. First, we need it to reach more young people, especially those between the ages of 25 and 30, because they are the ones with the greatest urgency for emancipation and, therefore, the ones who most urgently need a job with decent conditions and sufficient wages. . And we also need those job and training offers that are financed with this Youth Guarantee to be useful and of quality. Because this is precisely the weakest point, and that is why we have tabled an amendment. Let's be clear. Offering young people inadequate and low-quality training only causes the young person to waste their time and we waste public money. Offering them a low- or low-skilled job for which they are often overqualified takes them even further away from a true chance of getting a decent job. So let's keep working to improve this program and offer a future to our youth.

name: Marek PLURA
text: - Commissioner! I sincerely congratulate Roman Tomc on her thorough report and thoughtful recommendations. I believe that it is necessary to remove the barriers to the access of young disabled people to the Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee. The point is both to ensure the availability of training and internships by rational adaptation of workplaces, studies, teaching materials, etc. to the type of disability, and to disseminate information about these initiatives in formats accessible, for example, to blind or deaf people. In addition, Member States should review their case-law and benefit systems. It is worth limiting the adjudication of incapacity to work in a system that prevents registration with employment offices and thus prevents participation in the Youth Employment Initiative. We also limit the situations in which undertaking an internship or starting work is associated with the risk of immediate loss of benefits. Taking up a job is of colossal importance for every young person. For a disabled person, employment is additionally a ticket to normality. Europe needs its youth, its commitment and talents, it also needs the talents and commitment of young people with disabilities.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: - Mr President, we did not put youth unemployment on the European agenda in vain. Let's hope the worst is over. In five years, youth unemployment has fallen from 24 percent to 16 percent. Of the EU's instruments, the Youth Guarantee, the Youth Employment Initiative and the European Social Fund have together helped to eradicate youth unemployment. In my own country, Finland, too, the Social Fund has been financing a one-stop service for young people, the Cabin operation. For the forthcoming programming period, we still need to take action to eradicate youth unemployment. In particular, action is needed for people with disabilities, early school leavers, migrants or otherwise vulnerable young people at risk of exclusion. I would like to leave three healthy ones as we go to develop the future. The funds must be used efficiently, the traineeship, work or training must be of high quality and the work must be remunerated. That quality means that these activities lead to postgraduate studies or a permanent job. In addition, thirdly, getting information and guidance is a very important part. Young people themselves should be listened to at the planning stage.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - It has already been mentioned here that statistics today show a decline in unemployment, including among young people. I am convinced that Youth guarantee has really helped young people in critical situations in certain areas. It was the years 2013, 2014, 2015. The fact that in some countries this European money did not help enough is a lot of a matter for those nation-states that may not have been active enough and did not create the necessary conditions. Therefore, it is necessary to see critically how the program is implemented. We urgently need data to be able to evaluate well where the strengths and weaknesses are. The Member States must also help us here. But data collection is not the only thing where there is a weakness. We need to improve the registration system, also to improve young people's awareness, so that this program really goes there, to those regions, among those young people who need it most. I agree with the proposal to make this program more adaptable for disabled people as well as young parents. I think this is an excellent and important proposal. On the contrary, I do not agree with the increased bureaucracy, which would be, for example, an offer, resp. definition of quality supply. Namely, uniform implementation does not necessarily mean more efficient implementation at all. The decisive factor is the Office's individual approach to young people in need, taking into account national and regional specificities. In other words, this program needs a fundamental reform.

name: Eva KAILI
text: - The "Youth employment Initiative", this initiative of apprenticeship and job creation, is an excellent effort and a powerful tool to combat youth unemployment and especially in countries like Greece. In fact, it is a testament to where Europe looks. But there was also an unpleasant surprise, which we found especially in Greece, that instead of taking advantage of it in opening opportunities with the prospect of vocational rehabilitation then, the program seemed to apply mainly in the public sector, ie in jobs that have no hope or prospect of continuing employment. In response to the Commission, it was found that there is no information on where our young people learn, so there is no information on the quality of jobs, nor on the number of participants in the private or public sector. We hope that the amount provided, especially in countries with high unemployment rates and especially to young people, will increase, but it is important that this program is expanded and made more ambitious and targeted, with a better balance between supply, demand and skills to Let our young people feel that living in Europe their future is in good hands.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Madam President! I believe that combating youth unemployment should remain one of the top priorities of the European Union and the Member States, which is why I supported the Youth Employment Initiative from the outset as a new instrument dedicated to this - unfortunately still persistent - problem. I am glad that the Commission has decided to increase the Initiative's budget, and I hope that funds for this purpose will be available - if necessary - also in the next financial perspective. However, I would like to point out that in order for the instrument to increase its effectiveness, more attention should be paid to adjusting the offer to the qualifications of unemployed youth in such a way as to also take into account the needs of employers and fill vacancies. More than one third of employers report a shortage of labor. It is the imbalance between skills supply and demand that is more than the consequences of the financial crisis responsible for the persistence of youth unemployment. The offer of suitable training courses and professional internships, among other things, can significantly contribute to solving this problem. In addition, greater emphasis should be placed on monitoring and communicating the effects so that Member States can benefit from the exchange of good practices and systematically improve their offer.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, as stated in the report, although we came a long way from the alarming height of 24% youth unemployment in 2013, at present only a handful of Member States have this rate at less than 11 %. Youth unemployment ‒ with its lasting effects both on economic productivity and growth as well as on individuals ‒ remains a strong concern and needs particular attention.   With support provided to more than 1.6 million young people and operations amounting to more than EUR 4 billion, the Youth Employment Initiative has had a considerable impact on employment in recent years; although its success depended to a large extent on national factors such as implementation capacity.   However, the report rightly points out that the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative are no substitutes for macroeconomic and other national policies to promote employment in general and youth employment in particular. There are Member States which have not yet implemented much needed educational, economic and social structural reforms to address the challenges they are faced with.   Seeing several positive results achieved until now, I hope that an updated Youth Employment Initiative can be a better driver for policy reform in the fields of education, public employment services and improved synergies with employers in order to provide a better future for our youth.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, youth must be the European Union's priority. This has budgetary consequences, and also national budgets, since competence in the area of ​​employment is a national competence. The European Union has done its part. Member States should use the various funds they have for promoting employment. In cohesion policy alone there are 350 billion euros. The European Social Fund, the most important element for adequate training, employment, education, has around EUR 80 billion, and Member States should use it for this purpose. The European Union has done its part and reinforced, for example, in the conciliation for this year's budget the Youth Employment Initiative by 116 million euros. The Youth Employment Initiative is an instrument that demonstrates the European Union's solidarity. It helps the poorest Member States and regions, those with the highest youth unemployment, to improve their inclusion. In this way, it reinforces social cohesion and territorial cohesion. We have to strengthen, to improve the Youth Employment Initiative. We must continue with this initiative. The European Union needs inclusion, it needs territorial cohesion and, back to the way I started: youth must be the European Union's priority and young people must be involved in the implementation of programs, in the construction of policies that concern them.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President! Five years ago, youth unemployment was over 40% in some Member States. Today the situation has improved significantly, although there are countries where there is still a lot of work to be done. The uneven implementation of the Initiative in the Member States makes the process of its monitoring and evaluation a serious challenge. There is no transparency in checking the results achieved, and there is no uniform understanding of the key concepts of "good quality internships" or "good quality jobs". Member States also have difficulties in defining the target population. The Court of Auditors noted that the Member States apply too general and superficial criteria. The result of this is, among others the problem with the identification of the NEET youth population, the so-called passive youth. For example, no Member State has been able to develop methods of reaching this group. Thus, those who most need support receive it the least. It is essential that Member States put more effort into finding ways to identify passive and excluded NEETs and establish appropriate strategies for them. The main aim of the YEI is to complement national funding, not replace it. Unfortunately, the available data show that in some Member States funding from the Initiative has replaced national funding. Thus, the program does not bring such significant added value as was planned at the time of its establishment, and the costs are borne by young people. Summing up, the Youth Employment Initiative is beginning to generate many positive effects in the area of ​​combating youth unemployment, but nevertheless, the defined shortcomings should be removed, and elements discussed, Marek Plura, so that the real needy can use the program. I would also like to thank Roman Tomc for a very good, honest report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - First of all, sincere congratulations to my colleague Romana Tomc for an excellent report, congratulations and thanks also to you, Commissioner Thyssen, for your work in tackling unemployment among young people, who we know have been the biggest victims of the economic crisis. The report is encouraging, but at the same time your work finds that there is a strong link between school systems in countries on the one hand and unemployment on the other. The countries that have apprenticeships, the traineeships where the economy and education are linked, are the countries with the lowest unemployment rates, and I think that should also be a lesson in a way for those countries that now benefit from this guarantee for young people, and that we are also trying to reform school systems. However, we must also be aware of the fact that what is happening to us today is that the problem in Europe today is that young people are moving en masse from less developed countries to more developed countries, from less developed regions to more developed countries. Therefore, it is necessary to pay attention to this problem in this initiative, which will be a problem in the coming years.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, youth unemployment remains the great challenge in the European Union, particularly in some countries, certainly Spain, Greece and Italy. Mechanisms must be put in place to ensure greater transparency on how funds are spent on unemployed young people and Member States must be obliged to provide the monitoring data they have. We know too little about the results and effects achieved with the Youth Employment Initiative and what little we know is not reassuring. From the available data emerge not exciting results regarding the quality of the job offer. The Initiative should be more focused on long-term youth unemployment, concretely helping to identify young people who do not have a job or follow a school or training course, the so-called "NEETs", and therefore to prepare targeted and adequate strategies to solve this true and its own social drama. The youth issue must be addressed in a holistic way, integrating local, regional and national instruments, in order to do one simple but fundamental thing: to train young people and teach them to work well. There is no need for palliatives.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the Youth Employment Initiative in the European Union is indeed an important step. But as I have said many times in this Chamber, there are limited resources and therefore the first thing to look at is to increase resources. The second is to explain the figures because there is a decline in youth unemployment. But this is mainly due to the fact that there are flexible forms of employment, there is part-time employment, there is "part time". The next issue that should concern us is the countries of the European South: Greece, Italy, Spain. In Greece, 500,000 young people have left and gone to other countries of the European Union. Young people who are employed receive starvation salaries, up to 450 euros. Many of them remain unpaid. Also, there are not very specific data on how this initiative proceeded in Greece. Finally, funding from Member States is limited because, otherwise, the deficit increases.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, I also wish to congratulate the rapporteur for all the work she has done on this file. Youth employment training and empowerment have always been among ALDE’s priorities, and I am pleased that the Youth Employment Initiative has so far helped 1.4 million young people who were not in employment, education or training to get a job placement, an apprenticeship or a traineeship.  While acknowledging this achievement, I also need to underline that there is much more to be done in order to enhance and improve the implementation of the programme and ensure that it successfully complements the national youth employment initiatives, in particular by reaching out to those at risk of exclusion. The assessment clearly shows that the pace of implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative does not correspond to the one initially foreseen, taking into account the various options for implementation. On the basis of results obtained, specific measures should be undertaken in order to better respond to the specific needs and issues in each Member State.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Madam President, the high levels of unemployment, which remain systemically in the European Union, are not disconnected from its neoliberal policies and the promotion of precarious employment and low wages. Such policies have a particular impact on young people, which is why, in countries like Portugal, there is a youth unemployment level that reaches 25%. The IEJ is a palliative, which the practice demonstrates does not answer the objectives to which it is proposed. The report itself recognizes that around € 45 billion would be needed for the program to have a visible impact. Now, in the 2014-2020 period, you only budgeted 6.4 billion, well below what was necessary. Hell is full of good intentions. Consistently, we have systematically proposed a substantial increase in the YEI's appropriations, advocating the creation of jobs with permanent rights and contracts, proposals that the right-wing and social-democracy majority in the European Parliament have rejected. This report is, moreover, silent on many issues, notably in addressing the structural problems that are at the root of youth unemployment.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - So, this policy of promoting youth employment and this scheme is extremely important and we have helped many young people in the European Union, but it is true that, of course, the responsibility for solving this problem usually lies with the Member States. However, it is really necessary to remember that in the field of the labor market, especially among young people, there is more and more so-called precarious work, which is becoming the predominant form of relationship among young people. Of course, so-called digital platforms are also emerging, which are significantly changing the labor market and moving the labor market from the employment relationship to the services market. And these are things we need to pay close attention to because we can also get a different statistical picture. And I agree with colleagues who say this money should be earmarked for quality jobs that must meet certain quality standards, from social, paid, and also mean a possible good tool for a stimulating tax policy, depending on the state, how capable it is.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: - Madam President, I would first like to commend my colleague Tomc and congratulate her on her excellent report and suggestions. The launch of the Youth Employment Initiative is really commendable, as well as the increase in funding for this purpose. However, the process should be designed and implemented to the end, from the launch of the idea to the use of funds intended for young people from the NEET group as end users. We need to provide quality databases to know how many young people are in that category, we need to know transparently how much money and to whom it should be allocated, we should have feedback on how the allocated funds were spent and have measurable results of this Initiative. Responsibility for each individual item of the process must be very clearly defined and it must be known at all times at what stage the process of implementing the Initiative is. Youth unemployment is indeed one of the key challenges of the European Union and therefore this Initiative must not be limited to allocating certain funds, but must insist on the implementation of concrete strategies in line with education and labor market systems in the regions and member states. I consider this compliance to be crucial.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I would also like to thank you for your report and for this extremely important topic. If we do not solve the problem of reducing youth unemployment, we see how young people leave not from one country to another in Europe, but even on other continents and feed from national and European budgets skilled labor for the United States, for China, for India . I think we also need to find complementary measures. Of course I support this initiative, but, said a colleague and said well, we need to see how we reform education. I have a concrete example in my country: we educate people for jobs that are not found in the economy and I think that there must be this connection between what we educate, what jobs the economy offers and where we invest in vocational training. Adult education is needed, because parents no longer want to send their children to vocational schools - the abolition of vocational schools has brought such effects. I also believe in a comprehensive program, with complementary measures to this initiative, but we must obviously continue with the initiative related to the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Initiative.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, following the establishment of the Youth Guarantee, the Member States of the Union have committed themselves to the common goal of ensuring that young people receive a good and quality job offer, continuing education or an internship opportunity within four months of completing employment.or after their formal education has ceased.I commend the Report and the quality recommendations offered by the rapporteur in this Report, in particular those on adapting measures to local needs and on improving communication on existing youth support programs.In addition to the measures listed in the Report, I believe that it is crucial for young people to continuously emphasize the importance of strengthening entrepreneurial skills that cannot be developed without a positive business climate, which leads us to the conclusion that structural reforms are the fastest way to quality youth employment.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, according to the most recent surveys, the data on youth employment are slowly improving, but this is precisely why we must confirm the support to Member States through youth employment programs necessary to give more hope to the many young people still looking for work. To this end, as pointed out by the rapporteur, it is necessary to measure concretely and precisely the results obtained so far, which is not easy. It is therefore true that monitoring systems need to be improved in order to obtain more precise data, especially regarding the so-called "NEET" range. However, what is even more necessary is to take a further step towards developing stronger actions on active policies for the integration of young people into the world of work, rather than continuing to favor temporary anti-crisis or employment tools. And an adequate financial allocation is needed in post-2020 programs to ensure that young people are recognized stable working conditions, corresponding to their qualifications, skills and professional skills.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Madam President, I greet the Commissioner and especially congratulate the rapporteur, my colleague Romana Tomc, on this excellent report. She actually visited the member states to see the quality of implementation and the problems that the member states are facing, and that is why we have such a high-quality and good report, thank you for that. The Youth Employment Initiative also gives an important message to young people, and that is that we put them first and that it is very important for us to employ them and acquire new knowledge and skills, so that they can be employed easier, better and faster. What this Report clearly shows is that there is a lack of more concrete measures and activities that are done in cooperation with young people and that would better and better respond to their needs. Thus, for example, in the Republic of Croatia we have heard from young people that they would like more measures such as incubators at colleges, which will encourage them to realize ideas and self-employment or, say, professional development, but during studies and schooling, to be ready to work. completion of schooling, and not only then began to learn to work.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Madam President, in the years after the financial crisis almost one in five young people in the UK were not in education, employment or training, ‘NEET’, which is often a phrase I do not like. My constituency was badly affected, in fact Merseyside was one of the five UK areas granted Youth Employment Initiative funding. What this report touches on reflects my concern. Are our efforts working? In the UK, the number of inactive NEETs has stayed almost static since 2002. Young women remain more likely to struggle than young men. Disabled young people remain far more likely to be locked out of employment or education. Young people in the UK are still three times more likely to be unemployed than the general population. The longer a young person spends ‘NEET’, the greater the impact is on their employment prospects and even on their longer-term physical and mental health. So our efforts must be targeted better. Those hardest-to-reach groups must be identified more effectively, otherwise for all out efforts we will still be left with a lost generation.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Ms. President! Listening to this debate today, I was completely shocked when some said that this youth initiative should be stopped and the issues involved should be dealt with in the Member States. I was trying to ask these people what miracles would actually have prevented member states from doing anything to solve or alleviate or alleviate the unemployment of their own young people? At the same time, I also filtered out from today's debate that we are really just trying to focus on global numbers. What is the percentage of youth unemployment? But we did not take into account that this is even geographically different within some countries. This youth unemployment mainly affects people in rural areas and villages. I believe that this initiative should be extended to small settlements, small villages, where young people have essentially zero chance of anything, following the example of a 'smart village'.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the honourable Members for their support and for the interesting remarks and comments. Your report is very timely as we are now in the process of elaborating our proposals for the future funding of youth employment under the next Multiannual Financial Framework. Fighting youth unemployment will continue to be a high priority at European and national levels as long as the rates of young unemployed and of those not in employment, education or training (NEETs) remain excessively high. The targeted funding and the focus on results which characterise the Youth Employment Initiative should be maintained. We will also address the challenge of simplifying implementation rules and reducing the burden on both managing authorities and beneficiaries. Many of you stressed the importance of macro-economic policies, and I would like to mention the policy of this Commission to stimulate economic growth, investment and job creation. Let me also refer to our skills agenda, and to underline our attention to quality in terms of offer in the framework of the Youth Employment Initiative. This initiative is well targeted, as you know, targeted at specific regions and groups of young people, and we have specific results indicators that act as an additional driver of quality. The Commission is also monitoring the quality of employment for all age groups under the European Semester, with particular attention being paid to issues related to labour-market segmentation. We provide guidance on the quality of traineeships and apprenticeships and we promote youth learning and vocational education and training (VET) mobility. We have enhanced the monitoring of the quality of Youth Guarantee offers in the Employment Committee (EMCO) multilateral surveillance process, and, as some of you might know, conclusions are expected soon – early this year. For the future, the commitment to quality offers for young people has been reinforced in the Pillar of Social Rights. In principle 4b of the pillar we have included the Youth Guarantee. Honourable Members, I look forward to working with you on the future Multiannual Financial Framework proposals, to securing a prominent place for investing in the future of our young generation. This investment in young people is not only, as some of you said, an expression of solidarity: it is also an essential condition for ensuring the future development of a highly competitive social market economy aiming at full employment and social progress. It is also about an inclusive society and a dynamic society. Thanks for your support. Let us work together in the interest of our younger generation.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Rapporteur. - Thank you very much again for the floor and thank you very much to all of you who took part in this interesting debate. I note that we actually have the same views on tackling youth unemployment and that we all together recognize this YEI program as one of the fundamental and very useful initiatives to reduce youth unemployment. Of course, we still have a lot of work to do in this area, and I agree that we need to make this program more effective in the future. The Commission must also be given greater powers to monitor Member States' spending of this money. However, let me draw my attention to what many of you have already pointed out before me. The European Union and the Commission make a lot of money available, and the Member States are the ones most responsible for making sure that this money, which is intended for young people, really reaches them. Another important caveat: this program and this money is neither the only nor the most important tool that Member States have to address their employment policies. They themselves are the ones who have to make all the necessary reforms first, and we are very different in that, some are far behind. Reforms on the labor market are needed, especially reforms on the market or in the field of education, namely we cannot afford for young people to enter the labor market who become unemployed but have, for example, a higher education. Education systems must take care of this. We will need this program, not only today, tomorrow, but also after 2020. But if we want it to be effective, we will also have to take into account the situation that will prevail in the labor market in a few years' time, that is, new and innovative youth programs. Thank you very much everyone for your cooperation again.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: - The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 18 January 2018.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - It is undoubtedly right that the European Commission has taken various measures and that the European institutions are actively trying to tackle the causes of high youth unemployment in the European Union, especially in times of crisis. Progress is visible. However, continuing to further reduce youth unemployment remains an important challenge. Unemployment remains one of the European Union's main priorities, and even in a slightly improved situation, one does not need to be overly optimistic and forget the real problems we face together. European support schemes must be set up to help all young people, including young people with disabilities who are unable to find employment in the labor market for a long time. European mechanisms are intended to complement, but cannot replace, national funding for youth support. Until now, unfortunately, this has often worked in such a way that states have used these resources to fund existing ones, rather than creating new ones. The European Union must strive to adopt policies and instruments that will benefit its citizens, even at a time when Europe is failing economically and stagnating.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The latest Eurostat figures confirm a situation of high structural unemployment in the European Union and the Eurozone. A systemic unemployment that coexists with another reality that the statistical data does not deceive: an abnormally low wage growth, a compression of the labor force price, which takes advantage of the social pressure exerted by the unemployed reserve army to increase the exploitation of those who they are still finding work. Two realities that particularly affect the youngest and that confirm that the capitalist crisis was used to force the entry into a new level of exploitation. The European Union and its policies are an active agent in promoting this race to the bottom in terms of rights, wages, living and working conditions. In Portugal, youth unemployment reaches 25%. The Youth Employment Initiative appears as a palliative. But what the practice demonstrates is its almost residual impact. We have repeatedly proposed an increase in the resources allocated to this program and a clarification of its rules, in order to prevent the promotion of forms of precarious work. Significantly, these proposals were defeated by the right and social democracy in this Parliament. That now crocodile tears come to cry for youth unemployment.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - In addition to Greece, the financial and economic crisis of 2008-2009 affected Hungary the deepest in the EU - which, among other things, meant that the unemployment of Hungarian youth also increased dramatically. By 2012, the unemployment rate for young people was over 28%, 5% higher than the EU average. By 2017, this number has been reduced to 10.5% in Hungary due to efficient domestic programs and the efficient use of EU funds adjusted to them. Meanwhile, the same EU indicator fell to only 16.4% by the end of 2017, which meant much less dynamics than the Hungarian decline. Thus, according to the draft report, it has become clear that Hungary is one of the few countries, apart from Austria, the Czech Republic, the Netherlands, Malta and Germany, where youth unemployment is below 11%. It is unfortunate, however, that between 2013 and 2016, only 4% of young people participating completed the program, which can be considered very inefficient, especially when Member States' programs focused mainly on highly qualified young people. I suggested that, in connection with the work in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, resources spent on longer-performing Member States should be reviewed, as it is unacceptable for someone, such as Hungary, to improve their situation much better and faster. they would continue to receive subsidies even with poorer performance.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - The implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI) is a thorny issue because it opposes on the one hand the quite legitimate desire to help, through substantial funding, particularly desocialized young people, this that we support, and on the other hand, to develop a "system of assisted employment", criticized by the Court of Auditors and against which we are extremely critical. However, a large part of the funding comes from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) and some of our French regions benefit from it, which we welcome. French taxpayer money "returns", even if only in part, to the French who need it most. We call for better management and above all recall that this is not a long-term solution. Only an economic recovery framed by a patriotism of the same nature will be able to stem unemployment among young people.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - High youth employment rate is one of the most important items of any "healthy" economy. The financial crisis in 2008 significantly changed the situation on the labor market and affected the strong rise in youth unemployment rates. The Youth Employment Initiative was created with the aim of rapidly mobilizing financial resources in the most affected countries struggling with high levels of youth unemployment and inactivity. The program applies to young people up to the age of 24, but Member States have the right to increase this limit to 29 years. It is important to emphasize that the measures are intended solely to supplement national youth employment programs, which have failed in some countries, and not to completely replace them. The program is funded by 50% from the European Social Fund and 50% from the EU budget and is currently the most successful of all European Structural and Investment Funds in terms of implementation. There is still room for improvement, so work needs to be done on better exchange and quality of data between countries. Likewise, some countries use EU money instead of state money earmarked for youth employment programs which needs to change. I believe that the Initiative is very important in the progress of the EU, because youth unemployment has become a common problem of all Member States and we have to face it together, at EU level. The high youth employment rate will create the conditions for a sustainable and unified recovery of the euro area economy.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Unemployment particularly affects younger people. The European Union and its policies are an active agent in promoting this race to the bottom in terms of rights, wages, living and working conditions. In Portugal, youth unemployment reaches 25%. So it is in many other Member States. The Youth Employment Initiative does not solve the structural problems of unemployment. Worse, it becomes a factor of devaluation of work, whether in terms of employment, remuneration or flexibility. In other words, young people, wherever they find work, internships or training, become a stick for the whole spoon. But still, its macroeconomic impact is almost residual, as the statistics show. We have repeatedly proposed an increase in the resources allocated to this program and a clarification of its rules, in order to prevent the promotion of forms of precarious work. Significantly, these proposals were defeated by the right and by Social Democracy in this Parliament, which now come crying crocodile tears for youth unemployment.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: written.- The Youth Guarantee is another of many EU programs that this Parliament thinks should be extended despite its failures.In addition, as is the case in principle always in this union, Sweden pays in more than we get back.Labor market policy initiatives must, insofar as they are needed or judged to function, be decided on in national parliaments, in my opinion.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - I accept the report on the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative only with moderate relief. Youth unemployment at EU level, reportedly around twice the overall average unemployment rate, is a primary concern for us, and the Youth Employment Initiative is one of the key instruments we implement to tackle this problem. However, I would like to point out that both the Youth Guarantee and the Initiative itself can only be a first step towards an integrated approach that takes into account the employment needs of young people. In particular, I consider the initiative an adequate incentive to carry out far-reaching reforms and to stimulate better coordination in the area of ​​employment and education. In this context, I would also like to emphasize with particular strength the employment potential of the cultural and creative sector. Europe's cultural and creative industries provide more than 12 million full-time jobs, representing 7.5% of the working population in the EU. Moreover, they contribute significantly and more than any other sector precisely to youth employment. Finally, in the context of the implementation of the Initiative we are discussing today, I strongly emphasize that well-functioning monitoring and reporting systems remain the key tools for a proper assessment of implementation.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: - The next item is the Commission statement on the decision on plastics strategy (2018/2508 (RSP)).

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, we have managed to make solid progress in the implementation of the Circular Economy Action Plan. Thanks to Parliament’s hard work, one of the key initiatives, the legislative package on waste, is now very close to adoption. I am grateful for the hard work of Simona Bonafè and all the shadow rapporteurs involved. The package the Commission adopted yesterday keeps us on this very positive track. The main element of this package is the Plastics Strategy for Europe. There is a tide of growing awareness and concern among people, businesses and governments about the enormity of plastic pollution. In last year’s special Eurobarometer survey, 84% of European citizens said that they are worried about the impact of plastics on our environment. The Commission also received a petition signed by 800 000 Europeans calling on us to deliver an ambitious plan, and I know that, in this House too, there is a sense of urgency about this issue. Plastic pollution is an enormous challenge, threatening our environment and health. Every second, approximately 700 kilos of plastic waste ends up in our oceans. If we go on this way, there will be more plastic than fish in the ocean by 2050. Micro-plastics are found not just in our oceans but also in our water, in the water we drink, in the food we eat, and in the air we breathe. Also, the way we produce, use and dispose of plastics today is a threat to several economic sectors: fisheries and tourism, to name two. It is also a wasted economic opportunity. Vice-President Katainen will say more about that in a second. With this strategy, we aim to foster a new, sustainable and profitable plastics economy, with the design of products and other parts of the production chain taking into account re-use and recycling needs. Plastic packaging accounts for about 60% of all plastic waste generated in Europe every year. It is therefore paramount that we address packaging as a priority. Our aim is that, by 2030, all plastic packaging placed on the EU market will be reusable or recyclable in a cost-effective manner. We have quickly begun work on future revision of rules, and new harmonised rules, on packaging. In the shorter term, we need to curb plastic waste and reduce the use of certain types of plastic. Several measures for that are provided for in the strategy. We will propose an EU-level legislative initiative on single-use plastics before summer. Single-use plastic items constitute 50% of litter found on EU beaches, and it is important that we significantly reduce the use of these products. Micro-plastics are another serious problem. We have launched a process to ban micro-plastics that are intentionally added to products such as cosmetics, paints and detergents, and we can do that under the Reach framework. Also, we will continue our work to ban oxo-plastics because these oxo-plastics fragment to tiny pieces, exacerbating the micro-plastics accumulation even more. Together with this strategy, we adopted a new directive on port reception facilities, which goes a long way, ensuring that waste is brought back to land instead of being discharged at sea. We will also develop additional measures to motivate those working on boats to bring the fishing gear to land and not dump it into the sea. Since a significant part of plastic pollution comes from other parts of the world, we will need to work together with the rest of the world to make sure that we improve the situation. We, as the EU, can be a global leader in this. We have been a global leader on climate action and we can be a global leader here as well. We need the full support of this Parliament if we are to be successful. Vice-President Katainen will now explain how this is also working well for our economy.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, today, or actually yesterday we adopted a plastic strategy, which is the elementary part of the circular economy thinking. Today, all too often the way plastics are produced, used and discarded fails to capture the economic benefits of a more circular approach. According to the estimates only 5% of the value of plastic packaging materials remains in the economy, the rest goes to waste after a very short first use. The annual bill accounts for up to EUR 105 billion. We simply cannot afford it. This is why we are proposing rethinking and improving the functioning of the entire complex value chain: plastic producers, designers, retailers and recyclers and consumers all need to act. It often seems to be forgotten that high levels of plastic recycling can only be achieved by improving the way plastics are produced and designed. The aim is that by 2030 all plastic packaging will be reusable and recyclable. This will be achieved by stimulating design for circularity, boosting recycled content and stimulating better separate waste collection. Plastics packaging today accounts for about 60% of all plastics waste generated in Europe every year. It is therefore paramount that we address this as a priority. In the EU, the uptake of recycled plastics in new products is low; only around 6%. Our objective is to support the creation of more stable markets for recycled plastics and ensure the demand for recycled plastics is multiplied by four. In other words, our aim is, first, to create a truly well-functioning single market for recyclable plastics, second to improve waste collection and, third, promote recycled plastics. The intention is to stimulate investment in the sector. Existing EU funds such as the structural funds, the European Fund for Strategic Investments and Horizon 2020 will continue to support businesses and Member States to upgrade their waste management infrastructure. We aim at stimulating the increase of the European recycling capacity and the quality of the resulting recycled material. This will create trust in the market and attract further investment and innovation in Europe. But plastic waste reduction depends not only on the recycling infrastructure, it can also be reduced by using more sustainable materials which could replace traditional plastic while offering the same functionalities. Later this year the Commission will develop a strategic research innovation agenda for plastics. The focus will be the development of smarter and more recyclable plastic materials and products, more efficient recycling processes, the removal of hazardous substances and contaminants from recycled plastics and finding solutions addressing the problem of micro-plastics. And if we manage to set things right the world will follow us. It is always the case that good European policies are copied elsewhere, and that should be our goal, to have a global impact. This is the most effective way to ensure that the European plastics industry, employing today as many as 1.5 million people, will become stronger, more competitive and at the same time the world leader in innovation, digitisation and decarbonisation.

name: Peter LIESE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, dear Vice-Presidents, dear colleagues! I very much welcome the fact that the Commission presented the strategy today. We have a huge problem, we have a problem with the pollution of the world's oceans. It is a dramatic portrayal, but what you said yesterday, Vice-President Timmermans, is surely something to the fact that, if we are not careful, we will have more plastic in the sea than fish by 2050. And it already brings health problems with it. We also have the problem that we use up our children's raw materials, that we have too little circular economy overall and too much of a throwaway society. So we have to do something. The Commission has made very interesting proposals. After all, there is also a legislative proposal that is already part of it. And that's where I want to start. We have to stop just talking. We have to act very specifically. And that requires legislative proposals. The European Commission is the only body that can make legislative proposals. Therefore: Congratulations on the one, very small suggestion you made. But I really want to ask that, as announced, the next proposal comes in May and that it doesn't stay that way. We need a legal framework that puts those who want to promote recycling and those who want to promote sustainable production methods better off against the competition. Because there are good ideas everywhere, and there are people everywhere who want to do something. But there are shareholders everywhere who say: If you do that, we will lose money. So the rules have to be such that you don't lose money when you invest in sustainable production, but that you win money. We should work together on the way.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
