text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - When Frans Timmermans is there, I always take the opportunity to speak in my own language. That is a bit annoying for the other Commissioner, but he can listen to the interpretation. Let me start by saying “thank you, congratulations”. It was about time, but you are doing it. You come up with a plastic strategy and I think we are the only major region in the world today to take that responsibility. With this we also set the standard for the rest of the world. That's really important! We will fully support you in this. We also especially look forward to the legislative proposals, because soft law strategies and awareness-raising are all well and good, but we also need legislation. I am thinking of the working group on disposable plastics, but also of the legislation on port reception facilities. Both are very important and Parliament will certainly support them. There will also be an investigation into a tax on disposable plastics. That is a very important item in many of our Member States. Our group wants to support that. I think that's a good way to tax plastic away. What we are less in agreement with is to use that tax as a kind of own income for the Union, because this is pre-eminently a tax that you do not want to collect, that must go to zero. And when we talk about own income - and we are very much in favor of this - we want to have a stable basis for it. One last point. It is very important that the Commission proposes to ensure that all plastic packaging is recyclable by 2030. Take a look at that together with the wonderful work that our rapporteur Simona Bonafè and the others have done on the waste package and the circular economy. Then you have a good basis. But we will also have to ensure that we create a market, that the producers also start using recyclable packaging. As long as cheap oil is more easily accessible than the recyclable materials, we have a problem.That is why strong initiatives are needed, for example ensuring that products of the future contain a minimum number of recyclable materials.But thanks in advance for this initiative!

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –Madam President, I would like to thank our Vice-Presidents. It is interesting to hear your proposal.  I know that it is not a very fashionable thing to say, but I am actually a great fan of plastic. It is a wonderful material. It has transformed most of our lives, certainly mine. If you are as old as I am, you can remember when there was not very much plastic around and life was very different. But we all have to accept, and there is common agreement, that we have probably got to the point where – a bit like all of our issues around climate change – it is time that we stopped just taking the benefits and realised that there are some pretty heavy downsides.  I really think that this argument is done. It is made. I doubt if you will hear too many people today, or in the future when you are putting the strategy into place, arguing with that. I think our problem is going to be about how we put these proposals in place. Perhaps, given where I stand in the Chamber and possibly a little bit my nationality, it will not come as a great surprise to you that I am not such a fan as the two previous speakers of the legislation. That is not to say that I do not think we need any – of course we do, we do need a framework – but I would like to make an appeal for that to be as light as possible in the sense of setting Member States’ targets and allowing them to use their own best efforts to meet those. The new thing in here that I took away was this issue about setting a single market for recyclable plastics, standards on how they are manufactured and what they are manufactured with. That is how you stimulate this change. It is by creating a market, making that market work and trusting the public. I can tell you that in the UK, where we have just banned microplastics, there was no resistance. They do not need to be brought on board. It is actually the functioning of the whole system that needs to be taken very seriously, so I thank you very much.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, many thanks from my side to the Commission for their strategy paper. If a few years ago, someone had told me that two Vice-Presidents would present a strategy on plastics in Parliament I would have sent that person to the madhouse. So it is great to see that commitment from the Commission, and leafing through the strategy, I must say the analysis is very strong, the language is right and the intentions are very, very promising. If the European Commission were a consultancy firm I would certainly recommend it to all my friends and businesses around. But the Commission is a political body; not only that, it is the only political body that can propose legislative proposals. And that is what is still lacking here. I know some elements are technically difficult: setting common standards for biodegradable plastics is not easy, and I know there’s a huge scientific debate behind that. But there are many other elements that are much less complicated and that have already been considered by the Commission for years and years, even by previous commissioners. Ms Girling has already mentioned that tackling the use of micro plastics in cosmetics would have been easy, and it would have been quite easy to set minimum standards for recycled content in the Ecodesign Directive. And what about measures on single-use plastics? That has been done the around the world So concluding, I’m very happy with the strategy, but I had expected a little bit more on the legislative part. I know that your intention is to come forward with those, please do so during your mandate because if it is left to the next Commission we don’t know if the same two vice-presidents will still be still there.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - I would also like to thank the two Commissioners who came to us today to introduce us to the material that we have all probably been waiting for a long time, but I must say that the strategy presented leaves us with mixed feelings. On the one hand, I very much welcome the fact that the European Commission plans to work to ensure that all plastic packaging placed on the EU internal market is either reusable or easily recyclable by 2030, and that more than half of all plastic waste will be recyclable by that year. . The single internal market for plastics is the right way to go, but it will require a robust investment. We are currently facing a global crisis in terms of plastic packaging, and we do not have time to wait until 2030, and we will not solve it by starting to transport it to China, where our plastic waste no longer wants it. The situation in our seas is unsustainable in the long run, and not just because of microplastics. It is therefore essential that, on the basis of the strategy, ambitious rules be presented as soon as possible by this Commission. These must drastically reduce the consumption of both plastic objects and packaging. We did without them before that, we have to do in the future. I am not sure if it is enough to rely only on voluntary commitments from industry. After several studies of biodegradable plastics performed in our country in the Czech Republic, when it was found that in most cases these do not decompose even after two years in the soil, I am skeptical of them as well. We should start verifying what we are proposing, and not be appeased by the industry over what he is proposing to us.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! It really is a great day! After all, it is four years ago that the Commission, and not least Commissioner Timmermans and I, were really up for a fight. The Commissioner was sure that plastic was "small things" and the Commission should be petty about "small things". Now we are here, and the Commission has recognized that plastic pollution is "big things". They have even come up with something that is reasonably "big". It ends up becoming a habit with me to have to praise Timmermans, and I do so with joy every single time he gives me the opportunity to do so. Thank you so much! But of course there are a few little things! But let me first take the praise further: It is good that there is a coherent description of the problem, so that we have health, climate, nature, jobs and resource efficiency with us, and that the need for competitive advantages is mentioned. I also believe that we need to get the industry in properly, as it has been mentioned by several, including by Peter Liese. I support ensuring that we have progressive support for the industry. We need to have mid-term evaluations so we can see that we are actually achieving something. Then I would also like to share in the grief that there are no concrete proposals. But now I have been so happy, so I will content myself with rejoicing instead that we have been promised that the proposals will come in May. I reckon key parts of them can be finished so we can meet our citizens with proof that we are actually taking their concerns seriously. I think the best thing we can do to strengthen the European Union in this matter is to do something really good here. I have one more small thing: I know that the Commission has a problem with endocrine disruptors. I do not know if they themselves have been disturbed in the head, since we can not be allowed to have them with us. So we have to make sure that the endocrine disruptors also come out of plastic if it is to be reusable and recyclable. But let me say thank you very much for us to finally get a ban on oxo.It must be banned as soon as possible.It is a disaster that this substance is in our environment.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, my party and I strongly value products, materials and resources in our economy, and we believe that these should be kept in use for as long as possible in order to minimise the generation of waste in our environment. Thus, it is our opinion that plastic, which is an extremely important material, should be used prudently. However, food packaging has led to a reduction in food wastage. The UN’s Food and Agricultural Organisation estimates that 33% of food produced for human consumption is lost or wasted globally, totalling about 1.3 billion tons per year. Therefore, packaging techniques such as modified atmosphere packaging and innovations such as active and intelligent packaging can ameliorate this. My party and I therefore believe that plastic packaging which cannot be reused should be made of a substance that can be recycled.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, Honorable Vice-Presidents, since the publication in 2013 of the Green Paper on the strategy on plastics, we have taken the measure of a major problem which seriously endangers the environment and the health of Europeans. From "all-plastic" yesterday, today we are taking the more reasonable path of saving and recycling. The alarming figure of eight million tonnes of plastic waste dumped into our oceans every year is urging us to act. Fighting pollution by increasing the lifespan of plastics and their recyclable content, promoting biodegradable plastics and empowering consumers are steps in the right direction. But we need to go further, namely to ban plastics wherever possible, especially when other options already exist, and to move away as far as possible from the “all-throwaway” logic. I am thinking in particular of single-use plastics, which can be quickly replaced by materials made from cardboard or recycled paper, and which are sustainable alternatives. In any case, Gentlemen Vice-Presidents, you can count on our group to supply proposals for this strategy that you want ambitious.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: – Madam President, the plastic strategy is long-awaited and from what I hear already today the commissioners will have huge support in the European Parliament to help them deliver on this strategy. We all agree that high-quality recycling of plastics is a key part of the process, yet we need a viable market for them. That is why I welcomed the proposal for quality standards for recycled plastics and the intention to incentivise packaging for the construction and car industries to use more of them. That creates a complete economic value chain, giving the industry the possibility to adapt to the new rules. Moreover, while taking into account food safety, we need to discourage multi-layer packaging and encourage easier-to-recycle plastics. We can and should have more ambition when it comes to micro-plastics in detergents in detergents and cosmetics and single-use plastics, by building on the success of our legislation on plastic bags. In the end, as has been said many times, the ocean and the seas are being suffocated by plastic particles, and I’m very happy to see the EUR 100 million in funding for research and support for action on marine litter. However, we need to consider every level of production, recycling and disposal for this strategy to be a success story.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, let me start straightaway by congratulating both Vice-Presidents. I have been through the strategy. I have spoken to both of you and I have to say I am satisfied that for the first time ever we are looking at the issue with a holistic perspective. It could be that I come from an island in the middle of the Mediterranean, and that makes me much more aware of the environmental and health problems that plastic waste brings. I think this is our opportunity to actually make sure that we put environment at the forefront, while also making sure that we get industry on board. We need to make sure that we remain competitive and we do not let other continents run in front of us in the competitiveness stakes. This is our opportunity because people are aware of the impact that plastic has, not only on our environment but also on our health. I have to be honest with you, I was quite shocked to hear that micro-plastics are not only ending up on our seabed, not only in the fish that we eat, but are also in the air we breathe. It is such a complex issue and so great a problem that we need to address it sooner rather than later. I have spoken to both of you, and if I may, as a final point, I would like to commit you on something, because I have heard some of the concerns that were raised. When we spoke, you promised a ban on the deliberate addition of micro-plastics, in detergents and cosmetics for example. You spoke about legislation on single-use plastics, and we will hold you to your word. We hope that we will see this by May, as we really want to make sure that we have progress on another legislative proposal from your end to make sure that waste does not come into our ports.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - The strategy is without a doubt another step forward towards the circular economy that we all envision, in which more and better recycling of plastic is an important and necessary link. Thank you and congratulations for the ambition that the Commission is showing here. We must use the Chinese import ban on plastic resolutely to invest more in our own recycling capacity. But more recycling alone is of course not enough. We also need to focus on waste prevention, on well thought out product designs, on new business models. I also welcome the Commission's nuanced stance on biodegradable plastics. Clear agreements are needed, but we also have to realize that even that kind of plastic is not a saving grace for marine litter, on the contrary. The announced actions regarding microplastics also sound promising. European solutions must, will and can really make a difference here. Finally, I call on the Commission to speed up legislative work, but also to focus on customization and not limit its actions to consumer packaging. There is certainly room for innovation in the business-to-business market too!

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-Presidents! I welcome the fact that with its plastics strategy the Commission is facing up to the implementation of environmental requirements. However, the conceptual corset for this strategy will hardly prove to be sustainable, because the chosen voluntariness, the focus on recycling and reuse and the consideration of the plastic problem from the perspective of the internal market and supply and demand alone will not provide a solution. Specifically: The fact that Germany will not illegally hide its 570,000 tons of plastic waste annually from China in Poland, Bulgaria or Romania in the future is, yes, a domestic market issue. The fact that China is not being replaced by Vietnam, Turkey or Africa is a question of trade policy. We are responsible for ensuring that plastic is not simply deposited here or anywhere else. The problem with these materials is that out of sight is out of mind, but not out of the world. There are reasons and arguments for a serious policy of waste prevention as well as technologies for its removal. But the industry sings its interest song as always: too high standards. Because the cash register only rings when production is buzzing. That is why we need environmental standards and material waste avoidance as criteria as early as the productive approach and must also translate these into internationally binding goals.

name: Claude TURMES
text: - Madam President! These terrible images: plastic on the beach, plastic in the forest. Animals that die miserably - fish, cows. And then these pictures that there is a continent in the sea, so to speak, made only of plastic. I also think it's good that you mentioned the specific number. At some point we will have more plastic in the sea than fish. I think it's good that the Commission is finally doing something. I'm sitting here with Mother Teresa from all the plastic bags. She is a priestess and she probably converted Mr. Timmermans, so that the Juncker Commission finally wants to make the little things that interest people big. I think it's nice that you've changed your mind, and I mean that personally too. Well, then we need more laws - but now I will tell you something from my personal story: In 1991, as a young man, I was at a conference of the UNECE, that is Europe, Canada and so on. At that time we discussed a ban on PVC - why? Because the experts said at the time: If I mix PVC and polyethylene and other plastic, then I get downcycled or I have to burn it. In other words, for me the real political courage of the Commission would be: We have to ban all plastic that does not become a proper product after recycling. That is the real challenge, and I hope the Commission will dare to do it.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: - Madam President! Yes, indeed: two Commissioners and then two Vice-Presidents here today. It's a miracle. Mother Teresa moved a lot there. We do not want to talk any further about the fact that there are also two vice-presidents, who were the subject of the debate about “big or small” in the last election. They are both still here now, that speaks for their character; I am pleased. It was obvious that you were taking up this topic. At that time, President Juncker was using the wrong dimensions. Today we are happy that he sees that too. Only 5% of the plastic that we have in Europe is processed. Everything else ends up where my colleagues just mentioned it. And that's why we all agree: we have to do something. Commissioner, or gentlemen, one thing is certain: I am now probably one of the oldest in this room and have been here in this house for ages. If we had once properly implemented our European waste laws - also in my own country, I don't even want to deny that - then we would have far fewer problems. Then we wouldn't have to list these horror scenarios that we are listing right now. It is important to have moderate, strict rules. And we have to involve and commit the industry. That means that we have to - as we have been doing for many years - ensure along the value chain that the designers of the products have a serious say and that the designers finally sit down with the recyclers. One then says to the other that it is a social decline for him. No, that is a rational solution and we have to go there! In this case, I am counting on the Commission anyway, but also on European industry, which will support this idea and support sensible proposals.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the Commission for presenting this strategy which is very important for Europe, both from an environmental and an economic point of view. I start from a fact: today in Europe 25 million tons of plastic waste are produced and less than 30% is recycled. These are impressive figures if we consider that much of this waste is the primary cause of pollution of the seas: today there are entire islands of plastic in the midst of the oceans. It is good to clarify that this is not a strategy against plastic but an opportunity that we must be able to seize. Aiming to make all plastic packaging recyclable and reusable between now and 2030 is not only a way to protect the environment but it is also a precise choice, which gives new impetus to the recycling industry, to innovation for more sustainable materials, to revive the competitiveness of our businesses and support employment. Challenges requiring investment in research and development, which will be stimulated by the additional EUR 100 million. The agreement on the circular economy package that we reached in December will already concretely kick off many actions included in the strategy, starting with the strengthening of separate collection obligations, to preventive measures in the generation of waste, such as the introduction of extended producer responsibility schemes for packaging. When we talk about plastic we are talking about products and materials in common use for European citizens: bottles, cosmetics, bags. This is the right time: there is a public opinion very attentive to sustainability issues and worried about the impact of pollution on health. Citizens have already demonstrated that, when it comes to implementing actions that protect the environment, they are the first to adopt virtuous behavior. It is our duty to move from intentions to concrete measures, as we are doing.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Madam President! I also join the thanks that the tandem of the two vice-presidents presents the strategy on this issue, as announced, expected at the end of last year. It is a very important fact that we are complementing the circular economy strategy by this presentation by you. It is true that there are no regulations yet, but it seems to me that the announcements that are here prove that we all think that we must think about plastics or about plastics, from prevention, from ecodesign to good - that so to speak - effective methods of collecting what is produced. Apparently, we produce 300 million tons of plastics annually worldwide. This significant percentage is also produced here in Europe. However, what I would like to point out: that in this document you do not pay attention to the combination of this strategy in the field of plastics with bioeconomy, and yet this is a kind of hope at the moment related to the fact that renewable raw materials can be a source of plastics production, which are biodegradable. Of course, there are some that can contain these components and are not biodegradable, but a large part is biodegradable. We know the changes in the agricultural commodity markets. Some of them are already polymerized into plastics (for example sugar by laccidic acid). Secondly, I would like to draw your attention (just a moment, Madam President) to the problems related to marine litter. It seems to me that we will not only do this as the European Union and the Member States. We have to work together with our neighbors here. An example is the Mediterranean Sea - without cooperation with the Middle East and Africa, we cannot prevent this pollution, especially when it comes to microplastics.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome the publication of the Plastics Strategy. I would like to comment on the costs. The strategy states that between 70 and 105 billion euros are wasted annually on non-recycled plastic waste. You also refer to the damage caused to the environment by marine waste or the burning of plastic waste. But we also need to talk about health costs. Every year, millions of tonnes of plastic waste are generated with a polluting impact on the environment and which is difficult, if not impossible, to dispose of. What are the health risks posed by the tiny pieces of plastic that can now be found in the air, in drinking water, in some foods we eat? In line with the strategy, the Commission will ensure that plastic microparticles are covered by chemicals legislation. It's an important step, but it may not be enough. The European Union has not made enough progress in researching and reducing citizens' exposure to toxic substances, although it has an obligation to do so under the Seventh Environment Action Program.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, excuse me, I didn’t hear how much time I have. Sorry. Thank you. I shall be quick then. I would just like to say that in 2002, Ireland introduced a plastic bag levy and there was an immediate 90% reduction in the use of plastic bags. So Member States can do things themselves. That’s the good news. The bad news is that my country is one of the largest producers of plastic waste in the European Union, so we’ve got a lot of work to do. We need to talk about China and its decision not to take our dirty plastic anymore. I’ve tried to find out from the industry where it is going to go. I wonder, do the Commissioners know? This is an immediate and real problem for us. It seems to me that we’re moving from landfills to sea fills, and that’s really serious because of the impact on our ecosystems. Therefore, this strategy is vital, and I thank both Commissioners for being here this evening to present it. It has got to work. We have an immediate concern around illegal dumping, I took a walk in the countryside at the weekend and I was disgusted with what I saw around me. A French colleague saw my pictures on Twitter and shared her experiences, so we need to tackle that in the Member States.  There is one area where we are encouraging people to use the internet to buy goods and services. However, when it comes to buying products, we all know that the amount of packaging that comes through our post, or otherwise, with internet sales is enormous, and we are not talking about it. My young children buy things on the internet and I have more waste as a result. This is something we’ve got to talk about and deal with, or the mountains will rise.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: - Madam President!It is really gratifying that we now have a plastic strategy for the EU.It contains a lot of good goals and intentions.Plastic needs to be better regulated, and waste in particular is a huge problem for which we are now taking responsibility.The 2030 targets with high demands for reuse and recycling are therefore absolutely right.The EU is becoming a world leader, and the strategy is much needed, necessary and good.So thanks for that!But I must also say to the Commission that you are disappointing a little here by not taking action sooner!I think you should have presented 3-4 bills together with the strategy.You know very well that we here in the European legislative machinery are not working very fast, so it will be several years before the legislation is in place.So promise us that you will meet the deadlines, and promise us that you will come up with something as soon as possible.We have to act now!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union's plastic strategy is a first and important step in combating one of the tragedies that characterize our civilization, namely plastic, the third most widespread material on earth after steel and concrete. From the 1950s to today, with the start of the widespread use of plastic, 8.3 billion tons of plastic have been produced and around 6.3 billion tons have been thrown into nature. The initiatives that the Commission intends to implement are all acceptable. However, much more could be done, and perhaps the time span of the strategy can also be shortened, given that 2030 is not that close. But what I would like to point out is the political fact of the initiative: the European Union finally certifies, at the highest level of institutional authority, that the problem of plastic exists and that it must be tackled seriously. As has already happened in the past for other elements of environmental policy, this position of the European Union will also force other areas of the world to confront the problem in the same direction, confirming that the European Union knows how to exercise its world leadership in environmental matters.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, Honorable Vice-Presidents, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating the Commission on the launch of the first European strategy for plastics and efforts to harmonize defense and environmental protection, with economic growth and the innovation it translate. We all know that human society is largely dependent on plastic. More than 70% of our products that we use on a daily basis are made from materials composed of plastics. The reality is that we Europeans generate 25 million tonnes of plastic waste per year, of which less than 70% is collected for recycling, the rest ending up in our oceans, contaminating everything in its path, endangering its own sustainability the planet. The need to invest in recycling and design, Vice-Presidents, is not enough. It is also necessary to change behaviors, to change the culture of the disposable in terms of production and consumption, encouraging the use of durable and reusable materials. Dear Colleagues, it is an evidence that today's society is unfortunately plastic-dependent. That is why I understand that it is up to all of us to create the conditions for this dependency to end in favor of a more sustainable environment. I will end by saying, Mr Vice-Presidents, as Mr Vice-President Timmermans said, if we do not change the way we produce and use plastic objects in 2050, there will be more plastic than fish in our oceans.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, while acknowledging that plastic is an important material for our economy and daily lives, serious threats emerge when plastics end up in the environment, especially in the oceans and in the seas, where they have an impact on nature, the climate and human health. Therefore, we have to bring strong capabilities in order to tackle this worrying issue and to frame a robust strategy for improving the economics, quality and rate of plastic recycling and reuse, especially when plastic production is expected to almost quadruple by 2050. I therefore fully welcome the first ever Europe-wide strategy on plastics, which would ensure that the design and production of plastics and plastic products fully match the use, repair and recycling needs, and that more sustainable materials are developed and promoted, while laying the foundations for a new plastic economy and bringing new opportunities for innovation, competitiveness and job creation. In my personal opinion, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President of the Commission, the European Union has to ban the plastic bags within a very short period of time.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr Timmermans and Mrs Katainen, the European plastics strategy is indeed an interesting initiative, combining environmental protection with recycling potential and, at the same time, integrating the plastics industry into the circular economy. In addition, it protects fisheries and tourism which are particularly important for Greece, which has thousands of islands, as you know, and which require even cleaner shores and we want cleaner seas. In Greece, the process has already begun and from the beginning of the year 0.03 euros are imposed for each plastic bag plus 24% VAT. The state is trying to "get rid of the fly", as we say. This amount will reach 0.09 euros from January 1, 2019. However, in our strategy the goal must be to strengthen businesses in order to be able to move to the circular economy and this concerns at least 200 small and medium enterprises in Greece and 12,000 employees.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: - Madam President, dear Vice-Presidents, dear colleagues! At the Our Ocean Conference in Malta there was a huge plastic albatross right in front of the event building - Mr Timmermans, you saw it - precisely from the amount of plastic that gets into the sea every second - that was terrifying. Prince Charles, one of the speakers, spoke of it: plastic is now on our menu. Then there was an Indian activist who urged that we stop using straws - all good ideas. It is also a good idea that we have the revision of the port reception directive. But there is a lot more that just needs to be discussed. I recently competed in a young people's circular economy competition. There was a young woman there who developed furniture from plastic waste from the sea. I know a journalist in Germany - a family man - who has given up journalism and is now developing a consumer seal for plastic-free consumer goods. There are quite a few of these: in cosmetics, in clothing - we just have to bring it forward. For example, in the European Parliament we can see that we no longer use plastic bottles. One more thing: There is still a large plastic exhibition from the G7. I collected signatures with several colleagues from Parliament. If all goes well, we will have this exhibition in Brussels in April in front of our Parliament. Even now - if it works - I ask you that we all meet again there.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Madam President, the market and its sacralization have imposed unsustainable irrational practices and behaviors with regard to the use of disposable goods, showing enormous disrespect and contempt even for the physical limits of the planet. It is essential that the production and use of disposable and useless products be reduced, but we are not going with the market approaches recommended by the European Commission or with the so-called economic instruments. The application of the polluter pays principle, which means reserving the right to pollute to anyone who can pay it, does not make that pollution less harmful by the fact that someone, in this case consumers, pays for it. There is nothing to prevent an end to the distribution, unpaid or not, of unnecessary and non-biodegradable plastic bags. That the proliferation of unnecessary packaging be attacked and that reusable packaging be encouraged by the distributor, removing its cost from the consumer, more, making it no longer a cost, either economic or environmental. It is that, in the waste management hierarchy, before recycling comes the reduction.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - So, plastic is becoming an increasing destroyer of our planet. Europeans throw away as much as 25 million tonnes of plastic waste a year, and less than 30% is recycled. Disposable plastics account for half of the waste at sea and on the coast, and as we have been able to hear, by 2050 there is expected to be more plastic in the sea than fish. According to some estimates, about a billion animals die each year from plastic bags. These are just some of the horrifying data that point to the seriousness of the consequences of plastic waste. Some even link and compare the plastic pollution crisis to climate change. Well, and finally, the European Commission has presented a strategy to combat plastic waste, which should be welcomed and strived to be as ambitious as possible, and of course I welcome the proposals aimed at reducing plastic consumption and promoting recycling. Our attitude towards the planet we live on is truly reprehensible, so our sobriety is needed, because if we already have microplastics in water and salt and in the air, we are facing a serious test in the future.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, I would like to congratulate the Commission on this proposal. I think that there is rarely an item on the agenda that unites us as much as this plastic strategy of yours has united us. Since they say that the picture speaks more than a thousand words, today I want to show with this picture the plastic garbage that flooded the southern coast of Croatia, that is, the city of Dubrovnik, of which I am still a resident and former mayor. So the city, which is under UNESCO protection, is under plastic rubbish from neighboring countries that want to be candidates for the European Union. Therefore, I take this opportunity to appeal to the Commission and to all of us to be strict when it comes to environmental chapters. There are a number of conventions, there is the Barcelona Convention and many directives. However, these countries do not adhere to that. Therefore, this is a unique opportunity for us all to finally reflect on our destiny. I agree with all the statements so far here regarding garbage and plastics. Let's not repeat ourselves, but tighten the rules, make regulations. So the strategy is yes, but as fast as possible with directives and as fast as possible with regulations that will unite us even more and free us from this scourge that definitely has an impact on human health.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Madam President, gentlemen Presidents! May I thank you for the strategy that you have presented to us. Because there is a long way to go between plastic is fantastic and ban on all plastics. What you have suggested to us here is a very balanced approach. We don't want to do without plastic. I believe plastic will continue to have its place in our lives in the future. But the sometimes thoughtless and often very irresponsible use of plastic in our society, in our economy, has made plastic and the products that are made from it a threat to health, the environment and people. The aim of this strategy is to ensure that, on the one hand, production takes place safely, that recycling and reuse of the products are sensible and desirable for people, the environment and health, and that, on the other hand, those products that do not do justice to the concept of sustainability will disappear from the market. For me, of course, this also includes all microplastics. I would ask you to take real action in this regard as soon as possible so that we also have legislation as soon as possible.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I can be brief. Seldom in my three years in this Parliament have I experienced such a unity of purpose. Everyone agrees that we need to do something; perhaps not everyone agrees on the measures we need to take or the speed with which we will do it. But let me give you one guarantee: this Commission will try everything it can to put on your table legislative proposals in those areas where we can come up with legislation. We’ve already started with REACH on micro-plastics in cosmetics, paints and in detergents, but sometimes we need more analysis. How are we going to deal with micro-plastics coming out of tyres on cars or coming out of our clothes when we wash them? These are complicated things and we want to make sure we get the science right before we put legislation on the table. And as far as packaging is concerned, we will be extremely ambitious and we will come up with legislation, and we want this to happen very quickly. But we’ve also seen that the unity of purpose in this room is shared by industry: by and large they want to be part of this. They know they need to be part of this. We need to create the circumstances for them to be part of it and for it to become a profitable business. But I believe that plastics will continue to have a huge role in our society. I’m not an enemy of plastics. Plastics can be fantastic if they’re the right plastics, and we need to get the science right. That’s why we’re putting EUR 100 million extra into research through Horizon 2020. So I see the message you gave to us today as a strong endorsement for this Commission to continue along this path. This is what we will do – and this is a promise I make on behalf of all of us – we will make proposals for legislation where we can. But we will not rush into things, especially if we haven’t got the science right yet or if we can still wait for industry to do its part. If industry won’t do its part we will step in. But I have the feeling that given the sense of urgency that is shared by industry, we will be able to do a lot of things together as well. If we do this in a holistic way, if it is part of our circular economy, if it is part of the fourth industrial revolution and the benefits it brings, we will lead in the world and make sure that the health of our children and grandchildren will not suffer and our environment will not suffer more than it already does as a result of the waste of plastics. (Applause)

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for your strong support. This debate made me really happy, and I do believe that we can deliver. Thank you very much for the ideas. I have four points: firstly, why do recycled plastics not account for more than 6% of the entire volume of plastics used? It is because we don’t have European-wide quality standards for recycled plastic, and this we will change. We need a single market tool for recycled plastics. Why don’t we recycle more packaging waste, plastic bags and waste? Because there are too many different types of plastics used for packaging. So that’s why we want to change this. We need quality standards and other standards in order to create a more harmonised approach for producing plastic packages. This enables us to create a single market. These two measures enable us to create a well-functioning single market for plastics. Secondly, we also need to look at the regulatory framework for biodegradable and compostable plastics. You are right that bio products can be an alternative source for producing more sustainable plastics, but we need to get this regulatory framework right. Our consumers must also know that you cannot mix biodegradable plastics with oil-based plastics, otherwise recycling is impossible. So we have to encourage or empower consumers. Thirdly, we certainly need more innovations. Horizon 2020 has already financed plastic-related innovations worth EUR 250 million during this period, and an additional 100 million will be made available. Furthermore, FC and structural funds can provide public financing. But even more money is available in private sector if the regulatory environment is right, and that’s why we have to concentrate on this part of our work. Fourthly, on China. I must say that I could not blame China at all when they decided to ban plastic waste imports. I must congratulate them. It’s actually a good incentive for Europe to find solutions, sustainable solutions. How to deal with plastic waste. It puts pressure on us, but it also create incentives. It will change the market, and this is what we need: a sustainable market where profit is coming from more sustainable behaviour. Finally, thank you once again very much for an excellent discussion. (Applause)

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing. - Last September, the European Commission presented its industrial strategy to enable European companies to be more competitive. Among the stated objectives is the desire to massively and efficiently recycle plastics in Europe. The recycling rate in the EU is only 22%, a level considered too low. A new strategy is therefore essential, not only to encourage good practice but also to resolve the difficulties encountered by the plastics industry sector. As we know, the obstacles to better recycling are essentially technical and economic. Indeed, there is a cost gap between virgin plastics and recycled plastics, which comes at the expense of the latter. In addition, the recent decision by China to ban the import of certain plastic waste from Europe offers us a real opportunity to create the conditions for an internal market for recycled materials. Establishing such a market will also require investments in plastic recycling infrastructure, the cost of which should be borne by both companies and public authorities. Yes, we need plastics, but quality and recyclable plastics.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – Eight million tons of plastic end up in the sea every year; 80% of litter in the oceans is plastic; 85% of beach litter is plastic. According to UN estimates, by 2050 practically 100% of seabirds will have ingested plastic, and around 600 marine species will be harmed by plastic. I welcome the Commission’s strategy to address the usage of plastic in Europe, where 25 million tons of plastic waste is generated every year, of which only 30% is collected for recycling. Whereas this strategy is a step in right direction, it still fails to target the problem as a whole. The EC strategy focuses primarily on circular economy, on developing bio-degradable and reusable plastic. We eat plastic, we breathe in plastic in the environment. Plastic is everywhere. It should be a European goal to dramatically reduce the usage of plastic to a minimum, especially when it comes to packaging. It is not enough merely to ban single-use plastic bags. I call on the Commission to go far beyond its current proposal and offer a vision of a plastic-free Europe. We need an ambitious goal to save the next generation from drowning in a new ocean of waste.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - The European Commission has not yet delivered binding rules in the context of the European Union's Plastics Strategy. There must be no room for disposable plastics in the current and future economies of the European Union. Such plastic - its production, use and disposal, in addition to being environmentally unsafe and its effect on the health of citizens is still unknown, is also contrary to the potential of the circular economy. In order to make full use of these potentials, products must not contain toxic substances such as those found in, for example, disposable plastic bags and other plastic products. Europe produces 25 million tonnes of plastic waste each year, of which less than 30% is recycled. Also, as much as 85% of waste on beaches is plastic, if we are talking about the world level. The European Commission should therefore include as soon as possible appropriate plans for strong measures to limit toxic and hazardous substances used in the production of environmentally harmful oxo-plastics and microplastics. For this reason, I welcome any future effort by the European Union to eliminate toxic substances from plastic products, reduce their use and increase the level of reuse and recycling of relevant waste.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Tadeusz Zwiefka, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters and the matters of parental responsibility (COM (2016) 0411 - C8-0322 / 2016 - 2016/0190 (CNS))

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: rapporteur. - Madam President! I would like to point out at the outset that although we have worked and are still working on the recasting of this regulation in accordance with a special legislative procedure which establishes the European Parliament in a consultative role only, and the Council acting unanimously as the sole legislator, it is the work that had to be done right here We took up our House in the European Parliament with full enthusiasm and - I think - we have done it really well. Therefore, I would like to start with a thank you. First of all, I would like to thank the European Commission for preparing a really good project to recast the Brussels IIa Regulation. I would like to thank my fellow Members in the Committee on Legal Affairs, and in particular the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I really had a great pleasure and satisfaction to work on this very regulation. Although the Commission's proposal was indeed rated as very good, Parliament has made some of its own proposals which, I strongly believe, improve the Commission's proposal while at the same time making the Council want to reflect on our comments as well. I would like to raise a few of the most important points. First, the question of hearing the child. For us, this is a key point in this regulation, because we believe that in a parental dispute over the exercise of parental responsibility or the issue of child abduction, the so-called parental abduction, the child is unfortunately the weakest party and this side must be absolutely protected. A child must be the subject of this case, and God forbid, not an object, which is why we put so much emphasis on all the elements that allow the child to maintain the best possible position. Of course, we cannot order that the child be heard on all matters. This decision remains independent for the court, but what we are introducing as a novelty is the necessity to justify a negative decision in when the court decides not to hold a hearing. We also draw attention to the fact that these hearings should be based on certain common standards. They should take place in a child-friendly atmosphere, i.e. it can be outside the court. They should be carried out by a specialized judge or a prepared expert, without the influence of third parties and without pressure from parents, and thus also without their participation. This is a very important point. We suggest that in these matters related to the exercise of parental responsibility, consideration of the possibility of conducting or using mediation as an alternative method of dispute resolution. Mediation offers various possibilities, greater than the court, it also shortens the time of the proceedings and, of course, allows you to save considerable expenses. Another issue that I want to draw attention to is the issue of placing a child outside his / her biological family, i.e. in a foster family or in an educational and care facility, by a court decision. I added my proposal, adopted by the Committee on Legal Affairs, to the Commission's proposal, so that the court could consider, when taking this decision, the possibility of leaving the child in the family residing in the country where the case is pending. This is a very, very useful solution for long-term cases. We are pleased to welcome the Commission's proposals to abolish the exequatur procedure, i.e. to abandon the need to confirm processes carried out in other Member States of the European Union, which has already been tested in other cases. Thank you for the opportunity to give this introduction. I will be curious to listen to the debate and then comment on it.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Brussels IIa Regulation is a key tool to navigating cross-border legal issues in family matters and to providing protection for children. Its revision addresses the shortcomings regarding parental responsibility proceedings which have also been flagged in the past by the honourable Members.  I am very happy that the Commission and Parliament have a common goal. We want to prevent that, in cross-border cases, children end up being taken hostages of long disputes. We also want to facilitate the procedures for families by various means including by reducing the length and cost of these procedures. Before I speak about Parliament’s amendments, I would like first to express my thanks to our rapporteur, Mr Zwiefka, for the excellent cooperation on this file. I am delighted that the report acknowledges that time and a smooth return to family life is of essence for children’s welfare and their relationship with their parents. In particular, I very much welcome the measures included in the report aiming to substantially reduce delays in returning children who were abducted by one of their parents. These are in line with the Commission’s proposal. These measures will imply in practice less cumbersome procedures for parents and quicker decisions by judges in cross-border cases. This will result in giving children back the stability they need and deserve, and an earlier return to family life.  Facilitating enforcement of judgments once decisions are taken is another crucial aspect to ensure the rights of children and their families. The abolishment of the intermediate procedures to obtain cross-border enforcement of judgments will make this possible. This will avoid costs and delays, whilst maintaining the necessary safeguards to ensure, for instance, the rights of the defence. Therefore, I welcome Parliament’s support for this measure in this respect. Concerning the amendments on the rights of the child to be heard in the proceedings, I take note of Parliament’s wish for their to be common minimum standards at EU level – to be proposed by the Commission – such as referring to the practical arrangements of the hearing. We have carefully assessed such a possibility.  However, given that the existing rules and practices in Member States in this area are extremely divergent, we find it more efficient to rely on existing standards laid down in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, to which all Member States have already subscribed. Therefore, I hope to have this particular rule accepted in the final version of the new instrument.  As you all know, strengthening the rights of the child is a top priority for the Commission. Our proposal in this area will ensure that children are given an opportunity to be heard in legal proceedings concerning them. Mutual recognition of Member States’ practices in this respect will avoid refusals at the recognition or enforcement stage, thus allowing true circulation of judgments in the European Union.  For the sake of efficiency and in order to avoid overlaps we have not included specific rules on mediation for conflicts between parents, as requested by Parliament. The existing Mediation Directive already covers efficient mediation mechanisms in these situations and foresees support for parents in resolving their conflicts. Finally, I have noticed that Parliament’s amendments focus also on close cooperation between Member States’ authorities. Here again, we speak with one voice. Central authorities are the direct interface with parents and should play a key role in supporting judges in applying the regulation. The report and the proposed amendments reflect the need for more efficient cooperation.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. – Madam President, I too would like to thank the rapporteur. What we are discussing today is a sensitive issue that has a direct impact on thousands of citizens, particularly children living across the EU. So it is our duty to ensure that both children and parents who act in good faith are protected. There are too many cases of international child abduction by one of the parents for us not to act, and our guiding principle is that child abduction is detrimental to the fundamental rights of any child, wherever he or she is.  It is a fact that the world we are living in is changing, and family law issues also change because family law issues that, before, were exclusively dealt with within national states now require international application. As international relationships and marriages increase, so do international custody disputes. In the Committee on Petitions we deal with cases of parents being deprived of their children, illegally taken away from them by the other parent, and that is why we believe that any proposal has to be more effective and ensure the best interests of the child.  This is precisely why we need to close all loopholes and make sure that the regulation is not interpreted in a way that favours the parent responsible for the wrongful removal of a child. We need to make sure that the court of the Member State of origin of the child is the one that takes the final decision in this respect. And we have to reduce, if not eliminate, forum shopping and ensure the interests of both parents are protected and, most importantly, reduce any possible harm to the children involved. I believe that this is the only way through which we can ensure effective judicial protection of the fundamental rights of children across the EU, wherever they are.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: for the PPE Group. - Allow me to thank all my colleagues in the JURI Committee, in particular our rapporteur, Tadeusz Zwiefk, for the work they have done in discussing this report. I want to assure all citizens that today we are discussing here a proposal for a new version of important legislation that affects many citizens. We register around 16 million international families in the EU. Unfortunately, we also register 140,000 international divorces a year and, worst of all, 1,800 cases of child abduction by one parent each year. Regulations governing jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters and parental leave have been in force since 2005, with the exception of Denmark. However, experience has shown that the current wording can be improved for the benefit of children in particular. It must also be ensured that this regulation only improves procedural rules. Substantive law, such as the definition of marriage, is not covered by this Regulation. Subsidiarity is respected. The Regulation also applies only to so-called cross-border cases, ie cases where each spouse has the nationality of another state. It is in the interest of the JURI and this House as a whole that this legislation be adopted because it pursues the best interests of the child, and I can say on behalf of the JURI Committee that we have dealt with this issue, this aspect of the new proposal, very carefully.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! Mr Svoboda just mentioned it: far more people than before are living together and are aware of these achievements of the European Union, of European citizenship. Of course, there is also a downside: not all marriages that are concluded are successful in the end. When I was the mediator of the European Parliament, I saw the suffering of the children who are affected by child abduction, and I have to say that these are not nice stories to be witnessed. That is why I was very pleasantly surprised to find that the European Commission had taken up a large number of the proposals that I was drafting at the time to improve the law in this area and incorporated them into the draft. That is a good thing. In particular, there must be better cooperation between the courts and the authorities, faster cooperation, because the longer such proceedings last, the worse it becomes, especially for the children. And the legal certainty associated with it is also required. Another area that is extremely important is hearing the children. We have to ensure that the rights they have under the UN resolution are actually realized. We have to ensure that children can be heard in a child-friendly way, in their own language, but also in such a way that they can be asked in a protected setting and not in a room that can be very impossible for children, such as a courtroom is. We have to be very careful that the framework conditions are correct and also acceptable for the children. Another point - and I am very grateful to Mr Zwiefka for that, as we worked very well together - is the question of mediation. Yes, we have regulations on mediation in the European Union, but they are not yet sufficient. The It is not enough if we see that the courts do not take advantage of the possibilities that exist. We have to ensure that less well-off parents in particular do not have to bear the associated costs alone, because the very questions that have to be asked - this mediation - can lead to - as you, Mr Zwiefka, rightly said - Costs are saved because the procedures can be faster, such procedures may not even be necessary, and are also better for the parents and for the children concerned. So a very important question. However, I still have to address one last point, and we could not agree on that, Mr Zwiefka and I simply disagreed, and unfortunately neither has Parliament so far: it is the question of registered partnerships. I cannot understand why the children from registered partnerships in which there are problems do not have the same rights as the children from marriages. We'll have to rework that in the future, because that's actually unbearable.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! When two fight, the third cries - a slightly modified wisdom that describes well what children experience when their parents get divorced. It is all the more important to always put the best interests of the child at the forefront of a separation process. Germany has a special duty here. Our federal government urgently needs to revise divorce and family law. We need a consistent change model, like almost all other European countries. The many petitions to the European Parliament regarding the work of the German youth welfare offices show me that we need comprehensive reform here too. For over a year I accompanied a French mother and her daughter in this difficult fight. Today the verdict was in their favor. Germany, move! Many families benefit from this in divorce disputes. The separation fathers, who are still disadvantaged to this day, benefit from this and the children benefit because both parents remain with them. Europe can provide valuable impetus to get German politics moving. Let's do it for the benefit of our children!

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. Madam President, the increase in the number of couples of different nationalities necessitates the improvement and clarification of European Union law on international jurisdiction, the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial and parental disputes, and the international abduction of children. Legal uncertainty must be put an end to, as well as unnecessary delays in related cases that negatively affect the families involved. Emphasis must be placed on protecting the interests of children, including refugees. Specialized training of judges and the strengthening of the subsidiary institution of mediation are also needed. We still need to consolidate jurisdiction over the international abduction of children in specialized courts and to rationalize the reasons for any refusal to enforce relevant foreign judgments. On this basis, I agree with the report by MEP Mr Zwiefka, which we are discussing today, and I will vote in favor of it.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposed recast of the Brussels II bis regulation has lights and shadows. The rules aimed at facilitating the recognition of sentences and at minimizing the possibilities of international child abduction are welcome. In particular, the introduction of the principle according to which the protection of the child's best interests and related fundamental rights must take precedence over all other rights is welcomed. Also appreciable is the request for ad hoc training for the judicial staff of the Member States, especially in the field of family law. However, serious doubts remain, first of all the encouragement to resort to mediation in the matter of custody rights, a solution that does not give sufficient guarantees of impartiality. Furthermore, the concept of habitual residence has not been adequately clarified and sufficient guarantees have not been given to avoid the risk that the judges of some Member States take decisions in favor of their citizens, without taking into account the sentences of colleagues from other countries.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, cross-border child abduction is a serious problem. In France, it particularly affects children from Franco-German couples. When these couples separate, German parents frequently take their children to Germany, even though French justice has entrusted their custody to French parents. Several of these victimized parents have complained to me about the inertia of the European Union. I am delighted today to see that their suffering has been heard. The Zwiefka report should indeed make it easier for them to recover their children. Among the measures he puts forward, three seem particularly promising. First, the reduction in return times for children to a maximum of 18 weeks. Then, the establishment in each European state of national judges specializing in child abduction. Finally, the strengthening of the role of national central authorities guaranteeing the effectiveness of the system in each state. That is why I will vote for the Zwiefka report.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: - Madam President, indeed, international cross-border marriage conflicts have increased because this is a reality that is increasing. There are sixteen million international families. There are 140,000 divorces a year in the European Union and also 1,800 cases of child abduction. Indeed, it is an issue that addresses the legal cornerstone that is this "Brussels II bis" Regulation, which we are dealing with today and which is a Regulation that has had benefits because it has helped this judicial cooperation, but, obviously, a few years after the application, we have been able to verify that it has had deficits and difficulties. Difficulties have been described here in what is judicial cooperation, difficulties in what are foster care, difficulties in the protection of the minor, in the necessary elimination of the exequatur, in the execution of decisions and, above all, the legal uncertainty that many times it has hosted and unnecessary delays, which have always hindered the interest of the minor, because if the interest of the minor is already complicated when a separation occurs, it is even more so when this situation is unnecessarily prolonged. Therefore, this revision of this Regulation is welcome to be able to improve legal certainty, to be more effective, to be able to bet on mediation, to be able to bet on a harmonious resolution and, above all, to protect itself, without any doubt, the interest of the minor, which is what concerns us in this case. We will have thus made Europe closer to its citizens and that we are truly effective and agile in protecting human rights.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: - Madam President! A child-friendly Europe must be what we all strive for. It is a good Europe for all of us. Children should not have to experience harsher conflicts than those concerning how many of these you can get or how many fairy tales it can be to the gruel for the evening. Unfortunately, this is not the case in our Europe. We have, and it is gratifying, a high incidence of cross-border family creation, but it also means that as many as 16 million people have cross-border disputes and 1,800 child abductions take place in the Union. These are children who end up in trouble. Revising the regulations is therefore very important if we want to put the best interests of the children first. The rules have many times today been characterized by confusion, legal uncertainty and unnecessary delays. For me and for my political group, it has been very important to put the children first in the first room, and then the children must have a say. I am very happy that we want to secure it by tomorrow's vote. I have also pushed, and our group has pushed, for the regulation to include registered partnerships. I am disappointed that the Conservatives did not agree. There are children who end up in trouble because you did not want to go any further and also help these children. But finally, I would like to say that the cornerstone of the regulation must be that the will of the children is put at the center.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank my colleague Zwiefk for a report which, without interfering with national competences, addresses the serious and practical problem of international child abduction. And I also thank my colleagues for the inspiring contributions and views you give on this topic. The breakdown of a marriage is always a tragedy that threatens the development of children. When a child becomes hostage to a dispute between two arguing spouses who were supposed to be his loving parents, it is a loss to all parties. All the more so if the voices of the children have not been heard, in which country and with which parents they want to live. The heartbreaking cases of abducted children by their own parents in other Member States have faced the inability of European judicial mechanisms to stop this madness. I trust that this Parliament will continue in the set trend and the rights of children in any situation and at any stage of development it will unconditionally respect. And I want to use this word to point out those children who are still only in the womb and have not yet had time to be born. We must also respect and protect these rights.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a multitude of European citizens continue to denounce with the instrument of petitions very serious violations of those fundamental rights that this report aims to protect more effectively in matters of the best interests of the child and parental responsibility. Complaints mostly focus on procedures, mechanisms and practices implemented in practice by the Jugendamt in Germany, recognizing multiple discrimination against non-German parents. There is also an insufficient willingness on the part of the German authorities to offer full and genuine cooperation at present. As long as full light is not brought to light on this matter, which has been dragging on for too long, the more rapid circulation of judicial decisions that is intended to be obtained with this provision will produce a simple consequence, that is to aggravate intolerable injustices which, on the contrary, should be fought by starting to intensify controls and punctual checks in the Member States on the conduct of the competent authorities in matters of parental responsibility and effective guarantee of the well-being of the minors involved.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: - Naħseb naqblu li nassiguraw il-protezzjoni tat-tfal minn xi forma ta ’periklu dejjem kienet parti intrinsika mill-valuri tagħna bħala Evropej. U dan nistgħu nkomplu nwettquh permezz ta ’titjib biex nirregolaw kaži internazzjonali ta’ abdikazzjoni tat-tfal. L-importanza ta ’mižuri legali huma ċari u joħorġu b’saħħithom. Niftakar f'każ anki f'Malta fejn missier kellu l-problema li minkejja li kellu l-ordni favur il-kustodja mill-qrati Maltin, kellu problemi kbar biex dik ikun jista 'jinfurzaha fi Stat Membru ieħor f'każ fejn fil-fatt it-tifel kien maħtuf minn ommu u miżmum f'pajjiż ieħor. Hawnhekk qed nitkellmu fuq każijiet reali u każijiet li jolqtu aspett tal-ħajja mill-iktar importanti tal-persuni umani. Dawn ir-regolamenti naturalment għandhom il-vantaġġ li ser jagħmlu r-ritorn tat-tfal li jkunu ġew maħtufa ħafna iktar effiċjenti permezz ta 'żmien stipulat għall-proċess, permezz tal-introduzzjoni tal-medjazzmeni u fki a millar mill-aħħar l-iskop prinċipali tagħhom huwa li jinfurzaw prinċipju li għalina huwa għażiż ħafna: il-prinċipju li l-akbar u l-aktar interest importanti huwa dejjem dak tat-tfal u li t-tfal għandhom id-tagritiet jridu jkunu dejjem imħarsa.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for a regulation we are discussing intervenes appropriately for a necessary updating of the legal framework aimed at overcoming the criticalities that too often arise in the execution, in the various European countries, of decisions in matrimonial matters, in general, and in cases of international child abduction, which in fact end up being disputed for a long time, too long, by parents following international divorces. I particularly appreciate in the report the introduction, in these procedures, of the hearing of the child, essential for the child to be able to express his / her opinions in the proceedings concerning him, as foreseen by the international charters, so as to be able to provide the competent authority with all the elements for the evaluation of his, exclusively his, superior interest. And it is important that the hearing of the child takes place according to common standards, with methods aimed at ensuring due caution to avoid interference, disturbances, conditioning and trauma for the child. Particularly appreciable is also the introduction of a maximum deadline for the completion of the procedures for the return of the child, a provision which, together with the concentration of the competence for the abduction of minors at specialized authorities, will be able to speed up the return procedures avoiding subject to long periods of legal uncertainty. I therefore thank the rapporteur and my colleagues from the JURI committee for their excellent work.

name: Emil RADEV
text: - Madam President, I would like to congratulate and thank the rapporteur, Mr Tsviefka, for a wonderful report. I am glad that many of the amendments I have proposed have been included in the final text of the report. I now hope that, despite the European Parliament's advisory role on this issue, our voice will be heard by the Council and our proposals taken into account. I believe that our proposals will contribute to better protecting the interests of children in the procedures for determining or withdrawing parental responsibility and in the event of divorce or separation of their parents, as well as in cases of child abduction in the Union. In this reform, strengthening cooperation between Member States' central authorities is key. The issue of equal treatment of the parties in divorce proceedings and in the deprivation of parental responsibility is also important. In the case of international couples, each country must be fully and promptly informed of all measures taken in a language it fully understands. The most important point of our proposals, however, concerns the consistency in the upbringing of the child, his ethnic origin, religion, culture and language. In particular, in cases of long-term placement of a child, the authorities should always consider accommodation with relatives and family members, even if they live in another country. It must be ensured that the child's parents and relatives can, regardless of their place of residence, have a regular personal relationship with him. I believe that the Brussels IIa Regulation must guarantee the preservation of the sovereignty of states with regard to national substantive law in the field of parental responsibility and not impose legal relations in this area which are foreign to the Member State.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I have listened with great interest to this debate.At the time when I was the Minister of Justice in the Czech Republic, I solved several examples of problems with international child abductions, when in practice it was clear how Brussels does not work, what gaps it has and I am very glad that the problems we are in practicesolved - delays in the proceedings, unclear positions of individual courts -, so in this amendment, in this amendment.I would like to thank the rapporteur, because I really feel that this amendment can have a big impact in practice, and it is good that we are dealing there with things such as special courts, such as deadlines for judicial decisions, such as special arrangements for questioning a child, which wouldshould lead to the best interests of the child being taken into account in any case.So, as a person with practical experience with this, I thank the Commission, I thank the rapporteur, and I think that this legislation can help a lot in practice.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, how could a majority of this European Parliament not approve, by a large majority, a regulation aimed at reinforcing the principle of mutual trust and mutual recognition of judicial decisions in such a sensitive and important matter How are divorce or matrimonial law disputes, but above all, child abduction in the European Union? It is a matter that I dealt with when I had the responsibility of being Minister of Justice of the Government of Spain and, therefore, I welcome all progress aimed at providing greater clarity, legal certainty, the abolition of the exequatur and, above all, to reinforce rights of the minor to be heard in any procedure that affects him. I can only regret that the amendments proposed by the Petitions Committee, which pointed out the importance of precisely reinforcing the minor in cases as painful as those that affect gender-based violence or the express recognition of the different forms, have not been successful. of filiation and, consequently, of the different forms of family that inhabit the European Union and enrich it. In any case, I welcome this Regulation and we are going to vote it favorably.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the recast of Regulation (EC) No Council Regulation (EC) No 2201/2003 on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters and in matters of parental responsibility, I consider to be particularly important. The Petitions Committee had received numerous cases involving both parental care and abduction. In fact, we have had many complaints about the operation of the special welfare service in Germany, the famous "Jugendamt", and I consider Mr Gericke's intervention very important, and I wanted to congratulate him, who really asked his country to make changes to the issue. this. It is obvious that the regulation is very important because it focuses on the best interests of the child. I consider it particularly important to be able to hear the child himself in order to issue a specific court decision. It is also very important that specialized courts be set up to deal with child abduction cases. These are the focal points and I think we are moving in the right direction.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: - Perhaps we could hear the voice of the only child present in the hall here, a colleague's child here. First of all, let me thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has done. Thanks to the ever-increasing mobility within the EU, of course, the number of international couples is also growing. Matrimonial matters and parental responsibility are areas that need to be addressed immediately. We must then pay special attention to children, including the cross-border placement, recognition and enforcement of decisions and cooperation with national authorities. International abductions by one of the parents are a separate and sad chapter. According to statistics, one child is lost in Europe every minute. In 2015, more than 60,000 kidnappings were reported.
