The aim of the recast regulation we are debating today is to improve the efficiency of the return of an abducted child. I welcome the rapporteur's approach, which is aware of the sensitivity of a number of issues and has chosen, in my opinion, a prudent but clear approach.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Madam President, it is imperative to strengthen impartial legal certainty that ensures the fundamental rights of the child and simplifies finding a solution. It is also necessary to maintain family law under the full jurisdiction and competence of the Member States, including the condition for the immediate recognition of decisions under certain conditions. Nevertheless, for emotionally charged and real issues, an attempt is being made to disrupt the rule of law and logic. Particular attention needs to be paid to the application of the Western legal approach to illegal immigrants and persons whose usual residence cannot be clarified and who deny their social and cultural integration and have different moral and humanitarian values. Respecting the Treaties, we must limit ourselves to supporting the development of appropriate infrastructure and channels of communication between Member States, without interference in family affairs and with the best interests of the child in mind.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Madam President, trying to improve European legislation on cross-border marital and parental disputes is the right thing to do.The Commission proposal respects the competences of the Member States.It allows them not to recognize and refuse to enforce decisions that are incompatible with the public policy of most Member States.However, I find four amendments limiting these competences unacceptable.Two of them require a Member State to recognize marriages that are not recognized by its legislation.And the other two could mean that states would automatically have to recognize private divorces declared, for example, by Sharia courts in Muslim countries.I would like to thank my colleague Zwiefk and I realize that he was primarily concerned with the protection of children, but if the proposal passes this wording, I will not be able to support him.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in a historical moment like this, when the mobility of people and their family members is our daily routine, there is an increasing need to regulate certain legal frameworks at the level of all members of the Union. However, it is crucial to stay within the competences of the European Union and not allow excessive legislative ambition to violate the rules of subsidiarity and to directly infringe what is the exclusive legislative power of each individual Member State. It is for this reason that I call on colleagues to vote against Amendments 19, 28, 31 and 49. By adopting these amendments, public policy in a Member State will no longer be relevant in decisions relating to parental responsibility, which directly violates . In this way, we want to abolish what the Court of Justice has established countless times, and that is the competence of a member state to determine the comprehensiveness of its own public order and policy.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I was here throughout the discussion and I reported to catch the eye.Commissioner, rapporteur, I would like to appreciate the role of the rapporteur.I really think it was a proverbial dance between eggs, because this standard is primarily a procedural standard.She has to help resolve disputes that occur as a result of just divorce.The priority of the child is guarded, and it would probably be appropriate for us to consider it a real priority, regardless of certain ideologies.It is necessary to lay down clear rules and, above all, to decide quickly according to these clear deadlines, and those deadlines are brought about by this regulation, so that the revision of the Brussels Regulation is simply very important.It is equally important, of course, to inform parents about their rights and obligations and to contribute to that mutual mediation, but mediation is no longer covered by this regulation.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. –Madam President, let me again express my thanks on behalf of the Commission for Parliament’s report and your support for this recast proposal. Your report will inspire the debate in the Council. We remain confident that under the leadership of the Bulgarian Presidency, which has chosen this as a priority, we will see progress on these files. A swift conclusion to the negotiations. will be important as it would help families in difficult situations and protect children in particular. I am sure that this will lead to the adoption of measures that will serve this very noble purpose.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: rapporteur. - I would like to sincerely thank you all for this extremely interesting discussion. Parliament is ending its participation in this legislative procedure with tomorrow's vote, but I hope that what will be the fruit of our work and voted tomorrow will indeed be an impetus for further work in the Council. I would like to reassure everyone that tomorrow - to the best of my knowledge - we will not vote any amendments to my report and, as far as I am aware, no such amendments have been tabled and it will be a single vote. Against this background, I encourage all those who have not yet decided to support this report to do so. I would like to express my sincere thanks to all the other colleagues who, on behalf of the political groups, have given their support to my report in tomorrow's vote. Ladies and gentlemen, this regulation, this procedure is of course intended to solve the problems of family life, but we are not in the slightest stepping into the scope of family law, which is the responsibility of the Member State, and we have not exceeded the subsidiarity principle in either the Commission proposal or my report . However, I would like to point out one fact that is undoubtedly extremely important, and that is that it will be a test of mutual trust in the judiciary of the Member States. And only thanks to the high level of the judiciary in particular countries, we will be able to build such trust in other future solutions.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday, 18 January 2018.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - Greater mobility of people in the EU also brings with it a higher number of marriages between people of different nationalities. These marriages do not avoid conflicts, breakups and an increase in cross-border litigation. It is therefore appropriate to facilitate both the enforcement of judgments given in another Member State and the mutual recognition of such judgments. I support the proposal to revise the Brussels II Regulation because it adapts the existing rules to this new reality. Among other things, I welcome the mandatory finding of a child's opinion in cases where the child is able to express his or her opinion on the matter at hand. I believe that this obligation will help the court to issue a decision that is in the best interests of the child. In this respect, mutual trust between Member States needs to be strengthened by recognizing these interrogations of children between Member States. The abolition of proceedings for a declaration of enforceability of judgments given in all areas covered by the Regulation will also help to strengthen this mutual trust and shorten the whole court procedure. I also consider it beneficial for proceedings on international child abduction to be conducted by specialized courts in each Member State. This specialization should increase the quality of these decisions and effectively shorten the deadlines for issuing them.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the proposal for a Council decision, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, concerning the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Marrakesh Treaty facilitating access to published works for the blind, partially sighted and otherwise printable (12629/ 2017 - C8-0375 / 2017 - 2014/0297 (NLE)) (A8-0400 / 2017).

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: rapporteur. –Madam President, today we are discussing the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, which aims to facilitate access to books for blind people and visually impaired and otherwise print-disabled persons. This will improve the lives of a very great number of people. Today when you make a copy of a book, in an EU country, into a format that blind people can read, you are mostly not allowed to bring it across a national border because that’s the way copyright is constructed. But the Marrakesh Treaty, which is a UN Treaty, seeks to liberate those books so that they can be shared freely all over the world, or at least in all the countries that have ratified the Marrakesh Treaty. This will make life better for many of the 285 million beneficiaries of this treaty, who will get access to a lot more books that they can read, and access to better educational opportunities. While this will be good for blind people inside the EU, the greatest benefit will be for blind people in those countries – especially countries where they speak English or French or Spanish or Portuguese – where access to books today is very poor by comparison with rich countries such as those in the Union. Those readers will have access to books that are already available inside the EU. So this is a great step forward and it is going to happen quite soon, hopefully in September once we ratify the treaty. It has made possible partly by the work of the European Parliament, which has been fighting for this treaty for very many years. Of course, not only the European Parliament has been fighting for it: we have been working together with blind people’s organisations and with libraries, as well as a great number of concerned citizens all over the world, to make this possible. It has not always been easy. Some Member States were, let’s say, more protective of their publishing interests than they were interested in standing up for the rights of blind people, and they were very cautious, very reluctant, but we are argued them down. This is a huge step forward. What is the next step once we ratify this treaty? Well, in many Member States in the EU today there are discussions about how to implement the treaty, and some governments are considering compensation schemes – a possibility that is, in fact, allowed – to compensate publishers for the income that they will lose when blind people do not buy their books because they can get them freely through libraries with the help of the Marrakesh Treaty. I do not really understand why compensation schemes are necessary but some Member States insisted on them. I would just like to remind those governments that the implementation provisions include rules to make sure that compensation schemes which have to be paid for by libraries and blind people’s organisations shall not be an excessive burden on them. I think I speak for many people in this Chamber when I say to the governments who are considering how to implement the treaty that we will be watching them. (Applause)

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission would like to express its deep satisfaction with the fact that the legislative file on the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty is now entering its final stages. The draft Council decision is on the table, and the EP is voting on its position regarding its consent. The Marrakesh Treaty aims to substantially improve access to books, journals and other printed texts for persons who are blind, visually impaired or who have other disabilities that prevent them from reading in the same way as persons without those disabilities. This objective is very important. Even today, too few print materials can be accessed by people with brain disabilities worldwide. Addressing this problem is fundamental for social inclusion and social advancement. Doing so will benefit people with brain disabilities, and it will benefit everybody else. The Marrakesh Treaty has been an important priority for the Commission for a long time, and we would like to support the statements made by the rapporteur of this file, Mr Andersson. Together with the adoption by the European Union of the directive and regulation implementing the Marrakesh Treaty into the EU’s legal framework on 13 September 2017, the ratification of the Treaty means that the European Union will soon be in a position to participate in the exchange of books and other print materials in formats accessible for the beneficiaries, as envisioned by the Treaty. We will therefore give our full support to this proposal, and we hope that the legislative procedure can be brought to a swift end.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, indeed, the Marrakesh Treaty means facilitating access to published works for people who are blind or have some visual impairment. And we know that there are 2.5 million blind people in Europe and more than 25 million visually impaired people on our continent. Until now, they only had access to less than 5% of the works in accessible format. Thanks to this Marrakesh Treaty, which began to be negotiated in 2013 and whose ratification we are completing today, these millions of people will be able to access, in accessible format, thousands and thousands of books and we will be able to fix the reading famine. It is a historic moment because we achieved with this decision that there is an impact on the accessibility of people with visual difficulties, with a format that can be Braille, it can be large print, large reading, audiobooks ... We managed, without a doubt, to remedy - it I have said - the reading famine, but we also achieve that millions of people can access education, can access employment and can access full inclusion. We always defend a Europe for all, an inclusive Europe, an inclusive Europe. And today, with this decision, we show off everything we stand for. Let us not forget that the glue of European sentiments is precisely values. And today walking together makes sense, today it makes sense that Europe has life and life expectancy, and that we invite with this decision a greater commitment to the dignity of people. Without any doubt, after this decision - which will soon see the light of day - our commitment to human rights becomes superlative and, without any doubt, today we are proud to be European and today we really show off European patriotism .

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: for the S&D group. - Madam President! I would like to thank my colleague Max Andersson from the Green Group, who has led the negotiations, and the rest of all colleagues involved, because this is a historic debate and a historic vote that will take place. This man should have slept, but he wants to be part of this occasion, I think. As many as 120,000 Swedes are considered visually impaired and 10,000 are blind. Across the EU, the figure is 30 million people and globally it is 285 million. These have the right to accessibility and deserve more opportunities for talking books, Braille books or visual interpretations in different languages. It is a prerequisite for democratic participation and the opportunity to be culturally involved and be able to take part in the cultural debate and the offer. I and my Social Democratic Party are very proud that we have finally completed the negotiations to transpose the Marrakesh Treaty into EU law. For the first time in EU history, copyright exemptions are now being harmonized at EU level for those in great need. It's not a day too early. The EU's ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty has long been extremely important in order to give blind, visually impaired and other people with reading or visual difficulties the right to read literature and visual interpretation in different languages. Due to some opposition from some EU countries, we have during the negotiations been concerned about how the proposal could be diluted and not provide sufficient access to books for the visually impaired. However, the agreement from 13 September is generally good, which we are very happy about. Therefore, I would urge all Member States to really make sure to transpose national laws in this area as soon as possible, so that books and e-books can be transferred to readable media for the visually impaired without cumbersome copyright fees. The adoption of the Marrakesh Treaty is an important reform of global equality. I also just want to say briefly that in some countries it is as low as one percent who have access to books.The fact that we are now approving this means increased availability in Africa, South America and Southeast Asia.It is also extremely important.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, the Marrakesh Treaty was adopted in June 2013. It falls within a framework of international treaties on intellectual property rights. It has a strong humanitarian and social dimension since what it forms is a series of mandatory exceptions in favor of the blind, in favor of people with visual impairments, in order to be able to read publications in published works. But it took a lot of fighting. We had a lot of discussions in the Committee on Petitions. There has been a lot of pressure from the European Parliament. An opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union had to be issued in February 2017 to finally pave the way for the ratification of this treaty, which is really an important step forward for the European Union itself, as it now supports people with disabilities and especially those with vision problems.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, as few as only 5% of the books published in the EU are being translated for people with visual disabilities, and not even one single percent in the developing countries. In other words, the opportunities and the world as such presented to people with visual impairments are much narrower than for others. Not only because they cannot access the same number of books as others but also because books are a key to education.  I am a firm believer, as are most of my colleagues in this House, in equal opportunities for everybody. Two years ago my committee, the Committee on Petitions, put forward a resolution on this topic urging the Member States to ratify the Marrakech Treaty. Tomorrow this House has an absolutely unique power to greatly improve equality by voting in favour of the Marrakech Treaty. This will not only be a big step towards increasing the variety of books translated into Braille but also towards equal opportunities.  Sadly, the world is not at all fair. Fair education for all is a faraway dream for too many. Rich countries have lots of books and smaller numbers of visually impaired persons. Poor countries, on the other hand, suffer from the opposite: they have too many blind people and visually impaired people and too few books. The aim of the Marrakech Treaty is to bridge this gap.  On the other hand, protection of intellectual property is crucial. In its legal essence the Marrakech Treaty is a copyright exemption but it is a proportionate one, a justified one, because the essence of its aim is equal opportunities for all and in the end a much more inclusive and educated world.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - First of all, let me thank and congratulate the rapporteur for his work. Thanks to the Marrakesh Treaty, more than 300 million blind, visually impaired and people with reading disabilities will be given access to books and other printed materials, which complicates the copyright that colleague Wikström spoke about today. People who are blind, visually impaired or have reading difficulties continue to face obstacles in accessing books and other printed materials. The need to increase the number of works and other subject matter in accessible formats, such as Braille, audiobooks and large print, has finally been recognized internationally. This will allow the persons and organizations concerned to make copies of the works in accessible formats and to distribute them throughout the EU and in third countries which are parties to the contract. This will increase their access to education and the possibility of full participation in life.

name: Julia REDA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, this treaty has been 10 years in the making. It took the tireless work of human-rights defenders such as James Love to initiate the treaty, and it has taken the rapporteur, the entire Parliament, including former Members, and the Commission to get Member States finally to accept it. Thanks to them, millions of Europeans and hundreds of millions around the world who are blind or partially sighted will finally get access to accessible books. Over those 10 years we had to overcome relentless resistance from those who wanted to stop or water down the treaty. That list includes, among others, the pharmaceutical industry, the film industry and other intellectual property holders because the very idea of an intellectual property treaty that is there to protect users and not rights holders is offensive to them. They called the access of blind people to books, and I quote, ‘an unbalanced privilege’. It is not a privilege: it is a human right enshrined in the Convention on Rights of People with Disabilities, the right of equal access to information and culture. This equal right means that Member States should not charge blind people’s organisation any compensation for making books accessible. So let us remind the Member States that this is a humanitarian treaty, not a new income source for publishers. And let's make sure that Member States implement this treaty properly and don’t charge people with disabilities extra for enjoying the same access to knowledge that we all already have.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has finally decided to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty, which is a fundamental legal act in the implementation of the rights of blind or visually impaired people. The treaty was signed in 2014 but never ratified due to the Council's reluctance, with great prejudice for all the rights of people with visual impairment. Ratification by the European Union therefore represents a moment of great importance and finally, after years of pressure and battles waged against the Council, we can say that we have made it. Blind or visually impaired people will finally have their rights recognized. We can therefore only congratulate ourselves. It is an act which allows for the concrete implementation of the principle of equality and which demonstrates how the European Union, when it wishes, can work in the right direction. It is decisions like these that give meaning to the European project and allow European citizens to understand the added value of this Union, which too often deals only with banks and finance, and too little about rights, especially the rights of the weakest. I therefore invite all my colleagues to vote positively tomorrow. Tomorrow's vote will truly be remembered as a historic moment in the recognition of fundamental rights and the importance of dissemination and accessibility to culture.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, tomorrow we will vote on the Council's decision to conclude the Marrakesh Treaty. This aims to facilitate access to published works for the blind and visually impaired and people with other print disabilities. This vote will mark a decisive step for Europe in a process that began in 2009 within the World Intellectual Property Organization. This process culminated in the adoption of this treaty in 2013. The effective application of the directive and regulation adopted on September 13th and implementing the treaty will be enabled by this ratification. As a Frenchwoman, from an eminently literary country, I would like to thank all those who made such a treaty possible. I can only reiterate my satisfaction with this progress in favor of all these people who will finally be able to have access to a larger part of our heritage.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: - Mr Chairman! I would like to join all those voices of joy expressed at the end (tomorrow) of the work on the final ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty. This is evidence of historical justice. Of course it was taking too long. I think that the procedures that were going on could be seriously shortened. Fortunately, they did not result from the reluctance to ratify the Marrakesh Treaty by the European Union, but resulted from procedural issues relating to the competences of the European Union and the Member States. Anyway, the time that has been wasted must be quickly made up for, because there are unfortunately a huge number of blind or partially sighted people, and limiting the possibility of using cultural goods is, of course, something extremely unfair. It is good that today we are finishing this work and we are finally making such an opportunity available to our citizens, also because, unfortunately, the number of blind or partially sighted people will increase due to civilization reasons. Mr Andersson, whom I thank for this report, asked how it will be implemented. I hope soon. I would like to once again, as I have already done so in the autumn of last year, call on the Member States to immediately implement the provisions of the directive and regulation in cooperation with the organizations of the blind and partially sighted, but also with publishers and all other institutions involved.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! We should really be happy today - the Marrakech Treaty will finally be ratified by Europe. With this international treaty, current literature and art are made accessible to blind and visually impaired people - actually something taken for granted. This treaty was signed back in 2013, and four years later Europe finally has the chance to ratify it - a long period of time. Nobody really had anything particularly against it, the whole thing took so long because there were disputes over competencies between the Council and the Commission, and even the European Court of Justice had to be sought to resolve this. All of this is absurd and cynical because once again inter-institutional disputes and political disputes are being carried out on the backs of those affected and the weak. We should be happy that we finally made it, but it should be a lesson for us to focus on what we have in common and not disputes over competence. Unfortunately, this happens far too often in European politics, for example - because the Commissioner is here right now - in asylum and migration policy too.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: - Today, the European Parliament is finally taking the final step in the ratification process of the Marrakesh Treaty. People who are blind, visually impaired or with a print disability still have very difficult or no access to books and other printed materials. There is a great need to make more works and other protected material available in accessible formats such as Braille, audiobooks and large print. The text on the table introduces a new mandatory exception to copyright in EU law. This will allow beneficiary persons and organizations to make and distribute copies of works in accessible formats in the EU and third countries that are parties to the Convention. Thanks to the Marrakesh Treaty, more than 30 million visually impaired people in the EU will finally have equal access to the printed word. A small step for humanity, a giant step forward for blind and partially sighted people. Thank you.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, so far only 5% of the world's book and cultural heritage has been available in accessible format, 1% only in developing countries. This is a very serious damage to the right to knowledge for hundreds of millions of people in the world, and tens of millions in Europe, and a condemnation of not being able to reach, therefore, an adequate level of education, with a strong impact on the levels of employment and therefore also poverty. With the Marrakesh Treaty, which through specific exceptions to copyright expands the usability of textual products for the benefit of blind people, people with visual disabilities and other difficulties in reading printed texts, they can be written and exchanged in accessible formats many more works, such as books, magazines and newspapers or other genres of publications and notations, including musical scores and related illustrations. It is a real revolution, expected for years by citizens and defended by the European Parliament. There remains the bitterness for the tiring process of implementation. For many years the Commission has shown very little political will to defend people with visual impairments and reading difficulties and some Member States, unfortunately including Italy for a time, have used laughable arguments to slow down the process of entering force. But now an agreement has finally been reached, mainly thanks to the work of this Parliament and the strenuous defense of the treaty by the organizations representing people with disabilities. We reiterate it today once again: knowledge is everyone's right.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, it is the right of everyone to fully participate in culture. Persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled sadly continue to face many barriers in accessing books and other print materials which are protected by copyright and related rights. Adopted in 2013, the Marrakesh Treaty, which allows for copyright exceptions to facilitate the creation of accessible versions of books and other copyrighted works for visually impaired persons was a landmark move to enable visually impaired people to access books with the same ease as sighted readers. Whilst working as the shadow rapporteur in the Committee on Culture and Education for this file, I consulted with a wide cross-section of stakeholders:  disability experts, NGOs working on disability issues and representatives from the author and publisher fields, who were largely in agreement with each other and stressed the importance of the speedy ratification of the treaty. Europe’s non-discrimination law for people with disabilities is one of a string of EU actions that have brought tangible benefits for those who live with a disability in Europe, including those who live in Britain. With Brexit, the disabled communities will lose a crucial platform to defend their rights. We must guard against that.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - The education and full involvement of blind, visually impaired or reading disorders in society is also related to the accessibility of books, textbooks and other printed works.Nevertheless, today only 5% of them are published in accessible formats, in developing countries they are not published at all.Books in accessible formats often have to be published at the expense of organizations of people with disabilities, who, however, cannot provide them across borders due to copyright.The Marrakesh Treaty, which removes these obstacles, has already been ratified by 33 countries around the world, and it is very important that the EU countries join them as soon as possible.More than 30 million Europeans with severe visual impairments, who have so far had very limited or no access to books and other printed materials due to copyright, have been waiting too long for it to enter into force.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I believe that people who are blind, visually impaired or have other reading difficulties continue to face many obstacles in accessing books and other printed materials.I agree with my predecessors that, unfortunately, one of those obstacles was the lax approach of the European institutions.He may not have been so lax, but as a result he delayed access to these cultural goods for this very group of people.I am very pleased, then, that the ratification process has progressed so that we can conclude it now.I would very much like us to learn from this example, which we are currently tackling here, so that, for the next time, it is precisely for the benefit of these specific people that the action of the Union's institutions and bodies is as rapid and thus as effective as possible.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: - Sir. Chairman! It's a great day! I have been involved in all the ten years we have been fighting for this cause, and I can assure you that Parliament has been very good at supporting the cause. The problem has not only been the institutions, it has been a very hefty lobbying effort on the part of the rights holders. They have also lobbied my government, and it has been really embarrassing to see how large countries have tried to hide behind nice little Denmark, which was just run over by the rights holders. But let me warn against one thing: recital 14. It allows for national compensation schemes to be made. Make sure it does not happen! There is a loophole in this system, and we have never seen rightholders be able to document that they have suffered more than minimal losses, as stated in recital 14. Now fight at home to avoid this loophole. the law! It can be devastating for the whole thing, and that's the only weak point in what we are facing now, and part of our compromise. I very much hope that you will do your best at home.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all colleagues. This debate stresses once again the importance of this file which is far from being only technical. It will produce better opportunities for people with print disabilities and, as I said earlier, it will contribute to a better society and a better economy for all of us. The time seems to have come for the Marrakech Treaty to become a reality and to have its practical effects on the ground. For this reason I would like to thank the honourable Members of this Parliament for their tireless work and for the resolve that this House has put into this file, and in particular our rapporteur Mr Andersson and the shadow rapporteurs. Thank you, Mr President, thank you, dear colleagues.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, when I was appointed rapporteur for the Greens for the ratification of the Marrakech Treaty nearly three and half years ago, I was told that this would be an easy file and that it would be over quickly. Well, we were overly optimistic and I fear that we might have underestimated the degree of resistance that certain lobby interests would be able to push for and try to delay the ratification of the Marrakech Treaty.  But we overcame this resistance, and this is because many people – the shadows and many other MEPs present and not present in Parliament right now – did a lot of work in order to improve the access of blind people to books that they can read. We did it, and I also would like to thank the Commission for its sterling work on this issue and of course I would like to thank the Estonian Presidency and the Maltese Presidency for all the good things that they also did in order to make this a reality.  It has been very encouraging to hear this debate and all the speeches and I am quite confident that tomorrow we will vote to ratify the Marrakech Treaty so that blind people and visually impaired people and people with other reading disabilities will get a lot better access to books that they can read.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, 18 January 2018, at 12.00.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - How is it possible that the right to read in the 21st century is still not guaranteed to all people? We can be extremely concerned and even appalled at the fact that only 5% of all published books are available to the blind and partially sighted in developed countries, and less than 1% in developing countries. At the same time, it is clearly forgotten that the right to read is inextricably linked to the right to education, which is a fundamental human right. By procrastinating with the implementation of the Marrakesh Treaty, we are thus every day a step further from equality, which should be something taken for granted! It is high time we changed this, so I support the recommendation that the Marrakesh Treaty be approved as soon as possible, and I call on the Member States to implement it as fully as possible in practice. Namely, some Slovenian disability organizations have already expressed concern that the implementation of Slovenian legislation could lead to changes that could even worsen the current situation (eg the introduction of a possible economic compensation for publishers). We must not allow this to happen. I would also like to point out that adequate financial resources are also needed for full implementation, as without this, the long-awaited changes in everyday life will be difficult to implement.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- The Marrakesh Treaty will facilitate access to published works for blind and partially sighted people and people with other reading disabilities, as blind and partially sighted people still face many barriers to accessing books and other printed material.They need a greater number of works and other protected content available in accessible formats such as Braille, audio books and large print.EU law provides for the introduction of a new mandatory copyright exception under the Marrakesh Treaty.This will allow beneficiaries and organizations to make copies of the works in accessible formats and distribute them throughout the EU and in third countries that are signatories to the Marrakesh Treaty.I am pleased that the Marrakesh Treaty will ensure fundamental human rights for more than 30 million visually impaired children across the EU and make books more accessible in developing countries.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on the question with request for an oral answer to the Commission on combating trafficking in women and girls for the purpose of sexual and labor exploitation in the EU (O-000094/2017 - B8-0616 / 2017)(2017/3008 (RSP)).

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: author. – Mr President, Commissioner, as we speak, tens of thousands of women and children are being sexually abused and exploited in Europe. The EPP wholeheartedly supports this initiative to join forces across political groups to put an end to this unfolding tragedy.  Tonight, we stand united to urge the Member States to do more, faster and better, to stop trafficking. When visiting reception centres in Sicily, I was told by doctors that there was not a single women or girl who had not been raped on her way to Europe. Their stories are devastating. You can read them on their bodies. The time has come for the Anti-Trafficking Directive to be fully enforced by all Member States. Trafficking is a high-profit and low-cost business, at the expense of women and girls. We call on the Member States to do more to combat impunity and protect victims, to increase police and judicial cooperation, including with Europol, Eurojust and third countries, to ensure that traffickers are brought to justice, to combat demand for prostitution and online abuse, criminalise sex buyers and track their money, confiscate assets of criminal organisations and build trust with the victims, making them feel safe. They must provide psychological support and access to reproductive health services, allocate the necessary resources and support the anti-trafficking coordinator.  We must also make sure that Member States implement the Directive on Victims’ Rights. What is happening in Libya is totally unacceptable in modern times. It is a new slavery. The EU and the Member States must urgently act to deal with Libya and the trafficking routes, taking into account the gender dimension. From the Balkans to Western Europe, from the Mediterranean to the North Sea, there should be no hiding place for traffickers. Mr President, I am the author of this text and I would like to finish, if you would you allow me please. We welcome the Commission’s commitment but, once again, we ask for a new anti-trafficking strategy post-2016. Together with the EPP, and as co-chair of the Intergroup on Children’s Rights, I will continue to be committed to zero tolerance against trafficking. The EPP has been driving for the directive since 2011; we were here for the implementation report in 2016, and we are here tonight. We will not give up. The time has come for the Member States to go from words to action.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: author. - Mr President, in modern Europe of the 21st century there are sex slaves. In the developed Europe of the 21st century there are women exploited for work. In the advanced Europe of the 21st century, there are more than five hundred thousand women and girls who cross our borders annually at the hands of mafias and organized criminal groups. We could put names and surnames, faces, to these deceived women and forced into prostitution. Women and girls threatened with murdering their families contract a debt that they must pay in the brothels where they work. They work in brothels, they create a debt, they pay the money to these mafias. Customers' money that ends up in the pockets of the mafias and criminals. I repeat: customer money that ends up in the pockets of criminals. I say this because there are still those who, naively or intentionally, say that this prostitution is an exercise in freely deciding what one wants to do with one's life. And I think it would also be time for us in Europe to talk about legislation. Because without clients there would be no criminals with full pockets. And we must also talk about another issue, and that is labor exploitation. The Socialist Group was in the month of July on the island of Sicily, in the Ragusa area, to visit an area where there are women on agricultural farms - mostly, in this case, Romanians - who are being exploited for work, who work in the sun in the sun for less than three euros a day, if they charge them. Both situations, sexually exploited women and those exploited at work, have a common denominator: vulnerable women who suffer. For this reason, the European Commission and the Member States have to implement a strategy against trafficking in women and against trafficking in women and girls. Because laws must be converted into instruments and resources. It is our responsibility. It is our obligation. Therefore no We renounce to denounce and to be the voice of these women.There are no excuses to keep quiet.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The numbers are terrifying, yes. Across the EU there are over 16,000 people trafficked every year, three quarters of them women and girls, and the number of unreported cases is many times higher. Basically, unfortunately, one has to say: there are no reliable figures on human trafficking and there never will be. But that must not prevent us from doing everything we can to take action against human trafficking, forced prostitution, child abuse and illegal organ trafficking in Europe. Every victim is one too many. People force other people to work under unworthy conditions - worldwide. Forced labor also takes place in the middle of Europe, mostly invisible. People are threatened and exploited not only in prostitution, but also in construction, in hotels, restaurants, in the care and cleaning industries or in meat production. Let's also speak plainly about prostitution, and let's not fool ourselves: Over 90% of prostitutes in Europe's clubs and on Europe's streets do what they do not voluntarily. You are the victim of criminal violence. Women who came to Europe in the hope of being able to send money home month after month to support their children. We have to respond to all this criminal violence accordingly: zero tolerance. We need the Nordic model against forced prostitution. We need the full cooperation of the security forces in Europe against human trafficking. We need a European search system for missing children. In short: we need active, coordinated action and zero tolerance against any form of human trafficking - now, not tomorrow.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! More mobility of workers is an often expressed wish in Europe, because a lack of mobility is one of the limitations of the internal market. In some areas, however, we have more mobility than one would assume and than one could wish for. I have recently been intensively involved in reports of thousands of women who work as modern slaves in agricultural areas in Sicily. These women are barely paid for hard work, even if they toil twelve hours a day in scorching heat. Police reports speak of around 7,500 women, mostly from Romania, who are kept as modern slaves under these circumstances. Unfortunately, we all know that these official numbers represent only the tip of the iceberg for victims of abuse and exploitation. When these women should come to rest after a stressful day, another form of abuse is often waiting for them: sexual harassment - or exploitation - by the landowner, the employment agency, their acquaintances or friends. We have to face the fact and really look each other in the eye and say: Modern slavery exists! Not thousands of kilometers away on other continents, but in the middle of us in the European Union - and not only in Italy, but also in other Member States. Two thirds of these victims are EU citizens, most of them women and girls, and they are often taken across borders for sexual exploitation. The Member States have a legal and, above all, a moral obligation to protect these people who come from one country to another and are in danger of being grossly abused there. EU law obliges everyone to carry out regular checks to identify cases of exploitation and abuse, to protect the victims and to punish the perpetrators and tormentors.As co-rapporteur for the report on the implementation of the Victims Protection Directive, I will do more to protect those affected.The victims need targeted support, information about their rights, reliable prosecution and consequences for their tormentors.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Author. - Mr President! Commissioner Avramopoulos! You know that we have been asking for a strategy for a long time without the Commission delivering one. You have now presented a list of measures. That is of course welcome, but let's be honest: a list of actions is not a strategy. It is not as binding, not as forward-looking and not as systematic. Nevertheless, I would like to make some recommendations regarding the measures presented by the Commission. The main human trafficking in Europe is about women and girls bought by men in the prostitution market. It is therefore welcome that the Commission is finally doing something to criminalize those who expose and exploit victims of trafficking. I read from the Commission: "The Commission will encourage Member States to criminalize those who knowingly use the services of victims of trafficking in women or victims of trafficking." The problem, Commission, is that if you have someone who is knowledgeable, if you have to prove that someone is knowledgeable, then you make it difficult for those who are to prosecute. We have the most successful examples from countries that have gone further. Sweden, France, Norway, Iceland and Ireland have been most successful in combating trafficking in women. Prohibit the purchase of sexual services. It is 2018, it is time to put an end to the patriarchal notion that men can buy women and girls, that women can be bought and sold. It's simply passé. In Sweden, there has been a #metoo for those who have been exploited in prostitution and trafficking in women, against the abuse of power and exploitation that takes place there. I must also say to the Commission that I nevertheless encourage and welcome the support for women who are exploited in prostitution that you present in the list of measures and the increased support for children. But we must realize that if we do nothing for the demand, for those who buy and exploit women and girls in the prostitution industry, we will stand still and stomp. That may be the end of it. There is effective measures.It is important to dare to take them.It's time to say hello to the rights that men take when buying women in prostitution.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Author. - Mr President, trafficking in human beings in the European Union is a growing problem. According to data from the European Commission, 76% of the victims are women; 15% minors; from 2013 to 2014, almost 16,000 victims were registered and there were only around 3,000 convictions for trafficking. In any case, we know that the cases of trafficking today must be more than double or triple the registered numbers, because the majority of cases obviously escape the statistics. We also know that the current migration and refugee crisis is being used by trafficking mafias to identify the most vulnerable people, mainly women and girls, abusing asylum seekers who want to reach Europe or who are already in European refugee camps. . Sixteen thousand five hundred unaccompanied children entered Greece, Italy, Bulgaria and Spain during the first six months of 2017 and currently they clearly have a high chance of falling into trafficking networks. IOM has also reported a dramatic increase in the number of Nigerian women and girls who have fallen victim to human trafficking, the vast majority for the purposes of sexual exploitation. From January to September 2017 alone, 4,371 Nigerian women and girls marching from Libya identified themselves as victims of trafficking for sexual exploitation. And here too I would like to recall that, on November 6, twenty-six women and girls of the same nationality were murdered by their mafias when they tried to reach the Italian coast. We must react now to this terrible and intolerable reality, and we believe that the European Commission must act. We have some very valuable instruments, but they must be applied in a more concrete way, and the Commission must be more strict in compelling Member States to comply with these instruments. And, as has been said before, we believe that it is very important that, beyond the instruments we have, Let us develop a comprehensive policy from the European institutions to tackle this phenomenon.Therefore, Commissioner, we look forward to hearing today what actions the European Commission is taking to tackle this terrible phenomenon.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, even today, despite the Directive 2011/36 / EU on the prevention and repression of trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims, which has been in force for some years in the various Member States, this phenomenon it does not seem to diminish. On the contrary, the data shows us a drastic increase. As we know, in this submerged world of human trafficking, women and girls are the main victims. The Commission has in fact recorded that 76% of the victims are women, 15% of which are minors, victims of torturers who forcefully bring them to Europe, promising them a better world and a better life. Once they reach our borders, they find themselves living a nightmare far worse than the one they left in their homelands, joining the ranks of sexual exploitation or illegal work, managed by criminal organizations. According to some UNODC data every year, in Europe, criminal groups earn 3 billion dollars thanks to the trafficking of human beings for the sole purpose of sexual exploitation. We are well aware that trafficking in human beings is often closely linked to the migratory crisis that is affecting the European Union from the east and south of the Mediterranean, particularly Italy and Greece. Does the Commission intend to take specific measures to deal with this crisis or does it want to leave the whole burden on these states? Isn't it worth stepping up investigative efforts at borders to put a stop to this shame? Finally, I find myself forced to remind the Commission that the Union is not only the destination of choice for criminal organizations; in many cases the Union is also the place of origin of the trade in human beings because, as we know, there are very many young women from the poorest Member States who are forced into prostitution in the least affected states from the crisis.The humanitarian emergency we are facing is therefore made even more serious by the worsening of the economic imbalances within the Union and organized crime is not the only enemy towards which to take a decisive position.Poverty is now endemic within many Member States: it is an equally dangerous enemy, an invisible ally of organized crime acting silently from within our borders.We can't take it any longer, it's time to stop this.We are all here, once again, asking what concrete actions the Commission intends to take to tackle the problem.There is a need for zero tolerance, as has already been said, against trafficking in human beings because, as we know, it represents a form of slavery which is in stark contrast to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by expressing my thanks to our colleagues from all political families here who have initiated this debate here today. It is a very timely one and it is about an issue, as we all know, of high sensitivity, at the top of the interests of our citizens. Again, my thanks to this House for its continuous active interest and support in our joint fight against this odious phenomenon. I am sure that we will all agree in this room that when dealing with trafficking in human beings what really counts is actions and results, more than intentions and words. The modern ‘slave markets’ in Libya and elsewhere, where human beings are bought and sold as cheap commodities, will not be stopped if we do not act now.  The ruthless sick minds who take advantage of innocent children – girls and boys – or hopeless and vulnerable adults – women and men – will continue to make astronomical profits if we do not stop them now. The pain from the torture and the indelible damage on the victims’ bodies and souls will not be repaired if we do not protect and take care of them now.  Unfortunately, the situation, as you all know, is neither new, nor does it happen only in unstable countries. Trafficking also happens right here in Europe. As is rightly pointed out in your question, there is a strong gender dimension in this picture, while the available data does not capture the real magnitude of this phenomenon. It is also true that these desperate human beings are usually exploited for sexual or labour purposes. Therefore, what is needed now is exactly to focus on the specific characteristics of this crime and tackle them with the proper tools.  Let us be frank, however. The real fight against trafficking in human beings is not being fought here, by the European Union institutions. It is on the ground, and it is Member States’ authorities that need to deliver, where needed by joint efforts. Obviously the Commission will continue supporting efforts in these operational endeavours. A demonstrative example of joint efforts can be seen in the information provided by Europol. From 2016 until early December 2017, 2 476 new human trafficking cases were referred to Europol; 10 664 potential victims were registered, the majority of whom were EU nationals; 10 449 suspects have been signalled in its database, the majority of whom again were EU nationals. All these years, through an ambitious and progressive approach, we have managed in the European Union to create a solid legal and policy framework which has brought Europe to the frontline of global efforts. Now it is time, on the one hand, to fully implement and enforce our strong and modern legal armoury, and, on the other hand, to step up our efforts with targeted and focused actions.  My personal commitment, my personal aim, is to bring tangible results, to be as much as possible operational, to make a difference on the ground. This is the reason why last December, as you will remember, I presented a list of further concrete measures to step up our action to disrupt the modus operandi of traffickers, to strengthen victims’ rights and protection, to intensify internal and external efforts in a coordinated manner, and to widen our knowledge base and provide targeted financial support. We will monitor progress on the actions set out and will report on progress to this House and the Council already by the end of 2018. EU-wide updated statistical data on this phenomenon will also be made available in the next Progress Report in 2018, including on: gender dimension, children affected and forms of exploitation. We are now examining very closely how Member States comply with the EU Anti-trafficking Directive and we will not hesitate to initiate infringement procedures, if needed. On labour inspections, the Commission will come soon with the second report on the implementation of the Employers’ Sanction Directive. Moreover, gender plays a pivotal role in our new set of actions. In this respect, we will work closely with the European Institute for Gender Equality to deliver practical guidance to Member States on how to implement the provisions of the Anti-trafficking Directive on assistance and protection from a gender perspective. In terms of resources allocated and funding on the gender dimension, the Commission’s Comprehensive Policy Review (2016) demonstrated that almost 20% of funded projects were gender-specific in the period between 2004 and 2015. Future funding priorities by the Commission will ensure that the gender dimension is duly addressed. In that respect, the last call under the Internal Security Fund and Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund places priority on the gender dimension. Finally, the next Progress Report will also provide an update on the EU-wide progress made at investigative efforts, based on Member States’ information covering the period between 2015 and 2017. Thank you very much for your attention and most importantly, for your support. We are all on the same side to bring an end to this odious phenomenon.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I find it paradoxical that in 2018 we still find ourselves talking about slavery, because when it comes to trafficking in women, girls, children for sexual and work purposes, there is no other name than "slavery". In the world out of a thousand people, three are slaves, over a quarter are minors. Around the world, six to ten million children are forced into forced labor, sexually trafficked or segregated as slaves. In our very civilized Europe, according to data provided by the European Commission, 79% of the victims of trafficking are destined for prostitution and sexual exploitation. This is not the first time in this House that we have been debating and condemning traffickers and looking for the measures that can be taken to protect the victims, but if there were no demand there would be no market. We need homogeneous and rigorous European legislation, which would allow us to prosecute traffickers and clients in every corner of our Union. The Commission must be the bearer of this request and increase, with agencies such as Europol, all investigative efforts in those countries where exploitation is much more widespread. We are in 2018 and there are still sex slaves. I conclude, President, with the words of Simone Veil, whom we have been recalling in recent years, who said that Europe must demonstrate that it is exemplary in the application of human rights. Well, let's prove it!

name: Maria ARENA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, the evaluation of the Directive on trafficking in human beings, published in 2016 by the Commission, shows that sexual exploitation remains the most widespread purpose of trafficking in Europe, followed by exploitation by the job. Women and girls are the main victims and the visit that the Socialist and Democratic Group has made to Sicily in the field of agriculture has given us a glaring example of this modern slavery. Of course, Sicily is not the only place where this slavery takes place. Romanian women are not the only victims in Europe either. The networks of Nigerian minors in prostitution in Brussels are another example. We often talk about the exploitation of sex, but there is also exploitation by companies, simply because they have an interest in making short-term profits by paying their workers as little as possible. So what I am asking is that if we work on the issue of sex exploitation - which is important, of course, in human trafficking - we must also empower European companies which today hui exploit these people, whether it is in tomato cultivation, apple picking or other activities, simply because they want to sell products at lower prices in supermarkets, without any scruple. Therefore, Commissioner, I think it is important - and it is the responsibility of the Commission - to ask the Member States to enforce this directive, which exists and which is not respected by some of them. them, but we must also give the means to the Member States, as in social inspections, for example, to monitor labor laws, because it is through labor laws, through labor protection that we will also protect these people, and it is important that companies respect labor protection.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about a phenomenon at the crossroads of racism and sexism.76% of victims of human trafficking, according to the Commission's report published in 2016, are women.The most common sources are Albania, China, Morocco, Nigeria, 80% for sexual exploitation.A further figure says that 67% of victims of trafficking are subjected to sexual exploitation.Sexual slavery tells of the macho, patriarchal and violent connotation towards the women of this Europe, of many, very white, European citizens who in words support human rights.I urge the European institutions to a battle without borders against sexism and racism and I personally thank Mrs Matera for quoting Simone Veil and not Silvio Berlusconi about sexual exploitation.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, women and girls are not victims. Women and girls are made victims. Women and girls are strong and resilient, but too often they are being exploited. Too often they are being exploited by a system that is made for the few to gain profit and for the many to suffer from it.  It is not a sign of weakness in these women that they are exploited. It is actually a sign of our weakness that we let this happen, that we let so many women and girls not live in freedom in the European Union, and the responsibility is put from one to the other.  If the Member States are too weak to actually implement a Directive that is already in place, then the Commission needs to be strong because we need more police cooperation, including across borders. We need the perpetrators to see that their actions have consequences. We need to have better training for police and for justice personnel, because very often they do not even know how to act in cases of human trafficking. We need justice and support for those who have become victims because too often they are left alone. Girls’ and women’s rights are the unfinished business of the 21st century. Let’s put this directive in place and change something in this perfidious system.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, as the Commission has pointed out, over a third of the 15,000 victims of trafficking in human beings registered in the European Union between 2013 and 2014 were non-European foreigners. As the Commission itself admits, I quote: "Networks of human traffickers take advantage of irregular immigration routes by targeting the most vulnerable, namely women and children". She further points out that traffickers increasingly exploit asylum systems. However, in a response from July 2017, the Commission plans to turn against states if it judges that they are misapplying the Directive on combating trafficking in human beings. We can only be struck by the total lack of questioning by the European Union of its irresponsible migration policy when we know its appalling consequences in terms of modern slavery and sexual exploitation, which particularly affect children.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, trafficking in human beings such as forced prostitution and begging are realities in all our countries and in the whole world. They would be almost as profitable as drug trafficking or counterfeiting. In our cities, we meet men every day, but above all, women and children bruised by cold and hunger, exploited by mafia networks. 65% are believed to come from EU countries, but others come from much further afield. Unicef ​​reports an increase in the number of Nigerian women and girls victims of human trafficking. What do you propose? You are asking the Commission to sanction even more Member States which do not respect a given directive and, worse, their duty of care towards the Union, as if this would help the victims. You refuse to mention the strainer that the Schengen area has become, favoring trafficking in mafia organizations, which is becoming untraceable. In addition, the European Commission wants to further increase the quotas of migrants, thus creating new calls for air, delivering these migrants into the hands of smugglers who, in fact, will hasten to enslave or prostitute them. As often, you try with your incantations to resolve situations that could be controlled without your crazy policies.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, human trafficking is a serious crime that can affect anyone of any age, gender or nationality. It is a crime that currently affects every large town and city across the United Kingdom and the European Union, with women and girls making up more than 70% of the total estimated number of victims globally. National Crime Agency statistics estimate that, in the United Kingdom alone, there are tens of thousands of victims of this horrific crime. Previous estimates of between 10 000 and 13 000 across the UK are now thought to be only the tip of the iceberg. In 2015, the Human Trafficking and Exploitation Bill in Northern Ireland paved the way for more robust UK-wide legislation, giving additional support to those who have been victims of human trafficking. The bill gives much-needed support to victims with regard to compensation, providing ‘trafficking guardians’ for children who have been victims, and support up to and after criminal investigations. But legislation can only do so much. As we go about normal life, there is a growing and a good chance that you will come across a victim who has been exploited. Education will be one of the only ways to eradicate this terrible, vile crime.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - It is very sad to listen, because the victims of human trafficking are not declining. The statistics of 700 000 to 2 000 000 people are very sad statistics and, of course, as you said here, women and children, who are very vulnerable, predominate. Then there are also the sectors where there are the most women in slave labor, agriculture was mentioned here, but it is also construction, manufacturing or domestic work. If we look at geography, it is mainly women from Albania, China, Morocco, Nigeria and Vietnam. Of course, such human trafficking cannot be tolerated, and it is therefore right that we are looking for solutions that are more effective. The Czech Republic is a destination and transit country rather than a source country in the fight against trade. We provide protection and assistance to victims through specific programs and work with many non-profit organizations. I would like to emphasize that it is the non-profit sector that is a very important partner in the fight against human trafficking, and I would therefore recommend that other countries also consider involving it more. Given the national specificities, it would also be necessary to strengthen action at the national level in order to identify specific sectors and territories where support and assistance to these victims needs to be strengthened.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, do our values ​​have a cost, do our values ​​have a price? Well, I can tell you that for some, this price, they have fixed it: it is the price of a kilo of Sicilian cherry tomatoes, and it is true that this is not unique to Sicily, but I went to this territory and I saw all the excesses of the exploitation of these products. Behind these cherry tomatoes there is a system of small bosses and slaves, corporals and farm workers. These tomatoes are the result of social and sexual exploitation of Romanian, Tunisian and Nigerian women, often organized - it has been said - by the companies themselves. These women victims of trafficking, workers, hostages, are faced with Sophie’s choice, they dream of a better future but will never be free. These exploitations, this trafficking are always to be condemned, more and more strongly. I want to pay tribute here to these women, but good feelings are not enough and will not put an end to this social and sexual trafficking. Therefore, I ask you, Commissioner, to present to us your post-2016 strategy on combating trafficking in women and girls, which continues to increase. This strategy must be effective, respond to the urgency - I mean the urgency - of the situation, sanction the Member States which do not respect the legal instruments, but also, help them financially to better fight against this scourge.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: - Commissioner, inhumane working conditions prevail in the greenhouses of Italy and in the mushroom fields of the Netherlands. Workers in the Czech asparagus and strawberry crops in Greece were abused a few years ago. Human trafficking and labor exploitation shame Europe. They feed not only the sex industry, but also agriculture, livestock, construction, tourism, care. Europe can not be proud of the growth associated with this modern slave trade! Does the Commission monitor the implementation of the directives on trafficking in human beings and seasonal workers, or is it only concerned with budgetary rules? Because this problem needs to be solved, we need: - smart labor controls, as I emphasized in my report on domestic staff, - legal and transparent procedures for migrant labor, and, most importantly, - the safeguarding of labor rights in order to we can really enter the 21st century. This is the only way to break the fear!

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Mr President, trafficking of women and children for sexual and labour exploitation is as rife as ever. One of the most vulnerable groups are of course children. In 2016 roughly one in three potential victims of modern slavery were children. But current statistics underestimate the true scale of what is going on, only showing what has been reported, and in some cases there are inconsistencies in recording. The disappearance of children is a cruel reality of modern day slavery. In 2015, 10 000 migrant children went missing within Europe according to Europol, all with the prospect of a better life but instead headed for a life of domestic servitude, sexual exploitation or child marriage. We are letting down these victims, leaving them vulnerable and open to being trafficked and abused. How have we let this terrible violation of human dignity worsen? Criminalised gangs are taking advantage of the EU’s open borders and exploiting women and children for vast sums of money. Victims are used as mere pawns in the game of crime. Each victim is disposable and easily replaceable to the criminals. To them one death is nothing on the profitability of their enslavement.  The Commission must grasp that free movement of people is exacerbating the problem, failing the victims and aiding the criminals. As the EU prohibits the UK from conducting criminal background checks on EU citizens, it is no wonder that crime has escalated. Migrant children could start in Greece and end up in France without being tracked. This is not a simple matter, but each time we debate this nothing is resolved. If this issue is not addressed, then there is no hope for the victims.

name: Anna HEDH
text: - Mr President! Since 2016, the EU has been completely without a strategy for human trafficking. This is despite the fact that Commissioner Avramopoulos has repeatedly promised and assured that a strategy is under way. Instead, on 5 December, the Commission chose to present a so-called communication on trafficking in human beings, a document that will hardly make as much of a difference as a strategy. I am very disappointed and angry that the Commission has chosen to act in this way. I have been working on the issue of human trafficking for over a decade in the European Parliament and have constantly met with opposition. It is astonishing that there are so many who do not realize the seriousness of the crimes that human trafficking entails. Trafficking in human beings is a cross-border activity and requires cross-border solutions and a strategy. If we lower the level of ambition in the issue, we will send signals to the Member States that the EU prioritises other things and that the perpetrators can continue to commit crimes and abuses. In terms of signaling, it is very important that the EU acts vigorously. For human trafficking in the EU, avalanches are increasing. The human suffering that results from human trafficking requires that we constantly prioritize the fight against the perpetrators. We must criminalize the use of services from victims of trafficking in the EU. We must fight demand. The principle of following the money should be used in the cross-border police work. The protection of victims of trafficking in human beings must also increase, both during and after the legal process. I would also like to take this opportunity to point out the importance of the role of the human trafficking coordinator. The fact that there is a person and a function with a very large body of knowledge on the issue of human trafficking is crucial for us to succeed in the work of combating human trafficking throughout the EU. How long should we allow human trafficking in Europe? When will the Commission present a strategy to combat human trafficking in an active and concrete way?

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - (PT) Mr President, we know that organized crime derives more income from human trafficking than drug and arms trafficking, and is often associated with them, fueling business and other criminal activities that money laundering and tax havens facilitate. We know that the object of trafficking in women goes through forced marriages and situations of clandestine and or domestic work in conditions of slavery. But the fundamental thing is sexual exploitation, prostitution. Prostitution is a grave social scourge that enslaves millions of women, trapped in criminal networks of human trafficking and other forms of exploitation that some want to call voluntary prostitution or at the option of women. This is a serious attack on women, their bodies, their physical and psychological health, their dignity and rights. Prostitution feeds a sordid exploitation of women from the poorest classes and layers, constituting a serious violation of human rights. Therefore, there is an urgent need to reject any initiatives as some intend today, in Portugal, to regulate prostitution, legitimizing violence against women and the associated trafficking.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as has been said, it is not necessary to look far to come across stories of sexual or labor exploitation: they happen every day within the European Union and victims are, in most cases, women and young girls, who fall into the trap of sexual exploitation. For many of them, exploitation is also work: endless hours, poor working conditions and poor wages. My country is also an example of this, where many women are employed in agriculture in truly inhumane conditions. In some cases these grueling jobs led to death, as in the case of Paola Clemente who in 2015, in Puglia, lost her life at the age of 49, killed by fatigue while harvesting grapes for 2 euros an hour. Places where hiring is practiced, where there are labor intermediation systems with many complicities. The European Union must intervene, and it is not just a question of bringing traffickers and exploiters to justice and sanctioning complicit businesses, but also of practicing a policy aimed at ensuring that many girls are not forced to hand over their future to unscrupulous offenders. Educational training policies that allow greater opportunities are needed, labor and welfare policies capable of ensuring economic and social independence are needed, more stringent policies on rights and their full protection are needed. In short, Commissioner, we need to move from words to deeds.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, labor exploitation in the European Union is, unfortunately, a daily occurrence. The Fundamental Rights Agency itself alerts us to global economic inequalities and increased labor mobility, which are favoring labor exploitation. And it also alerts us that a work contract and a residence permit do not guarantee fair situations. Under the law, in the European Union there is also exploitation. The farm also has a feminine face. Labor and sexual exploitation among women, you know, is much higher than among men: 76% - three out of every four victims - and 15% of the cases are minors. Against this we need strong political action, not a declaration of intent. And we need coordination between the Commission and the States against trafficking in persons, transversal gender policies and a greater weight of social dialogue in the face of neoliberal policies that leave workers unprotected.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the rising number of reports of trafficking in human beings is a matter of extreme concern, especially for feminists. As we know, women are far more likely to fall victim to trafficking, particularly for the purpose of sexual exploitation. The phenomenon is in complete contradiction with our values, as well as European and national law. It shows that women are still, in many cases, denied their humanity and objectified.  I would like to highlight the situation of trans sex workers, whose situation and voice is too often overlooked. Most trans murders are perpetrated against sex workers who are often already victims of human trafficking. Their experience must be taken into account and our policies should have a specific trans focus. I am very curious to know what steps the Commission has concretely taken to put an end to the trafficking of human beings.
