It is shameful to see that our governments pretend to take the issue of trafficking seriously when it comes to preventing migrants from reaching Europe, but fail to address it with the gravity it requires when it comes to women and trans people. I look forward to your responses, Commissioner.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, it is 2018 and here within the EU we have humans being trafficked for sexual and labour exploitation: human slaves, with women and children making up the vast majority of those trafficked. At a time when the movement against the sexual exploitation of women is at its zenith we cannot forget those women and girls who are most vulnerable. Nor is it acceptable that human trafficking for the purpose of labour exploitation is on the rise. It is imperative that the EU take action to stop this cruel and inhumane practice. Perpetrators must be brought to justice and Member States must cooperate to name, shame and penalise those companies which are using labour from trafficked humans. Member States must comply fully with the Human Trafficking Directive, the Victims’ Rights Directive and the Seasonal Workers Directive, and we must collect disaggregated data so that we can fully know the extent of the horror, and then move to eradicate human slavery once and for all.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Mr President, I took part in the same debate in this House today as I did thirteen years ago.Colleagues, nothing has changed.According to the progress report on the fight against trafficking in human beings, most of the registered victims of trafficking come from Romania, Bulgaria, Hungary and Poland.Alternatively, of the five European countries whose citizens most often become prey to traffickers, up to four are among the so-called new Member States.Trafficking in human beings thrives where there is high poverty and few opportunities.As long as there are abysmal economic disparities between countries and regions in the European Union, there will be two Europe.If we call for unification today, we are thinking that real unity is not created by tearing down border fences.It is born in solidarity and respect for the dignity of every human being and in the common fight against extreme poverty, regardless of borders.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, trafficking in human beings, which sees women and girls as predestined victims, is a phenomenon which unfortunately does not tend to decrease but which, despite the adoption of the 2011 anti-trafficking directive, has worrying growth, mainly due to the ongoing migration crisis, during which, in particular, the number of unaccompanied minors has grown exponentially. Easy to recruit and unfortunately still not adequately protected today, most of these minors end up in organized crime networks that sexually exploit them or use them as criminal labor. In the face of such serious abuses, the Commission has a responsibility to intervene, so that the Member States all fully implement the anti-trafficking directive. Specifically, national authorities must increase the number and effectiveness of investigations and prosecutions, improve the procedures for identifying victims and, of course, provide them with specialized assistance and protection.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, trafficking in women and girls for the purposes of sexual and labor exploitation in the European Union is unfortunately on the agenda. The evidence shows that very specific measures need to be taken. It was found that 76% of the registered victims were women, while 15% were children. They come from Romania, Bulgaria, the Netherlands, Hungary and Poland. It is a given that this holding, in particular the labor holding, focuses on the agricultural sector. Member States should therefore implement Directive 2011/36 / EU effectively, labor traffickers should be punished and traffickers should be prosecuted. At the same time, there must be cooperation between states to tackle this cross-border trafficking in human beings.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr. president; This problem, Commissioner, combines the action of organized and clandestine international networks that require a global treatment at least at a European level, and a response, generally given at the local or regional level, from health, social services or education, to the victims of these practices. For this reason, both aspects should be integrated, in a decisive and sincere way, in the planning and execution of European policies against this scourge. Obtaining more reliable data and a real capacity for inter-institutional multi-level coordination, from the provision of specific services, are obvious advantages of their participation. This is proven, for example, by the IV Four-Year Plan for the care of seasonal workers in the Basque Country, where this initiative has been underway since 2004. Finally, I would like to add two questions: can the Commission confirm that the increase in Could the activity of these networks lead to almost 30,000 unaccompanied minors missing in the Union? In addition to sexual exploitation, is there data on the relationship between these disappearances and illegal organ trafficking or illegal adoptions?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the sexual and labor exploitation of people, especially women and girls, is a reality which has its roots in antiquity but, unfortunately, in our time has taken the form of profitable economic activity. This situation is a stigma for our humanity and culture. The European Union, in cooperation with the Member States and other countries, must take drastic measures to reduce this unacceptable situation, albeit initially, and eventually eliminate it. It is not enough for the European Union to invoke Articles 5 and 31 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which prohibit slavery and forced labor and recognize workers' right to a fair supply and decent working conditions. Strict controls must be enforced in those countries where there is sexual and labor exploitation of women and children and, at the same time, the uncontrolled activities of slave traders and traffickers must be prevented. Finally, strict legal provisions must be enacted to impose draconian penalties on those who act in such a ruthless and unacceptable manner.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking colleagues again for this very interesting debate and their substantial and useful contributions. I make no secret of the fact that I was pleased to hear that all of us in this room share the same approach, as I elaborated in my introductory remarks. We have taken a very clear stance based on determination, resolve and principles. Over the years, the European Union and the Member States have demonstrated a strong commitment to cracking down on unscrupulous criminals, preventing the crime and, most importantly, protecting the victims.  We have developed a robust EU legislation and policy approach. Now we have to ensure full compliance with the European Union’s laws and be more operational with our work. Only if we all work together – the Presidency of the Council, Member States, the European Parliament, civil society and our agencies – can we make a difference on the ground, and we are determined to do so. I can only assure you that the Commission is committed to reinvigorating efforts and that the new set of priority actions is already being implemented. For me personally, as I stressed at the beginning during my introductory remarks, I am committed to delivering on that. I will be happy to inform Parliament later this year on progress achieved. Thank you for your support.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - As we can see, the Commission in its report on progress in the fight against trafficking in human beings, found that 76% of the registered victims are women and at least 15% - children. Most of the registered victims are citizens of the European Union. Despite the adoption of directives aimed at combating trafficking in human beings, the number of victims of trafficking for the purpose of exploitation at work is growing. With regard to serious exploitation at work and sexual exploitation in the various sectors concerned, it is necessary to assess Member States' compliance with those directives and their due diligence obligations in order to protect workers and carry out inspections to identify exploitation at work and protect victims. So, I would like to ask the Commission, what action is it taking against Member States that do not comply with these directives? I would also like to know what specific measures the Commission will take to address the gender dimension of trafficking, sexual abuse and exploitation at work. I would call on the Commission to review and evaluate the investigative steps taken in those countries where sexual and work exploitation are most prevalent. In addition, it is essential to ensure that the perpetrators of such crimes are brought to justice.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - In the advanced Europe of the 21st century, more than five hundred thousand women and girls cross our borders annually in the hands of mafias and organized criminal groups, who exploit them at work or force them to engage in prostitution, if not both. Women and girls, threatened with the murder of their families, who contract an exorbitant debt that they can only pay by working in brothels or in agricultural fields, with very poor salaries, in subhuman conditions, as the socialists saw in July in Ragusa, Sicily, where Hundreds of women, most of them Romanians, work from sunrise to sunset for less than three euros a day, and that's if they are paid. The European Commission must launch, without delay, a new European strategy against trafficking in women and girls. Although labor exploitation is increasing, the main destination of women who are trafficked as mere merchandise continues to be prostitution, from which mafias and criminals make huge profits. There are still those who believe that women freely choose to engage in prostitution. The time has come for Europe to consider legislating, because without clients there would be no criminals with their pockets full.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. - The trafficking and trafficking of women and young girls for the purpose of sexual exploitation and forced labor is happening next to us and has become alarming in recent years, making it the second most lucrative illegal activity in the world after the drug trade. In a Europe of values ​​and the fundamental protection of fundamental rights, our societies are saddened by the fact that the vast majority of registered victims are now unfortunately from EU Member States. the freedom and dignity of millions of women and girls, causing irreparable damage for a lifetime. Let us just consider that, many times, the effort to free oneself from this compulsion is paid for by young women with their own lives. Although European legislation on the prevention and suppression of trafficking in human beings is currently in place, harmonization between Member States remains lacking in establishing effective legal protection mechanisms, criminalizing perpetrators and protecting victims. It is our duty to join forces and work together more effectively across borders, because trafficking in women and girls does not discriminate and concerns us all.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - Trafficking in human beings is one of the worst things you can commit. It is an absolute moral evil regardless of the sex of the victims. Of course, some forms of trafficking arouse particularly strong emotions in us, for example when it concerns children or is related to sexual abuse, and this remains by far the most common cause of trafficking. Its victims are most often women and it is clearly visible that the direction leads from poorer to richer countries. It is also impossible to ignore the disturbing phenomenon of the increase in the number of slave labor - especially the agricultural sector is vulnerable to this type of exploitation. Efforts should be made to level out the differences between countries so that the disproportions in terms of the affluence of societies, and thus indirect reasons for falling into such conditions of exploitation, are eliminated. Finally, like many people, I call for the implementation at the level of the European Union and its Member States of all legal measures aimed at preventing and combating this practice, detecting and severely punishing the perpetrators, as well as material and psychological assistance for it. victims.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission declaration on the European Year of Cultural Heritage 2018 (2018/2509 (RSP)).

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, 2018 is the European Year of Cultural Heritage. As you will remember, it was launched at the European Culture Forum in Milan on 7 December 2017, in the presence of a vibrant crowd of 800 participants from a wide range of cultural organisations: UNESCO, the Council of Europe, the Member States and the European institutions. We were joined by the Estonian Presidency, the Committee of the Regions and the European Parliament. We were honoured by the presence and active participation of the European Parliament’s President, Mr Antonio Tajani, the Chair of the Committee on Culture and Education, Ms Petra Kammevert, and Ms Sylvia Costa, who led the European Parliament’s negotiating team on the decision for the year. I would like to warmly express my thanks to all of them, including the European Parliament’s rapporteur, Mr Mircea Diaconu, for the decisive role they played in making this European Year of Cultural Heritage happen. The European Year of Cultural Heritage comes at a particularly decisive moment in the history of our Union. It comes at a time when the European Union is grappling with issues that go to the very heart of the values it stands for, and that will have a bearing on how the Union will evolve. The European Year of Cultural Heritage also comes at a time when culture is high on the European Union’s agenda. In Gothenburg last November, the European heads of state and government discussed the important role of education and culture in strengthening people’s sense of belonging to a cultural community. As a contribution to this debate, the Commission issued a Communication on strengthening European identity through education and culture, which proposed, among other things, to strengthen the European agenda for culture. In December, the European Council followed up, recognising the importance of the 2018 European Year of Cultural Heritage. Indeed, the European Year of Cultural Heritage offers us a unique opportunity. By engaging with our cultural memory, we can better understand and raise awareness of the many cultural influences on which our identities are based and we can develop our vision for the future. We can reconnect our citizens with their roots as Europeans, while respecting and cherishing the values created by different communities. This is the message we want to pass on, with the motto of the year: ‘our heritage: where the past meets the future’. So, what have we done so far to put this year in motion? First, we have mobilised a wide network of civil society and heritage operators who are helping us to implement the year on the ground. We have also mobilised Member States. We each have a dedicated national coordinator for the year and have national and regional programmes of activities. We have been working very closely with the European Parliament, listening to you and involving you in all our stakeholder meetings. We have launched a specific call for proposals under the Creative Europe programme, to fund transnational cooperation projects in the field of cultural heritage. We have developed synergies with existing initiatives in the field of cultural heritage, in particular the European heritage days, the EU prize for cultural heritage and the European heritage label. All these are fully involved in the European Year, and we have established a committee of stakeholders involving 35 heritage, cultural and youth networks, selected through the voices of a structured dialogue framework on culture. Furthermore, Commission departments have joined forces to top up the Year’s dedicated budget with additional projects funded through regular funds. In the case of research, for example, this has led to over EUR 100 million of investment in cultural heritage. Finally, we have launched a communication campaign to give high visibility to our actions. The website is up and running in 24 languages, in addition to a video, leaflets, a very active social media strategy and a newsletter which goes to 4 000 stakeholders. But the year has only just started. A wide array of activities and events lie ahead. We are now putting the final touches to ten major initiatives at European level, organised around four pillars: engagement, protection, sustainability and innovation. We have an ambitious programme, comprising over 100 European-level events and around 2 000 national and regional events during the year. These are designed to resonate far beyond the year itself. It is only in the light of its long-term impact that we will be able to judge the year’s success. A successful year will help us to better protect and manage tangible and intangible testimonies from our past and ensure that our fellow Europeans become increasingly aware of the value of cultural heritage for our identity and for our future. I know the Commission can count on this House’s support and active participation to turn this vision into reality. Cultural heritage makes us Europeans. Our heritage makes Europe meaningful, so I believe that this is a project we all endorse and uphold, because in these difficult times, in this existential moment for Europe, culture is one of the pillars of our existence.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Culture as a priority - it sounds good, but the implementation is much worse. We have 11 pm, in the hall - 12 members, that is only 1%, in the audience seats - one person, perhaps waiting to turn off the lights. This late hour is a certain illustration of the approach to culture that always comes up at this time, just extremely late. But what I want to say today: I am very happy that the year of heritage is 2018, but on this occasion it is important to see what the state of participation in culture is, especially in this field. I am preparing a report on barriers to participation in culture and I have also dealt with heritage. I would like to say that the latest data show that only 30% of Europeans regularly visit a museum or see monuments at least once a year. Once a year! 80% are proud of their cultural heritage, but do not touch it or participate in it. If we ask why this is so, there are three answers. First - lack of time, second - costs and third - lack of information. What is a heritage year for, what should be the purpose Well, firstly - to improve information on European heritage, and secondly - to increase participation in culture by removing the barriers that residents themselves feel. If only 30% of Europeans visit or visit a museum year after year, and as many as 80% of them have a museum or monuments under their noses, very close, it means that the effort that should be made is only made and only in the so-called minimum. I bring it to your attention.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we would have liked a different time for this important debate, because we have fought a lot in Parliament, as we know, for this European Year of Cultural Heritage, which sees exemplary teamwork with the Commission , the Council and civil society. Of course, I also thank the Directorate-General for Culture and our colleague rapporteur Mircea Diaconu, and I think, I really hope that every one of our colleagues will feel like this year's ambassador. The vastness of the initiatives and participation that have been set in motion throughout Europe, but also the responses of the Eurobarometer, confirm that we were right, that the vast majority of Europeans believe that the common cultural heritage is a primary good to be shared. , in which Europe must invest much more. It is a message that goes against the trend of nationalisms, walls and the questioning of the very identity of Europe. It is a precious opportunity to share thematic initiatives that aim at the protection and enhancement of the material, intangible, landscape and digital European cultural heritage, a universal asset that expresses the rich linguistic and cultural diversity but also a common European identity, an extraordinary resource of intercultural dialogue and interreligious, as also recalled in Gothenburg. As we had hoped for and as emerged from the Milan forum in December, as many as 13 Directorates-General of the Commission took action with specific actions in a transversal approach on three main objectives: to ensure that citizens, especially the youngest, feel involved, recognize the economic and employment value of heritage and enhance the role of culture. However, we want this Year not to end in itself, but to be the premise for the 2019-2021 agenda for European culture and finally for a centrality of resources and attention. culture in the new multi-year financial program.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: for the ECR Group. - Mr President, the official website of the European Year of Cultural Heritage states that our European cultural heritage, which we undoubtedly want to protect and develop, takes four forms. Material as monuments, intangibles, language, customs, natural and digital. Commissioner Avramopoulos, you have mentioned here who is all involved in this reminder of cultural heritage. You mentioned four thousand players. And my question is: have you also addressed the Christian churches that built Europe? Europe is known for its cathedrals - Strasbourg also has one huge cathedral - and they are architectural gems. Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, let me say, however, that none of those cathedrals was built for itself. The intention is - the building was to represent respect for God. Culture is based on values. Christianity, that is, faith in God, is clearly the spiritual heritage of Europe. I feel that this year of cultural heritage is neglected. Colleague Zdrojewski said that only this late this plenary is devoted to culture, but I would add that we cannot mention respect for God and the upliftment of the soul. But Christianity was the engine for culture and science and the social sphere. And I think we need to be called upon to be proud of this year's cultural heritage of Christianity. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Thank you, colleague, for pointing out this.I would like to assure him that if we are planning a project for this European Year at the national and regional level, eg in the Czech Republic, we have involved, for example, the Archbishopric of Olomouc, but I want to ask you the question: What specific involvement would you imagine?

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Thank you, colleague, for your question.I think there is a really huge field of activity that the Christian churches can imagine.Above all, recall the history.We have church buildings here, not just to pay for them, to treat them, to keep them open.So that many people who have never seen the church from the inside can get inside and look.For example, a well-known event from the Czech Republic and Slovakia is the so-called Night of Churches, when they are open.There are parish workers there and they can show what all the people can know.So I think the church has something to open and we should do it and be able to invite them to do so.Well thank you.

name: Mircea DIACONU
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, since I began to draw up this report, I have had the concrete feeling of aligning the planets. A year with so much historical significance, with so much importance and weight, the first year in which the First World War ended and the borders of Europe were drawn today, when new states, new nations appeared, including my country, Romania, appeared then and because of that, I think we are at a point of extreme importance for all the European institutions. I must thank all those who participated in this report. Many of them are right here in the hall. And, the moment I went through the most difficult moment of my existence in the European Parliament, namely the negotiations with the Commission and the Council, I had everyone by my side, I was like one and I achieved something that happens very rarely or it is very rarely accepted, namely the participation of Parliament together with the other European institutions. The first reaction was that we were violating the treaties - a disaster. In the end we all argued and we managed to achieve this, that's why we are all together. My argument then was the following: it is a year of great importance, we must all be together for this holiday, for this open museum, a huge museum for 27 countries, open for a year, symbolically speaking, to which we must we know each other, to display what we have best and most representative of our national identity in front of each other and others. My argument was this: if there is a problem, a fault, it is the rupture between Europe, the European institutions and the citizen. Those who can better unite this are the members of Parliament themselves. That is why I invite Members of Parliament to be involved everywhere in all Member States in the development of this European Year of Heritage. The news you have given us, Commissioner, is excellent. I hope that at the end of this year we will enjoy expected results.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in a minute I will tell you a little story, that of Paolo Storchi, who is a young Italian archaeologist, thirty years old, who has a dream, which is to unearth an ancient settlement of theIII century BCbetween Reggio Emilia and Parma.It is a beautiful project, which has had the support of important Italian and European universities but never public funding from the Italian government.So what did he do?He became famous for another reason: he won a television quiz called "The legacy" in Italy and half of his winnings have been destined to continue the excavations to find Tannetum.Here, I hope that this Year of cultural heritage will help many Paolo Storchi of Europe who, marginalized by cuts to culture and education, still continue to fight to preserve the heritage of the past and hand it over to future generations.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, as a Brexiteer I often point out there is no European demos. People are primarily loyal to their own nation state, and that is a major flaw in the EU project. I do acknowledge, however, that there is indeed a shared European cultural heritage based primarily on the Christian religion. Look at our cathedrals, including the astonishing one in this fair city. Our great universities, too, grew out of monasteries and cathedral schools, while many masterpiece paintings depict Bible scenes.  Yet the European Year of Cultural Heritage does not seem to understand this, talking instead of ‘discovering diversity’ and ‘starting an inter—cultural conversation’. It promises to be little more, I am afraid, than a multicultural group hug, and yet seldom before has the cultural underpinning which, ultimately, advanced ideas such as female emancipation and democratic reform been more in need of honouring or affirming.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - So the European Year of Cultural Heritage 2018 begins with great anticipation, as my colleague Diacon said here. Why do we want to return to cultural heritage, to our roots? Because if we know our history and cultural heritage, we will be able to better understand today and also prepare for the future of a common Europe. Of the many objectives of the European Year, I would emphasize the focus on regions, local activities, especially the involvement of young people and also new technologies. The EP has explicitly called for important reminders of this year's important symbolic milestones, such as the 100 years since the end of the First World War and the emergence of new states. I will be very interested in how the young generation, those who have not yet been involved, will be involved and use the budget that was eventually approved at 8 000 000. As a Member of Parliament, I therefore personally support the support of regional initiatives, which are being developed, for example, in my region. It will be an exhibition of works of art Broken Time in Olomouc and also a conference on the birth of a modern Central European in Kroměříž, where we will commemorate the years 1848 and 1918. An educational project for the creative involvement of young people from 4 countries was also presented. I will watch very carefully which projects will be supported, because it must not just be a campaign, but it must be a really creative activity. I am afraid that if the bureaucracy wins over creativity, it would be a missed opportunity and it must not happen.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: - Mister President! The Year of Cultural Heritage is a truly European initiative. This applies both to the history of its origins and to its implementation and objectives. Especially today, when populists are trying to incorporate the cultural heritage for their nationalist agenda, we have to put the unity rather than the divide in the foreground. But this also means that 2018 must not be limited to being a mere juxtaposition of national, primarily cultural navel-gazing initiatives. European cooperation must be in the foreground. The year must not degenerate into a flash in the pan. The European project needs a fresh boost. To limit oneself to a common internal market and consumer rights is not enough. What we need is a deeper European cultural and educational policy so that citizens can continue to identify with the EU in the future. The Year of Cultural Heritage must be shaped by a spirit of European coexistence and the common values ​​that unite us all, and this spirit must reach everyone - no matter where and how they live, no matter how old they are. It also needs to send out stronger political signals. The key words here are: improving access to culture, cultural education, preserving cultural heritage, digitizing our film heritage, eliminating the chronic underfunding of culture and education. Let us, together with the Member States and the many civil societies, make this year's initiatives a success that has a lasting effect and brings Europe closer together.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Mr President, it does not seem wrong to me to talk about cultural heritage at night. I remember Hegel writing: "Minerva's owl begins its flight at dusk"; that is, it does not seem inappropriate to me. But that said, I am very pleased that the European institutions have proclaimed 2018 as the European Year of Cultural Heritage and that the Council of Europe, Unesco and Europa Nostra collaborate in this initiative, among others. European history and culture have been profoundly dynamic, beyond compare. And today we have a truly exceptional cultural heritage. I would like that by the end of 2018 an ambitious program or action plan of the Union for cultural heritage could be launched that would serve in the future to preserve and disseminate it. Indeed, this year 2018 should not be limited to a set of events or meetings during these twelve months, but should have continuity, Commissioner. And so I would like that idea of ​​the action plan. One year of paying attention to our heritage is not enough for me. I think that this action plan should even contemplate the creation of a specific fund or budget line for the Union to contribute to the recovery and preservation of cultural heritage, for example, of important architectural ensembles in the Member States. Now that we talk about the future financial perspectives, why not think about an item like that? I know that these actions are often co-financed through European funds for regional development, but a specific item would give greater visibility. It is not only peace, it is not only the economy, it is not only globalization that is the argument that justifies the European Union today. It is also the common historical cultural substrate that is reflected in this brilliant cultural heritage. Therefore, the Union must also help to preserve it. The legal basis for it? It seems to me that it is quite clear in article 167 of the Treaty of Operation.And, in addition, it is not necessary to underline the great tourist and economic impact of good care of cultural heritage.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with the interventions of the colleagues who have preceded me and for this very reason I will limit myself to just a few points. I too would like to start with just one critical observation: I am sorry that the discussion is confined to the end of the day because it deserves a more unified sharing by my colleagues in the European Parliament. 2018, the European Year of Cultural Heritage, must in fact see a choral commitment that makes it not a point of arrival but a starting point. Otherwise we would put in difficulty all the motivations and purposes of the choice which, in truth, and I underline it positively, has seen all the European institutions, the States of the Union and civil society actively involved. It is no coincidence: the conservation and enhancement of the European cultural heritage, in fact, are among other things a fundamental dimension of European identity, the result of a coexistent and shared history, which certainly includes the Christian religious dimension. Coherence, which we cannot lack, asks us that in the next financial framework as Parliament we make some consequent choices with reference to the new generations, education to cultural heritage, to the awareness that cultural heritage is a factor of cohesion and inclusion.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, declaring 2018 the European Year of Cultural Heritage is a testament to a change in mentality. It is high time we realized that culture and tradition are extremely important to Europeans, and we cannot compromise on that anymore. At a time when countries are experiencing financial difficulties, the first thing they do is cut the culture budget. This vicious practice must stop. According to the latest Eurobarometer data, more than 80% of European citizens believe that cultural heritage is important for their region, country and the Union. Let us not forget that Europe is visited by millions of tourists every year precisely because of the rich way of life and culture. I hope that the placement of this topic in the public space will not pass together with 2018, but will start a serious debate on the funds allocated for culture in the next multiannual financial framework. Unfortunately, Bulgaria, which has officially taken over the helm of the EU presidency, is one of the few countries that does not plan special funding for cultural heritage. Too bad for the missed opportunity.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - The debate was very interesting. I also consider the common cultural heritage to be an extremely important phenomenon, and I am glad that the debate is taking place here. I would like to emphasize one more thing. European Common Cultural Space projects strengthen European belonging, and I think that is extremely important today. Nowadays, sometimes some young people do not fully understand why European countries work together, why there is European integration, what benefits European integration brings. I think that it is through culture that we can strengthen our European belonging and thus fight against anti-European sentiments, against separatism, against nationalism. That fight is non-violent and, in my opinion, right. I am very pleased that transnational projects have been mentioned here, which are just about to show common European cultural roots. I ask the Commissioner that these projects should not be burdened with excessive bureaucracy, so that enthusiasts and authors of these projects are not completely overwhelmed by filling in various files and documents, but so that these people can really devote themselves to their creativity, as Mrs Šojdrová mentioned. It will then be a good idea to then evaluate these projects to see what impacts they have had and how EU citizens have been visited.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Mr President, our principles and values ​​as the European Union are the essence of our European culture. And our culture, Commissioner, is the supreme interest that holds us together to shape our common European future. That is why we warmly welcome this initiative and congratulations to all the contributors. However, our joy becomes pain and sorrow at the same time, because in the territory of the European Union, in the Northern Occupied Territory of the Republic of Cyprus, the Turkish army and Erdogan continue to protect. I will give you some numbers that concern us all as Europeans: 500 Greek Orthodox churches and chapels and 17 monasteries, which have survived centuries and conquerors, are being destroyed. 15,000 church icons were stolen and never found. 60,000 ancient relics have been illegally transported outside Cyprus. Now you know why our joy is pain and sorrow at the same time.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, 2018 as the European Year of Cultural Heritage must, among other things, be dedicated to the repatriation of stolen cultural property. I will not refer, Mr Avramopoulos, today to the archaeological treasures looted by the Nazis during the German occupation of 1941-1944 in Greece, an issue on which I have repeatedly informed the House. On the occasion of the Bulgarian Presidency, Mr Avramopoulos, I will focus on the issue of the stolen treasures of Macedonia, the so-called "Elginians" of Macedonia. So in the spring of 1917, the then Bulgarian occupation troops raided the Holy Monastery of Eikosifoinissi and the Holy Monastery of Timios Prodromos, which they looted by seizing ecclesiastical texts, manuscripts and history books, which are now in Sofia, in the center of Slavo-Byzantine "Ivanje" and the History Museum of Bulgaria. I consider it a historic opportunity for Bulgaria to proceed immediately with the return of the "Elginians" of Macedonia. This is what I would say today to Mr Borissov, who made the move to call Skopje "Macedonia". Unfortunately, I did not speak.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to express my thanks to all of you who participated in this debate. To be frank with you, I would prefer to see more people in the Chamber today. You who are present here have proven your strong interest in, and support for, the European Year of Cultural Heritage.  Our cultural heritage forms our identity, which is naturally rooted in the national and local context, but which also transcends borders to form and strengthen a European identity. Our cultures have common denominators, such as common democratic values, common principles and, most importantly, a common cultural consciousness, which will define our common European cultural future. With full respect for our national cultures, we can build the pillars of our common cultural architecture for the years to come. I am sure that many events that will be happening throughout the year will successfully spread this message. In this context, I would urge you to become ambassadors of the Year by making its ideas and activities widely known amongst European citizens and participating in events, be it at European, national or local level. The Commission will continue working with you as one of our principal partners of the Year. More than the economy, what will define the future of our union is our common cultural identity, which will guide us towards our common future as genuine believers in the European ideal. We can be, in a very harmonious way, proud of our national heritage, and we can be Europeans in our spirit and consciousness. This is the noble goal that the European Year of Cultural Heritage is meant to serve.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - The European cultural heritage is a common good that must be protected, preserved and enhanced in the best possible way and not used instrumentally to try to give oneself some visibility in view of the electoral campaign. I believe that it is essential to draw up a long-term plan and strategy also at the European level and not to launch extemporaneous initiatives, which are, moreover, without the appropriate financial resources, which are reduced to the media level only. Cultural heritage must be preserved and valued on a daily basis because only culture and knowledge can help us to obtain the intellectual means useful to better interpret the complex present reality, as well as to understand and accept those who are different from us. In this regard, concrete projects for the recovery, preservation and enhancement of cultural heritage would be needed. In this way, European citizens could experience first-hand the usefulness of such an initiative which otherwise risks remaining an empty spot. Furthermore, there are too many cultural operators whose professionalism is not recognized and who are abandoned when the spotlight goes out. Instead, the European Union should support these actors and offer solutions, together with the Member States, to the problems they face alone.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - With 453 sites inscribed, Europe accounts for about half of Unesco's world heritage. And, although under Article 167 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, heritage preservation is the responsibility of states, the contribution of programs like Creative Europe has been significant. However, these should not obscure the financing needs for the renovation of old buildings, while public funds are becoming scarce. The situation is particularly critical in France, exacerbated by the State's withdrawal from local finances. Thus, between 2003 and 2007, the proportion of monuments in a defective state of conservation rose from 32% to 41%, the crisis accentuating this trend. The awareness-raising actions deployed as part of the Heritage Year cannot therefore take the place of a real promotion effort, especially since the Eurobarometer of December 7, 2017 shows that the importance given to heritage is mostly shared by Europeans. Likewise, volunteering cannot be equated with renovation work, which requires specific skills. The European Year of Cultural Heritage could be an opportunity to promote these little-known professions, despite their tangible career prospects.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The main objective of the European Year is to celebrate Europe's cultural heritage as a common legacy from centuries of history, uniting the Member States and the peoples of Europe. The initiative is designed to help as many people as possible discover and learn about Europe's cultural heritage. It is important to nurture and protect our cultural heritage and to pass it on to future generations. That is why, in this European Year, we want to address young people in particular. In 2018, a number of cultural events will take place at European, national, regional and local levels. During the year, citizens can take part in events and projects that present and promote Europe's cultural heritage and values, reinforcing a sense of Europeanness. The professional program series of the European Year of Cultural Heritage will start with an opening conference in Hungary on January 22, where the strategy for the implementation of the Year in Hungary, as well as the state-monument restoration projects and the government's values ​​for preserving values ​​will be presented. Hungary considers the protection and preservation of the built and natural heritage of Hungary to be a priority task, whether it is a site of domestic significance or a world heritage site. I wish you every success in the realization of the Year in Hungary.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – I warmly welcome this year’s European year of cultural heritage. Undoubtedly, our cultural heritage and history are powerful agents which could reinforce a sense of belonging in EU citizens to our common European space and identity. Looking from this perspective, I believe that the initiative will promote cultural diversity, intercultural dialogue and social cohesion in a time when racism, xenophobia and nationalism are threating our EU integration. In the long term, the European year of cultural heritage will help build closer relationships between different regions at EU, national, regional and local level. Last but not least, the European year of cultural heritage could be a golden opportunity to teach future generations about our traditions and cultural heritage. So let us seize that opportunity – let us not miss it.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. - The European Year of Cultural Heritage and the public debate on taking stock of Europe's cultural heritage are extremely topical in 2018. Now that cultural memory and heritage are relativising, when many Europeans are being asked exactly who we Europeans are and what vision we face, it is important to show the values ​​that unite and distinguish us Europeans. from others. Some of our cultural heritage is linked to our religious traditions, others to our national identity and there are components that are elements of our common European identity. Like humanism, the renaissance or just religious freedom. Religious freedom, which was almost proclaimed in Europe almost 450 years ago, was first proclaimed in Transylvania in Turda in 1568, thirty years before the edict of Nantes. I wish the Commission every success in the events of the year and I call on the Member States to do their utmost to make this high-quality series a success.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: in writing. - The proclamation of 2018 as the European Year of Cultural Heritage is an ideal opportunity to claim more resources for culture. Resources for the promotion of our monuments, archeological sites and museums. The support of our cultural identity is an obligation towards our history and place but also a legacy to our children and young people. At the same time, we should emphasize that through the strengthening of industries and businesses related to culture, new jobs and business opportunities can be created that can, in partnership with sectors such as tourism and agriculture, but also with the modernization infrastructure and digital media, to make a decisive contribution to our economy.
